THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
In the Interest of: Justin B., a minor under the age of seventeen 
  years,        Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Bamberg County
Dale Moore Gable, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-237
Heard March 24, 2004 â€“ Filed April 
  6, 2004

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Acting Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of the South 
  Carolina Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  Assistant Attorney General W. Rutledge Martin, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Barbara R. Morgan, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  The family court adjudicated 
  Justin B., a minor under the age of seventeen, delinquent, finding he had committed 
  first-degree criminal sexual conduct.Â  The court later reduced the offense to 
  assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature and committed the juvenile 
  to the South Carolina Department of Juvenile Justice for an indeterminate period, 
  not to exceed the juvenileâ€™s twenty-first birthday.Â  The juvenile contends the 
  court erred when it found the four-year-old victim competent to testify.Â  We 
  reverse and remand.
This action began upon the filing of 
  a juvenile petition in which the juvenile is alleged to have committed first-degree 
  criminal sexual conduct on a two-year-old male [1]  in violation of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 
  16-3-655(1) (1976 as amended) by having the two-year-old child perform fellatio.Â  
  At the hearing, when the state called the child, then four years old, to 
  the witness stand, the following occurred:

THE COURT:Â  Good morning.
THE WITNESS:Â  Good morning.
THE COURT:Â  What is your name?
THE WITNESS: [The witness responds with his name.]
THE COURT:Â  . . . [I]n just a minute, some of these folks 
  are going to ask you some questions.Â  This man right here might ask you some 
  questions, and this man right here might ask you some questions.Â  Can you answer 
  their questions for me?Â  Tell me yes or no.Â  Are you going to answer their questions?
THE WITNESS:Â  Yes.
THE COURT:Â  Now, . . . I am the Judge in this case.Â  Do you 
  understand that?
THE WITNESS:Â  Yeah.
THE COURT:Â  Good.Â  You can talk good and loud.Â  Now, when 
  these gentlemen ask you a question, I want you to tell them the truth.Â  Do you 
  understand that?
THE WITNESS:Â  Yes.
THE COURT:Â  Do you know what the truth is?Â  See that lady 
  over there, when you say yes or no, it comes through on this microphone. Stand 
  up there closer to the microphone.Â  Now, say â€œyes,â€ for me one time.
THE WITNESS:Â  Yes.
THE COURT:Â  Did you hear how good it comes through the microphone?Â  
  When I ask you questions, I want you to say the answer into the microphone, 
  okay?Â  Can you do that?Â  Are you going to tell these men the truth?
THE WITNESS:Â  I donâ€™t know.
THE COURT:Â  Oh, you donâ€™t know now?Â  A while ago you told 
  me you were going to tell me the truth.Â  Letâ€™s see if we can try to get through 
  this.Â  They are going to ask you some questions, and I want you to tell them 
  the truth, okay?Â  Do you understand what the truth is?
THE WITNESS:Â  (Nods head.)
THE COURT:Â  Do you understand what a lie is?
THE WITNESS:Â  Yes.
THE COURT:Â  Okay.Â  I am going to let yâ€™all start with the 
  questions.Â  I am not going to make any ruling at this point in time.Â  I will 
  let him go through with the questions.Â  He told me he understands what telling 
  the truth is and not telling the truth is.Â  The main thing is, he needs to just 
  answer the question.Â  And we will note for the record when he nods his head 
  and when he shakes his head.
MR. WILSON:Â  Your Honor, will we be allowed, very brief [sic] 
  to question him on competency?
THE COURT:Â  Yes, I will let you do that.
BY MR. WILSON:
Q.Â  . . . What is your real name?
A.Â  [Name given.]
Q.Â  How old are you . . . ?
A.Â  Four years old.
Q.   Â Four years old now?Â  Are you in school yet?
A.   Â Uh-huh.
Q.   Â Where are you in school?
A.   Â [Supplies name.]
Q.   Â [Name of school]?Â  Is that what you said, [name of school]?Â  
  Do you remember your teacherâ€™s name?Â  What is your teacherâ€™s name?
A.Â  [Supplies name.]
Q.Â  What is your mamaâ€™s name?
A.Â  [Supplies name.]
Q.Â  Do you live with your mama?
A.Â  (Nods head.)
Q.Â  Does anybody else live in the house 
  with you?
A.Â  Yes.
Q.Â  Who else?
A.Â  My daddy.
Q.Â  What is his name?
A.Â  Dad-Dad.
Q.Â  Do you know what the truth is . . 
  . ?
A.Â  Yeah.
Q.Â  Do you know what a lie is?Â  Can you tell me what you 
  think a lie is?
A.Â  That you dig up dirt.
Q.Â  Can you say that again for me?
A.Â  That you dig up dirt.
Q.Â  That you dig up dirt, thatâ€™s a lie?Â  Do you know what 
  happens if you tell the truth?Â  What happens if you tell the truth?
A.Â  You get a beating.
Q.Â  You get a beating?Â  And what happens if you tell a lie?
A.Â  You get a beating.
MR. WILSON:Â Â Â Â  Thatâ€™s all I have, your Honor.
THE SOLICITOR:Â  No questions.

The trial court held the child competent 
  to testify, remarking:

THE COURT:Â  All right.Â  Mr. Wilson, I am going to let him 
  testify.Â  I understand he answers one of your questions that he might get a 
  beating if he tells the truth.Â  But prior to that, you had asked him a question 
  about lying, and he said, â€œDig up dirt.â€Â  And you asked him what happens if 
  he tells the truth, and you changed it.Â  I am going to go ahead and let him 
  testify.

We understand that the qualification of a witness 
  is within the trial courtâ€™s discretion and that a trial courtâ€™s ruling will 
  be reversed only for an abuse thereof.Â  State v. Hudnall, 293 S.C. 97, 
  359 S.E.2d 59 (1987), overruled on other grounds 
  by State v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 435 S.E.2d 859 (1993).Â  We 
  are also aware that, under Rule 601(a), SCRE, â€œ[e]very person is competent to 
  be a witness except as otherwise provided by statute or these rulesâ€; however, 
  Rule 601(b)(2), SCRE, provides, â€œA person is disqualified to be a witness if 
  the court determines that . . . the proposed witness is incapable of understanding 
  the duty of a witness to tell the truth.â€Â  
We think the Rule 601(b)(2) exception to the presumption 
  of competency applies here and hold the family court committed reversible error 
  in finding the child competent to testify.Â  Like the supreme court was in Hudnall, 
  â€œwe are convinced this child could not be held morally accountable for telling 
  a lie.â€Â  Hudnall, 293 S.C. at 99, 359 S.E.2d at 61.Â  A lie is not, as 
  the child defined it, â€œdigging up dirt,â€ for the truth may be found in â€œdirtâ€ 
  just as well.Â  Notably absent from the record is any demonstration that the 
  child understood the difference between lying and telling the truth. 
As to the childâ€™s answering â€œYou get a beatingâ€ 
  to the question â€œWhat happens if you tell the truth,â€ the child was twice 
  asked the question before he answered.Â  Although the inquiry turned from telling 
  a lie to telling the truth, there was nothing confusing or misleading about 
  this rather simple, straightforward question.Â  Particularly troubling, the child 
  gave the identical answer to the question of â€œ[W]hat happens if you tell a lie?â€Â  
  We think the same response by the child to questions about what happens when 
  you tell a lie and when you tell the truth and his defining a lie as â€œdigging 
  up dirtâ€ demonstrated the child did not understand the duty to tell the truth.Â  
  See State v. Needs, 333 S.C. 134, 143, 508 S.E.2d 857, 861 (1998) 
  (â€œA proposed witness understands the duty to tell the truth when he states that 
  he knows that it is right to tell the truth and wrong to lie, that he will tell 
  the truth if permitted to testify, and that he fears punishment if he does lie 
  . . . .â€). 
 REVERSED AND REMANDED. 
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, JJ., 
  concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  Testimony at the hearing indicated, and the family court so 
    found, the victim was three years old at the time the petition alleges the 
    incident happened.Â  The record does not show the age of the juvenile.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In the Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Orilee Loadholt, Jr.,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Lane Cribb, Sheriff of Georgetown County, 
        former Georgetown County Deputy Sheriff Cpl. Charles McLendon (Badge 561) 
        and three unknown officers of the Georgetown County Sheriffâ€™s Department,       
Repondents.
      
    
  


Appeal from Georgetown County
Court of Common Pleas
Benjamin H. Culbertson, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-238
Submitted January 12, 2004 â€“ Filed April 
  12, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
William Isaac Diggs, of Myrtle Beach, for Appellant.
Elizabeth Stuckey Murphy, of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

 PER CURIAM:Â  Orilee Loadholt, Jr., 
  appeals the grant of summary judgment in favor of Lane Cribb, Sheriff of Georgetown 
  County, former Georgetown County Deputy Sheriff Cpl. Charles McLendon, and three 
  unknown officers of the Georgetown County Sheriffâ€™s Department (collectively, 
  â€œRespondentsâ€) in this action for negligence and malicious prosecution.Â  We 
  affirm.
FACTS
On May 16, 1998, Deputy McLendon 
  initiated a traffic stop of Loadholt, an African-American correctional officer 
  at the J. Rueben Long Detention Center, while Loadholt was driving to work.Â  
  Loadholt was dressed in his uniform at the time.Â Â  Following a request by 
  Deputy McLendon for assistance, at least three other unknown deputies arrived 
  on the scene.Â  All of the deputies on the scene were Caucasian.Â  The deputies 
  searched Loadholt and his car and, after finding nothing incriminating, Loadholt 
  was issued a ticket for careless operation of a vehicle.Â  The ticket was dismissed 
  by a magistrate, without a hearing, on July 23, 1998.Â Â Â  
On October 12, 2001, Loadholt filed an 
  action against Sheriff Cribb, McLendon, and the three unknown deputies, alleging 
  malicious prosecution and negligence.Â  According to his complaint, although 
  Loadholt was cooperative and respectful to McLendon and the other officers during 
  the stop and search, he was referred to with the use of â€œracial slurs,â€ insulted 
  by being told he was â€œa disgrace to his uniform,â€ and verbally assaulted by 
  all the deputies.Â  Loadholt alleged the criminal proceedings were instituted 
  â€œwith malice and without probable cause,â€ and only because of his race.Â  Accordingly, 
  Loadholt alleged Respondents were engaged in malicious prosecution of him.Â  
  Loadholt also alleged that Sheriff Cribb was negligent in failing to properly 
  train his officers to respect their positions, to not discriminate on the basis 
  of race, and to arrest only on the existence of probable cause. 
Respondents moved for summary judgment, 
  arguing Loadholtâ€™s claims were governed by the South Carolina Tort Claims Act 
  (â€œTort Claims Actâ€) [1]  and were not timely filed pursuant 
  to the act.Â  After Loadholtâ€™s counsel asserted Loadholt had a claim under 42 
  U.S.C. Â§ 1983, Respondents pointed out that no allegations in Loadholtâ€™s complaint 
  raised a section 1983 claim.Â Â  Loadholt argued the allegations raised in his 
  complaint supported a cause of action against the sheriff under section 1983.Â  
  Loadholt conceded he could not pursue an action for negligence against Sheriff 
  Cribb. 
In an order dated August 19, 2002, the circuit 
  court granted Respondentsâ€™ request for summary judgment as to both causes of 
  action.Â  The court found the Tort Claims Act provided the exclusive remedy for 
  torts committed by governmental employees, and, thus, Loadholtâ€™s cause of action 
  for malicious prosecution was subject to the Actâ€™s two-year statute of limitations.Â  
  Because the suit was not filed until three years after the dismissal of Loadholtâ€™s 
  ticket, the circuit court found the suit was time barred.Â  
The court also found Loadholtâ€™s complaint did not 
  allege facts that would support a cause of action under section 1983.Â  The court 
  noted the complaint did not mention section 1983, nor did it allege that any 
  of Loadholtâ€™s federal rights were violated.Â Â  Loadholt appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An appellate court reviews the grant of a summary 
  judgment motion under the same standard applied by the trial court under Rule 
  56(c), SCRCP.Â  Fisher v. Stevens, 355 S.C. 290, 294, 584 S.E.2d 149, 
  151 (Ct. App. 2003) (citing Baughman v. American Tel. & Tel. Co., 
  306 S.C. 101, 410 S.E.2d 537 (1991)).Â  Rule 56(c) provides summary judgment 
  is appropriate when â€œthere is no genuine issue as to any material fact and . 
  . . the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56(c), 
  SCRCP.Â  In determining whether triable issues of fact exist such as will preclude 
  summary judgment, the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn 
  therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  
  McNair v. Rainsford, 330 S.C. 332, 341, 499 S.E.2d 488, 493 (Ct. App. 
  1998).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Tort Claims Act
A.
Loadholt argues the circuit court erred by applying 
  the limitations period contained in the Tort Claims Act to his cause of action 
  for malicious prosecution because the Respondentsâ€™ actions fell within an exception 
  to the Tort Claims Act.Â  Thus, he argues the three-year statute of limitations 
  provided by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-530 (Supp. 2003) applied and the circuit court 
  erred in granting summary judgment.Â  We disagree.
The Tort Claims Act provides the â€œexclusive 
  civil remedy available for any tort committed by a governmental entity, its 
  employees, or its agents except as provided in Section 15-78-70(b).â€Â  S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 15-78-20(b) (Supp. 2003) (emphasis added).Â  Section 15-78-70(b) provides 
  an exception for certain actions on the part of the state employee: 

Nothing in this chapter may be construed to give an employee 
  of a governmental entity immunity from suit and liability if it is proved that 
  the employeeâ€™s conduct was not within the scope of his official duties or that 
  it constituted actual fraud, actual malice, intent to harm, or a crime involving 
  moral turpitude. 

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-70(b) (Supp. 2003).Â  There is a two-year 
  statute of limitations period for actions brought pursuant to the Tort Claims 
  Act.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-110 (Supp. 2003) (providing that with the exception 
  of persons under a disability as provided for in Section 15-3-40, â€œ. . . any 
  action brought pursuant to this chapter is forever barred unless an action is 
  commenced within two years after the date the loss was or should have been discoveredâ€).Â  

At the summary judgment hearing, Respondents argued 
  Loadholtâ€™s claims fell within the purview of the Tort Claims Act and, as such, 
  the action was governed by the two-year limitations period contained therein.Â  
  Considering the ticket was issued on May 16, 1998, dismissed on July 23, 1998, 
  and Loadholtâ€™s suit was not initiated until October 12, 2001, more than three 
  years later, the claims did not fall within the time period allotted by the 
  Tort Claims Act.Â  Accordingly, Respondents asserted the claims were time barred. 
  Â Loadholt did not contest that more than three years elapsed from the 
  time the ticket was dismissed until the action was filed.Â  However, Loadholt 
  asserted he did not know the ticket had been dismissed until October 16, 1998.Â  
  He argued a question of fact was raised as to this issue, and a jury should 
  have determined whether the action was filed before the appropriate limitations 
  period expired. 
The evidence presented at the summary judgment hearing included 
  affidavits by McLendon and Cribb wherein they denied any wrongdoing in the performance 
  of their duties.Â  In his affidavit, McLendon stated that on the date of the 
  incident, he saw Loadholt â€œtearing down the road going real fast.â€Â  According 
  to McLendon, Loadholt did not stop for his blue light, so McLendon summoned 
  other officers to the scene for assistance.Â Â  McLendon estimated Loadholtâ€™s 
  speed at the time to have been between sixty and sixty-five miles per hour in 
  a thirty-five per hour zone.Â  McLendon averred that no racial slurs were used 
  by any of the officers.Â  
Loadholtâ€™s deposition was also submitted at the hearing.Â  
  Although Loadholt stated in his deposition that the officers were rude to him 
  during the stop and search, Loadholt never testified to any malicious behavior 
  and did not mention anything regarding racial slurs. 
Viewing this evidence in the light most favorable to Loadholt, 
  there was no evidence that the officersâ€™ actions fell within the exception to 
  the Tort Claims Act.Â  Because the Tort Claims Act provides the â€œexclusiveâ€ remedy 
  for torts committed by governmental employees, unless an exception applies, 
  the statute of limitations contained within the act will apply.Â  See 
  Joubert v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs., 341 S.C. 176, 185, 534 
  S.E.2d 1, 5 (Ct. App. 2000) (holding that because nothing in Section 15-78-70(b) 
  references a limitations period, as part of the Tort Claims Act, it is still 
  subject to the Tort Claims Actâ€™s two-year statute of limitations).Â  Accordingly, 
  the circuit court did not err in finding Loadholtâ€™s action fell within the purview 
  of the Tort Claims Act and the applicable two-year statute of limitations applied.Â Â Â  

B.
Turning to the claim of malicious prosecution, one element 
  necessary to maintain an action for malicious prosecution is that the judicial 
  proceedings be terminated in the plaintiffâ€™s favor.Â  Jordan v. Deese, 
  317 S.C. 260, 261-62, 452 S.E.2d 838, 839 (1995); 52 Am. Jur. 2d Malicious 
  Prosecution Â§28 (2000).Â  Thus, the cause of action does not accrue, and 
  the statute of limitations does not begin to run, until after the proceedings 
  are terminated in the plaintiffâ€™s favor.Â  Loadholtâ€™s ticket was dismissed July 
  23, 1998, and thus the cause of action for malicious prosecution accrued on 
  that date.Â  Loadholt alleged: he discovered the dismissal in October 1998; the 
  cause of action did not accrue until that time; and his October 12, 2001, complaint 
  was timely filed pursuant to the general three-year statute of limitations.Â  
  Regardless of which date you refer to, Loadholt clearly filed his action three 
  years after the accrual and outside the Tort Claims Actâ€™s two-year statute of 
  limitations.Â  
Because Loadholtâ€™s cause of action fell within the Tort Claims 
  Act and was brought more than three years after it accrued, we find the circuit 
  court did not err in determining Loadholtâ€™s claim was time barred.Â  Accordingly, 
  summary judgment on his claim of malicious prosecution was proper.Â  
  II.              
42 U.S.C. Â§ 1983 
   
Loadholt also contends the circuit court erred in finding 
  that the complaint did not assert a cause of action under section 1983.Â  He 
  asserts that while he â€œinartfully couched his second cause of action in terms 
  of negligence,â€ he actually alleged Sheriff Cribb violated his civil rights, 
  thus supporting an action pursuant to section 1983.Â  We disagree.
Section 42 U.S.C. 1983 provides liability for persons 
  who, acting under color of state law, deprive United States citizens of the 
  rights, privileges or immunities secured by the Constitution or laws of the 
  United States.Â  See Banks v. Med. Univ. of South Carolina, 314 
  S.C. 376, 382, 444 S.E.2d 519, 522 (1994).Â  The limitations period for actions 
  brought pursuant to section 1983 is adopted from a state courtâ€™s statute governing 
  an analogous cause of action.Â  See Wilson v. Garcia, 471 U.S. 
  261, 271 (1985) (holding that courts must adopt a â€œpersonal injuryâ€ statute 
  of limitations period in state court in section 1983 actions).Â  In South Carolina, 
  the general three-year limitations period for personal injury actions found 
  in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-530(5) (Supp. 2003) would apply.
Loadholtâ€™s cause of action for negligence against 
  Sheriff Cribb alleged that the sheriff was negligent in failing to train his 
  officers: (1) not to abuse their authority, (2) to refrain from discriminating 
  on the basis of race; (3) to make arrests only upon the issuance of probable 
  cause; and (4) to not use race as an element of probable cause.Â Â  Loadholt further 
  alleged in his complaint that as a result of the sheriffâ€™s failure to properly 
  train his deputies, he suffered emotional distress and deserved damages.Â  
The trial court found not only that Loadholt did 
  not mention 42 U.S.C. Â§ 1983 in his complaint, but that he also failed to allege 
  facts sufficient to support a cause of action thereunder.Â  We agree.Â  Loadholt 
  has not alleged that any federal right has been violated by the Respondents.Â  
  Accordingly, he has failed to properly plead a cause of action under 42 U.S.C. 
  Â§ 1983.Â  
CONCLUSION
Therefore, based on the above reasoning, the circuit 
  courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment is 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ.,Â  and CURETON, AJ., concur.

 
   [1]  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 15-78-10 et. seq. (Supp. 
    2003).Â

THIS OPINION 
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT 
  IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Angela C. Linder,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Harris M. Linder,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
C. David Sawyer, Jr., Family Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-239
Submitted March 8, 2004 â€“ Filed April 
  12, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART,
AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Gregory P. Harlow, of Aiken, for Appellant.
Sylvia W. Westerdahl, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This is a divorce action between 
  Harris M. Linder and Angela C. Linder.Â  Husband appeals the family courtâ€™s order, 
  alleging the court erred in refusing to apportion personal property, in requiring 
  Husband to pay a portion of Wifeâ€™s non-marital debt, in considering Wifeâ€™s motion 
  to alter or amend, and in failing to include Wifeâ€™s pension in the apportionment 
  of marital property.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand. 
  [1] 
BACKGROUND
Husband and Wife married in 1986 and separated 
  in 2001.Â  In its final order, filed on March 18, 2002, the family court granted 
  a divorce on the ground of one-year continuous separation and awarded Wife the 
  marital home and Husband a motorcycle.Â  The court also found $16,400 in unsecured 
  marital debt and apportioned the debt according to income, ordering Husband 
  to pay 39% of the marital debt and Wife to pay 61%.Â  However, the family court 
  refused to apportion the personal property and referred the parties to magistrateâ€™s 
  court to divide the property.Â  
Husband timely filed a motion to alter 
  or amend the judgment.Â  He requested the court divide the personal property, 
  exclude from the equitable distribution a portion of the debt he believed Wife 
  incurred post-separation, and include Wifeâ€™s pension in the property division.Â  
  Wife filed a motion to alter or amend on April 8, 2002.Â  Husband moved to dismiss 
  the motion, alleging it was not timely.Â  The court allowed Wife to proceed with 
  her motion.Â  The court denied Husbandâ€™s motion and granted Wifeâ€™s motion, declaring, 
  among other things, that Husband had no interest in Wifeâ€™s pension plan.Â  Husband 
  appeals.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court has 
  the authority to find facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance 
  of the evidence.Â  Greene v. Greene, 351 S.C. 329, 335, 569 S.E.2d 393, 
  397 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  This broad scope of review does not require us to disregard 
  the findings of the family court.Â  Id.Â  Neither are we required to ignore 
  the fact that the family court judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in 
  a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight 
  to their testimony.Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
  I.                  
  Family Courtâ€™s Refusal to Apportion Personal Property
At the final hearing, Husband and Wife presented 
  the court with lists of personal property.Â  Husbandâ€™s list provided a value 
  for virtually every item of personal property.Â  Wifeâ€™s list, however, did not 
  contain values for most items.Â  Both Husband and Wife argue the family court 
  erred by refusing to apportion personal property and, instead referring the 
  parties to magistrateâ€™s court.Â  We agree and remand for resolution ofÂ  this 
  issue. 
The family court has exclusive jurisdiction 
  over a divorce and the settlement of all legal and equitable rights of the parties 
  in and to the real and personal property of the marriage.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 
  20-7-420(2) (Supp. 2003).Â  Because the family court has exclusive jurisdiction 
  over this issue, the magistrateâ€™s court is without jurisdiction and, therefore, 
  the family courtâ€™s order left the parties without a remedy for dividing the 
  personal property.Â  The family court clearly erred when it found it had â€œno 
  wayâ€ to value and divide the personal property and referred the parties to magistrateâ€™s 
  court for a division of the property.Â  Based on the above, we remand this issue 
  to the family court for further proceedings to apportion the personal property.
  II.               
  Wifeâ€™s Post-Separation Debt
Wife obtained a loan from Beneficial Finance in 
  March 1999, nearly two years prior to the partiesâ€™ separation.Â  Wife testified 
  she incurred an additional $5,300 on the Beneficial loan after the parties separated, 
  increasing the total due on that debt to $13,349.Â  Husband claims the family 
  court required him to pay 39% of this post-separation debt.Â  We disagree and 
  find the family court judge ordered Husband to pay 39% of the marital 
  debt, only.Â  
The family court found the total marital 
  debt to be $16,400.Â  Although the record does not show the exact calculation 
  the court used to arrive at this figure, based on the total amount he found 
  it appears the court determined the marital debt on the Beneficial loan to be 
  $8,000, which is consistent with Wifeâ€™s records and testimony ($13,349-$5,300=$8,049).Â  
  When this figure is added to the sum Husband claimed was marital unsecured debt 
  on various charge cardsâ€”$8,400â€”the marital debt totals $16,400.Â  Based on the 
  records and testimony before us, we agree this is a correct total of the marital 
  debt.Â  In apportioning this debt, the court ordered Husband to pay $3,700 to 
  Loweâ€™s, $1,700 to Sears, and $996 to Visa, for a total of $6,396, which is 39% 
  of the $16,400 marital debt.Â  We do not discern an abuse of discretion by the 
  family court judge in requiring Husband to pay the amount ordered.Â  
  III.           Wifeâ€™s Rule 
  59(e), SCRCP Motion
Husband claims the family court erred in allowing 
  Wifeâ€™s Rule 59(e), SCRCP motion because it was not timely filed.Â  We disagree.
Although the family court believed Wifeâ€™s 
  motion was not timely filed, he determined the record failed to sustain such 
  a finding because it did not show when the order was served on Wifeâ€™s attorney.Â  
  Therefore, the court heard Wifeâ€™s motion.Â  
 Being mindful of our standard of review 
  in this case, we do not disregard the findings of the family court on this issue.Â  
  Greene, 351 S.C. at 335, 569 S.E.2d at 397.Â  We find no error in allowing 
  Wifeâ€™s motion.Â  This was a factual determination the court was free to make. 

  IV.            Wifeâ€™s 
  Pension
Husband argues the family court erred in failing 
  to include Wifeâ€™s pension in the apportionment.Â  We agree.
â€œA spouse who wishes to claim that certain property 
  is not a part of the marital estate has the burden of presenting witnesses or 
  evidence to establish its non-marital character and also to give the trial court 
  an opportunity to decide the issue.â€Â  Hodge v. Hodge, 305 S.C. 521, 526, 
  409 S.E.2d 436, 439-40 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  
Here, Wife never attempted to prove her pension 
  was non-marital.Â  To the contrary, counsel for the parties discussed equitable 
  division of the pension when the court asked about issues on which the parties 
  agreed.Â  When Wifeâ€™s counsel noted Wifeâ€™s pension had not yet vested, the court 
  stated the pension could be divided by a Qualified Domestic Relations Order.Â  
  Furthermore, during her testimony Wife said she believed Husband would be entitled 
  to a portion of her pension, and when the court mentioned her testimony later 
  during the hearing, Wifeâ€™s counsel accepted the courtâ€™s recollection.Â  Because 
  Wife never attempted to show her pension was non-marital, the court erred in 
  ruling the pension was non-marital.Â  We find Wifeâ€™s pension should be divided 
  by QDRO in the same proportions the judge indicated for equitable distribution.Â  
  Therefore, we reverse and remand to the family court for the preparation and 
  execution of a QDRO dividing the pension in the following proportions:Â  39% 
  to Husband and 61% to Wife.
CONCLUSION
We find the family court erred in refusing to 
  divide the personal property and in excluding Wifeâ€™s pension from the apportionment.Â  
  However, we find the court did not err in determining the amount Husband must 
  pay toward the marital debt or in allowing Wifeâ€™s Rule 59(e) motion.Â  Accordingly, 
  the decision of the family court is
 AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

 
   [1]  
    Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Harry L. Richie,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
James Brian Ingle,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
John W. Kittredge, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-241
Submitted March 8, 2004 â€“ Filed April 
  13, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Andrew N. Poliakoff, of Spartanburg; for Appellant.
H. Brent Fortson, of Greenville; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Harry L. Richie brought suit 
  against James Brian Ingle, alleging damages resulting from an automobile collision.Â  
  During trial, Richie moved for a directed verdict as to liability on the grounds 
  that it was admitted.Â  After noting Ingle admitted only negligence and asserted 
  the accident was not the proximate cause of Richieâ€™s injuries, the court denied 
  the motion.Â  The jury returned a verdict in favor of Ingle.Â  Richie moved for 
  a judgment notwithstanding the verdict and a new trial absolute.Â  The trial 
  judge denied these motions.Â  On appeal, Richie challenges the trial judgeâ€™s 
  failure to grant his directed verdict and new trial motions, as well as his 
  refusal to charge a requested jury instruction.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Ingle testified he was involved in an 
  automobile collision with a third party, which resulted in Ingleâ€™s vehicle spinning 
  around, out of control.Â  His vehicle then came to rest touching Richieâ€™s vehicle, 
  which was at a complete stop at the time the cars made contact.Â  Ingle claimed 
  his car was â€œalmost at a dead restâ€ when it â€œbumped [Richieâ€™s car] at bestâ€ 
  and the vehicles ended up touching.Â  He did not recall a second impact, and 
  did not know the cars were even touching until he let out his clutch and his 
  and Richieâ€™s cars were jarred by this action.Â  Ingleâ€™s passenger testified, 
  when they came to a stop after the initial collision, Ingleâ€™s car was touching 
  the other car, but she did not feel being hit again.Â  
The repairs to Richieâ€™s car cost approximately 
  $1,500. [1] Â  Ingle testified 
  Richie indicated he was okay when he got out of the car following the accident, 
  and that he appeared to be okay.Â  Ingleâ€™s passenger confirmed that Richie appeared 
  to be fine after the accident.Â  
Richie testified, following the accident, 
  he told the third party involved that he had back pain, but because this person 
  had an injured passenger, he told them to go ahead and let the ambulance take 
  her to the hospital.Â  Richie returned home that night and went straight to bed.Â  
  Two days later, he attended a previously scheduled appointment with his chiropractor.Â  
  Richie was subsequently diagnosed as having a herniated disk in the lumbar region 
  of his spine.Â  Dr. Awe, Richieâ€™s chiropractor, testified that in his opinion, 
  Richieâ€™s herniated disk was causally related to the automobile accident.Â  Dr. 
  Darwin Kellar, the neurosurgeon who performed surgery on Richieâ€™s herniated 
  disk, testified he had been given the impression the accident was â€œa near head-on 
  collisionâ€ with a â€œdirect blunt impact of a significant nature.â€Â  He stated 
  the pain Richie was experiencing could have been from an accident, and was not 
  necessarily caused by degenerative disk disease or degenerative joint disease.Â  
  Dr. Darwin testified he found there was a causal relationship between the automobile 
  accident and Richieâ€™s injury.Â  He admitted, however, that any causal relationship 
  he found was attributed to the history given by Richie.Â  He further could not 
  say that the accident exacerbated Richieâ€™s degenerative joint disease.Â  
At trial, Richie introduced damages totaling 
  $39,402.06.Â  The suit was originally brought against both drivers involved in 
  the first accident, but Ingle admitted during the trial that he was at fault 
  in the first accident.Â  Ingleâ€™s counsel stipulated the third driver had no role 
  in the accident.Â  With consent from Richieâ€™s counsel, the other driver was dismissed 
  from the lawsuit.Â  
As the trial continued, the court and the parties 
  engaged in discussions regarding Ingleâ€™s negligence and liability.Â  Richieâ€™s 
  counsel moved for a directed verdict as to liability, primarily based upon the 
  fact that Ingle stipulated he was responsible for the first accident, and he 
  was thus liable for the impact with Richie.Â  The court questioned whether Ingle 
  was admitting liability, or only negligence.Â  After the discussions, the motion 
  was denied.Â  
During the conference on the jury charge, 
  Richie requested a particular charge regarding preexisting conditions.Â  The 
  court found the instruction was encompassed by the general charge being given, 
  and declined to give the specific charge.Â  Following the jury instruction, Richie 
  took exception to the courtâ€™s failure to give the charge as requested.Â  
The jury subsequently returned a verdict in favor 
  of the defendant, Ingle.Â  In his post-trial motions Richie argued he was entitled 
  to judgment notwithstanding the verdict or a new trial under the thirteenth 
  juror doctrine.Â  The trial judge denied the motions after he noted that, while 
  negligence was admitted, proximate cause and damages were contested, and the 
  degree of impact and alleged resulting damages were â€œhotly disputed.â€Â  Although 
  he observed that his view of the evidence as to these contested issues may differ 
  from that of the jury, he still declined to invoke the thirteenth juror doctrine.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Directed Verdict
Richie contends the trial court erred 
  in failing to grant his motion for a directed verdict as to the liability of 
  Ingle, arguing Ingle accepted liability for the accident and the jury should 
  have been so instructed.Â  We disagree.
When reviewing the denial of a motion for directed 
  verdict, the appellate court must view the evidence and all reasonable inferences 
  therefrom in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Wintersteen 
  v. Food Lion, Inc., 344 S.C. 32, 35, 542 S.E.2d 728, 729 (2001).Â  â€œIf the 
  evidence as a whole is susceptible of only one reasonable inference, no jury 
  issue is created and a directed verdict motion is properly granted.â€Â  Id.Â  
  However, as long as the evidence is susceptible to more than one reasonable 
  inference, the motion should be denied and the case should be submitted to the 
  jury.Â  Harvey v. Strickland, 350 S.C. 303, 309, 566 S.E.2d 529, 532 (2002).
Several times during trial, Ingleâ€™s attorney 
  discussed his clientâ€™s fault in regard to the accident.Â  During his opening 
  statement, Ingleâ€™s attorney stated:Â  â€œWe admit fault in this case.Â  Thatâ€™s not 
  why we are here.â€Â  He further stated:Â  â€œ[I]tâ€™s our fault.Â  We agree with that. 
  . . . Weâ€™re just here to really look at this, apply good old-fashioned sense 
  to what is really wrong with Mr. Harry Richie that could have been caused by 
  this kind of impact.â€Â  
Later, during examination of Ingle by 
  Richieâ€™s attorney, Ingleâ€™s attorney interrupted to admit the third-party was 
  not at all responsible for the damages stating: â€œWeâ€™re not contending that we 
  were not at fault.â€Â  He then stipulated that the third driver was not responsible 
  for the accident between Ingle and Richie.  
The main conversation on the issue came 
  after Richie made a motion for directed verdict as to liability.Â  The following 
  colloquy took place between Ingleâ€™s attorney and the court:

Counsel:Â Â Â Â  And I donâ€™t know that - - we admit liability.Â  
  I think we just need to make a comment to them.Â  I think they clearly understand 
  that itâ€™s an admitted case as to the liability on the part of this particular 
  defendant.
Court:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Okay.Â  I didnâ€™t understand that earlier.Â  Thatâ€™s 
  - - and I apologize.Â  That was my fault.Â  I didnâ€™t know you admitted liability.
Counsel: Â Â Â  Okay.
Court:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  So Iâ€™ll just do one option for the Plaintiff 
  and instruct the jury they have to return some reward of money damages for the 
  Plaintiff.
Counsel:Â Â Â Â  If itâ€™s related. Â I guess they could find for 
  the Defendant.
Court:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Weâ€™re back where we were.Â  You say you admit 
  liability.Â  You admit negligence or you admit liability?Â  Thereâ€™s a difference 
  between night and day.
Counsel:Â Â Â Â  . . . We were negligent.Â  We deny liability for 
  damages and that kind of thing under the issue of damages in this case.Â  We 
  admit we were negligent and our party caused the accident.
Court:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  You told me just a minute ago that you admitted 
  liability.
Counsel:Â Â Â Â  I misstated.
Court:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Okay.Â  You meant to say you admitted negligence?
Counsel:Â Â Â Â  Yes.
Court:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  And liability is in dispute? . . .
Counsel:Â Â Â Â  Right.
Court:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . You dispute proximate cause and damages?
Counsel:Â Â Â Â  That is correct.

*Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  *Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  *

Counsel:Â Â Â Â  Okay.Â  Judge, we believe, you know, that we were 
  negligent.Â  He just does not want to accept full liability for everything, that 
  he was negligent, accepts his part in causing the negligent act and that kind 
  of thing - -
Court:         . . . He admits
negligence?
Counsel:Â Â Â Â  Yes.
Court:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The challenge is proximate cause and damages.
Counsel:Â Â Â Â  Correct.Â 

Finally, during closing arguments, Ingleâ€™s counsel 
  again stated that Ingle â€œadmitted heâ€™s liable.â€Â  
â€œIn order to establish a claim for negligence, 
  a plaintiff must prove the following elements:Â  1) a duty of care owed by the 
  defendant to the plaintiff, 2) a breach of that duty by negligent act or omission, 
  and 3) damage proximately caused by the breach.â€Â  Huggins v. Citibank, N.A., 
  355 S.C. 329, 332, 585 S.E.2d 275, 276 (2003).Â  Ingle clearly admitted he owed 
  a duty to Richie and his negligent actions breached that duty.Â  However, Ingleâ€™s 
  counsel indicated that his use of the word â€œliabilityâ€ was a misstatement, and 
  clarified that they challenged proximate cause and damages in this case.Â  Additionally, 
  there was sufficient evidence from which an inference could be drawn that the 
  damages claimed were not proximately caused by the impact between the partiesâ€™ 
  cars.
In spite of the misstatements made by 
  Ingleâ€™s counsel indicating Ingle admitted liability for the accident, the jury 
  had before it evidence from which it could find that Richieâ€™s damages were not 
  proximately caused by the impact between their cars, and thus return a verdict 
  for Ingle.Â  Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to Ingle, an inference 
  could be drawn that he only admitted negligence, and proximate cause and damages 
  were still issues to be determined by the jury.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial 
  court properly denied the motion for a directed verdict as to liability.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Thirteenth Juror Doctrine
Richie maintains the trial court erred 
  in failing to grant a new trial absolute under the thirteenth juror doctrine.Â  
  He asserts the evidence does not justify a defense verdict in this case.Â  We 
  find no error.
â€œThe thirteenth juror doctrine is a vehicle 
  by which the trial court may grant a new trial absolute when he finds that the 
  evidence does not justify the verdict.Â  This ruling has also been termed granting 
  a new trial upon the facts.â€Â  Folkens v. Hunt, 300 S.C. 251, 254, 387 
  S.E.2d 265, 267 (1990).Â  â€œA trial judgeâ€™s order granting or denying a new trial 
  upon the facts will not be disturbed unless his decision is wholly unsupported 
  by the evidence, or the conclusion reached was controlled by an error of law.â€Â  
  Id. at 254-255, 387 S.E.2d at 267.Â  In reviewing the denial of a motion 
  for a new trial under the thirteenth juror doctrine, the appellate court must 
  consider only whether there is any evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s decision.Â  
  Haselden v. Davis, 341 S.C. 486, 506, 534 S.E.2d 295, 306 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  
  Thus, in order to reverse such a denial, the appellate court must find the moving 
  party was entitled to a directed verdict at trial.Â  Id.
The record in this case contains contested evidence 
  regarding the severity of the impact of the cars and the amount of damages resulting 
  from the impact.Â  Ingle testified that the contact between the cars was very 
  light, describing the cars as only touching and stating, â€œwe bumped at best.â€Â  
  Ingle testified that the damage to his car was a â€œ[v]ery, very small dent,â€ 
  as depicted in a picture of the side of his car which came into contact with 
  Richieâ€™s.Â  The passenger in Ingleâ€™s vehicle testified that they came to a stop 
  after the first collision and she did not feel another impact, but discoveredÂ  
  Ingleâ€™s car was touching Richieâ€™s car when they attempted to exit the vehicle.Â  
  Richie, on the other hand, testified the photograph of Ingleâ€™s car was not an 
  accurate depiction of how his car appeared immediately after the collision.Â  
  He stated that it looked as if the sheet metal on the door panel of Ingleâ€™s 
  car had popped back out, while it appeared to be pushed in approximately six 
  inches right after the accident.Â  
Additionally, the medical testimony conflicted.Â  
  Ingle and his passenger both testified that Richie seemed unhurt after the impact 
  and that he was able to move around fine.Â  After the impact, Richie allowed 
  a passenger in the first accident to be taken by ambulance.Â  Instead of seeking 
  immediate medical attention, Richie went home for the evening and did not seek 
  any treatment for injuries until two days later when he saw his chiropractor 
  during a previously scheduled appointment.Â  
Further, Richieâ€™s neurosurgeon, Dr. Keller, testified 
  that Richie suffered from degenerative disk disease or degenerative joint disease.Â  
  He stated there could be a causal connection between the accident and the herniated 
  disk, but admitted his diagnosis of a connection was based upon the history 
  presented by Richie.Â  He also stated Richie had described the accident to him 
  â€œas something of a near head-on collisionâ€ and he got the impression that it 
  was a â€œpretty direct blunt impact of a significant nature.â€Â  Additionally, Dr. 
  Keller admitted he could not say whether or not the wreck exacerbated the preexisting 
  degenerative joint disease.Â  
The record contains contradictory evidence regarding 
  the severity of the impact between Ingleâ€™s and Richieâ€™s vehicles, as well as 
  medical testimony which contains some uncertainty regarding the cause of his 
  herniated disk.Â  Based upon our limited standard of review, we cannot say the 
  trial courtâ€™s decision is wholly unsupported by the evidence, or the conclusion 
  reached was controlled by an error of law.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court 
  did not abuse its discretion in denying the motion for a new trial under the 
  thirteenth juror doctrine.
III.Â Â Â  Jury Charge
Richie asserts the trial court erred in 
  refusing to charge the jury with his requested charge regarding his preexisting 
  condition.Â  We disagree.
The circuit court must charge the current and correct 
  law to the jury.Â  McCourt v. Abernathy, 318 S.C. 301, 306, 457 S.E.2d 
  603, 606 (1995).Â  When reviewing jury charges for error, an appellate court 
  must consider the courtâ€™s charge as a whole in light of the evidence and issues 
  presented at trial.Â  Keaton ex rel. Foster v. Greenville Hosp. Sys., 
  334 S.C. 488, 497, 514 S.E.2d 570, 575 (1999).Â  A jury charge is correct if, 
  when read as a whole, it contains the correct definition and adequately charges 
  the law.Â  Id. at 495-96, 514 S.E.2d at 574.Â  It is the substance of the 
  law that must be instructed to the jury, not any particular verbiage.Â  Id. 
  at 496, 514 S.E.2d at 574.Â  Further, refusal to give a properly requested charge 
  is not error if the general instructions are sufficiently broad to enable the 
  jury to understand the law and the issues involved.Â  McCourt, 318 S.C. 
  at 306, 457 S.E.2d at 606.
Richie asked the court to instruct the 
  jury with the following language:

That Plaintiff has preexisting condition resulting in greater 
  susceptibility to injury would not diminish his entitlement to damages for personal 
  injuries.Â  

The trial court denied the specific request, 
  noting that the proposed instruction was covered by the courtâ€™s general charge.Â  
  The trial courtâ€™s instruction given to the jury included the following relevant 
  instruction:

I now want to charge you on a principle of law called preexisting 
  condition.Â  [An] injured person is entitled to recover full compensation for 
  all damages which proximately directly result from a defendantâ€™s negligent act 
  or omission.Â  This is so even if the personâ€™s injuries may have been aggravated 
  by reason of a preexisting condition.Â  A defendant cannot invoke a preexisting 
  condition of the person injured for the purpose of escaping the consequences 
  of his own negligence or reducing the damages for which he is liable.
If a plaintiff is suffering from a preexisting condition 
  and the preexisting condition is aggravated by injuries sustained in a subsequent 
  accident for which you find the plaintiff should be compensated, the plaintiff 
  would be entitled to be compensated for the aggravation of the preexisting injury 
  or condition as well as any new or additional injuries sustained in the subsequent 
  accident.Â  Provided, of course, such aggravation or new injury is the natural 
  and proximate result of the negligence of the defendant.

The circuit courtâ€™s charge contained the current 
  and correct law. When considered as a whole, the general instructions contained 
  the correct definitions and adequately charged the substance of the law.Â  Refusal 
  to give the instruction specifically requested was not error since the general 
  instructions were sufficiently broad to enable the jury to understand the law 
  and the issues involved.Â  Accordingly, we find no error in the charge as given 
  by the court or in its refusal to charge the specific language requested by 
  Richie.
CONCLUSION
We find the trial court did not err in 
  denying Richieâ€™s motion for a directed verdict as to liability.Â  While Ingleâ€™s 
  attorney acknowledged he had admitted liability, he informed the court that 
  was a misstatement, and he clearly indicated Ingle contested proximate cause 
  and damages and admitted only negligence.Â  Because the evidence was susceptible 
  to more than one reasonable inference, the motion was properly denied.Â  We further 
  hold there was conflicting evidence in the record such that the trial court 
  did not err in refusing to grant a new trial pursuant to the thirteenth juror 
  doctrine.Â  Finally, while the jury charge did not use the specific language 
  requested by Richie, the charge, considered as a whole, was sufficiently broad 
  to enable the jury to understand the law and the issues involved.Â  Accordingly, 
  the decisions of the trial court are 
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, STILWELL, and CURETON, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  
    In his complaint, Richie sought compensation for damages related to his physical 
    injuries, but not for damages to his automobile.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE. IT SHOULD NOT 
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), 
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Edward Littles       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Marlboro County
John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-242
Submitted October 15, 2003 â€“ Filed April 
  15, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Edward Littles, Jr., pro se Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy 
  Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney 
  General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General Melody J. 
  Brown, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Jay E. Hodge, Jr., of Darlington,
for Respondent. 
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Littles was 
  indicted for murder.Â  The case was called for trial on February 12, 2002.Â  After 
  jury selection, the judge adjourned court for the day.Â  Littles was allowed 
  to stay on bond, but the court informed Littles that failure to appear at the 
  trial would not delay the trial from moving forward.Â  On February 13, 2002, 
  Littles did not return to court.Â  On February 14, 2002, Littles returned for 
  the second day of trial.Â  The jury convicted him of murder.Â  The judge sentenced 
  Littles to 40 years imprisonment.Â  This appeal follows.
FACTS
The victim, Harold 
  Richard Williams, owned a small store and poolroom in Bennettsville, South Carolina.Â  
  On August 11, 1999, the victimâ€™s wife, Kathy Moody, went to the store to see 
  the victim and pick up supplies for a planned outing scheduled for the following 
  day.Â  When Ms. Moody arrived, a group of men were at the store, including Edward 
  Littles, Jr.Â  Some members of the group were playing pool; Mr. Littles was observing 
  them play.Â  
At some point later, 
  Littles, Maurice McNeil and a man named Shawn (whose last name was unknown) 
  were outside in the middle of the street. They were involved in an altercation.Â  
  Littles approached McNeil and Shawn as they were crossing the street.Â  Littles 
  called to McNeil and stated â€œAll I asked you to do is buy me a beer.â€ Shawn 
  returned to where Littles and McNeil were talking and informed Littles that 
  he was trying to get home and did not want any trouble. Littles pointed his 
  gun at Shawn and told him that he was not speaking to him.Â  Shawn ran away, 
  while McNeil stood there.Â  Eventually, Littles and McNeil returned to the inside 
  of the store so that McNeil could return a paged call.Â  
Once McNeil and Littles were 
  inside the store, McNeil used the telephone. When McNeil picked up the telephone 
  and started dialing, Littles came around to where the phone was and pulled 
  McNeilâ€™s hand off the telephone and pulled McNeil away from the phone.Â  At that 
  point, McNeil and Littles began fighting.Â  Williams pulled out a gun and requested 
  Littles leave.Â  Littles got â€œcrazy, loudâ€ and said that he was not afraid of 
  the gun.Â  Williams picked up his gun and struck Littles on the forehead and 
  pushed him out the door.Â  As Williams was pushing Littles out the door 
  the clip fell from Williamsâ€™ gun.Â  
Littles returned and threatened 
  to shoot Moody, then shot Williams.Â  After shooting Williams, Littles 
  went outside.Â  After Littles left, there were several shots outside.Â  Littles 
  returned to the store and fired several shots into Williams, who was on the 
  floor. Williams was pronounced dead at the scene.Â  Â 
The case was called for trial 
  on February 12, 2002. Prior to the beginning of the trial, the judge allowed 
  Littles to remain on bond.Â  However, the judge admonished Littles that the trial 
  would proceed whether Littles was present.Â  Littles did not show for the second 
  day of trial and the trial proceeded and testimony was completed.Â  Littles returned 
  before closing arguments on the last day of trial.Â  He was convicted of murder 
  and sentenced to forty (40) years.Â  Littles appeals.
ISSUES 

  1.                 
  Did the trial court err in proceeding with the trial in abstentia?
  2.                 
  Did the trial court err in denying Appellantâ€™s motion for directed verdict on 
  the grounds of lack of evidence?

LAW/ANALYSIS
1. Trial In Abstentia
Littles asserts the trial court erred in trying 
  him in absentia. We disagree.Â  
Rule 16 of the South Carolina Rules of Criminal 
  Procedure provides:Â  

Except in cases wherein capital 
  punishment is a permissible sentence, a person indicted for misdemeanors and/or 
  felonies may voluntarily waive his right to be present and may be tried in his 
  absence upon a finding by the court that such person has received notice of 
  his right to be present and that a warning was given that the trial would proceed 
  in his absence upon a failure to attend the court.Â Â  

Rule 16, SCRCrimP.Â  
â€œA trial judge must determine a criminal defendant 
  voluntarily waived his right to be present at trial in order to try the case 
  in absentia.â€Â  See Rule 16, SCRCrimP; State v. Castineira, 
  341 S.C. 619, 623, 535 S.E.2d 449, 451 (Ct.App. 2000)Â  â€œThe judge must make 
  findings of fact on the record that the defendant (1) received notice of his 
  right to be present; and (2) was warned he would be tried in his absence should 
  he fail to attend.â€ Castineira, 341 S.C. at 623, 535 S.E.2d 451; State 
  v. Jackson, 288 S.C. 94, 96, 341 S.E.2d 375 (1986).
The record establishes the trial judge made the 
  requisite inquiries and findings; and counsel stipulated that Littles received 
  the proper notice, not only from the court, but also from counsel himself. Therefore, 
  this issue is without merit.
2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Directed Verdict Motion
Although Littles raises the denial of the directed 
  verdict motion in his statement of the issues on appeal, he failed to argue 
  it in his brief. â€œAn issue raised on appeal but not argued in the brief is deemed 
  abandoned and will not be considered by the appellate court.â€Â  Fields v. 
  Melrose Ltd. Partnership, 312 S.C. 102, 106, 439 S.E.2d 283, 285 (Ct.App. 
  1993).
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the trial courtâ€™s 
  ruling is 
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION 
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT 
  IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Carolina Power & Light Company,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Lynches River Electric Cooperative, Inc.,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Chesterfield County
J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-247
Heard March 11, 2004 â€“ Filed April 15, 
  2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Marcus A. Manos and J. David Black, both of Columbia, and 
  Thomas H. Pope, III, of Newberry, for Appellant.Â  
Mark W. Buyck, Jr., and Mark W. Buyck, III, both of Florence, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Carolina Power & Light 
  brought this declaratory judgment action against Lynches River Electric Cooperative 
  seeking a declaration of rights regarding the provision of electric service 
  to a Bi-Lo supermarket in the Town of Pageland.Â  Lynches River appeals the trial 
  courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment to CP&L.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Since 1925, CP&L and its predecessor 
  have provided electric service to the residents of the Town of Pageland.Â  Lynches 
  River began offering electric service in 1939.Â  In 1949, the Town of Pageland 
  extended its one-half mile radius boundary by annexing land within a radius 
  of one mile from the center of town.Â  The newly annexed area included electric 
  utility lines owned by both CP&L and Lynches River.Â  CP&L, however, 
  has always been the principal supplier of electricity to the town.Â  
In May of 1981, the town granted CP&L 
  an indeterminate permit to provide electric service to the residents.Â  Since 
  at least 1990, Lynches River has provided electric service to tenants in a strip 
  mall, including Bi-Lo.Â  The structure was located outside the original town 
  boundary, but inside the annexed area.Â  Lynches River has also provided electric 
  service to the parking lot adjacent to the structure.Â  CP&L has not challenged 
  Lynches Riverâ€™s right to continue service to the strip mall.Â  
In 2001, Bi-Lo began construction on a 
  new store located across the parking lot from the existing structure.Â  The new 
  structure is located entirely within the original town limits.Â  The same developer 
  owns the property upon which both structures are located.Â  
Lynches River and Bi-Lo entered into a contract 
  for electrical service on the new building.Â  Lynches River offered electrical 
  service to the new structure through a distribution point near the existing 
  structureâ€™s distribution point.Â  The distribution points are within the annexed 
  area of the town and not within the original boundary.Â  
CP&L, upon learning that Lynches River was 
  providing the electrical service to the new structure, filed this claim for 
  a declaratory judgment.Â  CP&L filed a motion for summary judgment, claiming 
  Lynches River could not serve electricity in the original town boundaries because 
  it is not a rural area and Lynches River failed to meet any of the exceptions 
  allowing it to provide electrical service inside the town.Â  CP&L presented 
  the figure from the 2000 United States Census showing the population was 2,521.Â  

Lynches River filed its own motion for 
  summary judgment, asserting the population was below 2,500 and it could continue 
  service to the new structure because it served the existing structure.Â  Lynches 
  River presented an affidavit by the mayor of the Town of Pageland, which stated 
  it was the mayorâ€™s belief that the population had dropped below 2,500.Â  
The trial court determined the mayorâ€™s 
  affidavit was insufficient to create a genuine issue of material fact as to 
  the population of the town, and that Lynches River did not meet any of the exceptions 
  of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-49-250 (1990) which would allow it to provide electrical 
  service to the new structure.Â  The trial court distinguished the case of Carolina 
  Power & Light Co. v. City of Bennettsville, 314 S.C. 137, 442 S.E.2d 
  177 (1994), finding the point of delivery to the new structure is not in a rural 
  area, but within the town limits.Â  Accordingly, the trial court granted summary 
  judgment to CP&L.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, 
  this court applies the same standard which governs the trial court:Â  summary 
  judgment is proper when â€œthere is no genuine issue as to any material fact and 
  . . . the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56(c), 
  SCRCP; Baughman v. American Tel. & Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101, 114-15, 
  410 S.E.2d 537, 545 (1991).Â  â€œIn determining whether any triable issues of fact 
  exist, the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn from the 
  evidence must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.â€Â  
  Strother v. Lexington County Recreation Commâ€™n, 332 S.C. 54, 61, 
  504 S.E.2d 117, 121 (1998).Â  â€œOn appeal from an order granting summary judgment, 
  the appellate court will review all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences 
  arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to the non‑moving 
  party below.â€Â  Osborne v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 S.E.2d 319, 321 (2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Rural Electric Cooperative Act (RECA) permits 
  the formation of nonprofit cooperatives â€œfor the purpose of supplying electric 
  energy and promoting and extending the use thereof in rural areas.â€Â  S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 33-49-210 (1990). [1] Â  As creatures of statute, rural 
  electric cooperatives â€œonly have such authority as the legislature has given 
  them.â€Â  Duke Power Co. v. Laurens Elec. Co-op., Inc., 344 S.C. 101, 104, 
  543 S.E.2d 560, 562 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  They may only serve rural areas, that 
  is, areas where the population is less than 2,500 persons.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 
  33-49-250(1) (1990).Â  RECA permits a cooperative to serve non-rural areas under 
  two exceptions:Â  (1) the cooperative may continue to provide electrical service 
  to a town in which it is the principal electrical provider, and (2) the cooperative 
  may continue to serve premises it served at the time the area was annexed into 
  the town, and until directed otherwise by the local governing body, it may serve 
  other premises within the same area.Â  Id.
â€œBoth exceptions prevent the ouster of co-ops from 
  areas they have historically served due to population growth or annexation.â€Â  
  Duke Power, 344 S.C. at 105, 543 S.E.2d at 562.Â  The statutory language, 
  therefore, â€œcontemplate[s] [a] co-opâ€™s continued serviceâ€ in an area to which 
  an exception applies.Â  Id.
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Affidavit Regarding Population of the Town of Pageland
Lynches River asserts the trial court 
  improperly attributed no weight to the affidavit of Pagelandâ€™s mayor, Carroll 
  Faile, in regards to the townâ€™s population.Â  Lynches River argues the affidavit 
  is sufficient to create a genuine issue of material fact regarding whether Lynches 
  River has the right to provide electric service because the population has fallen 
  below 2,500 people.Â  We disagree.Â  
Rule 56(e), SCRCP, states:Â  â€œSupporting 
  and opposing affidavits shall be made on personal knowledge, shall set forth 
  such facts as would be admissible in evidence, and shall show affirmatively 
  that the affiant is competent to testify to the matters stated therein.â€Â  Neither 
  the trial court nor this court are â€œrequired to single out some one morsel of 
  evidence and attach to it great significance when patently the evidence is introduced 
  solely in a vain attempt to create an issue of fact that is not genuine.â€Â  Main 
  v. Corley, 281 S.C. 525, 527, 316 S.E.2d 406, 407 (1984).Â  
In his affidavit, the mayor identified himself 
  as the townâ€™s mayor and a resident of the county, asserted he was familiar with 
  the townâ€™s economic conditions and its population trends over the last twenty 
  years, and stated that given the recent economic downturn and the downward population 
  downtrend, he believed and opined that the townâ€™s population was on the decrease 
  and had fallen below 2,500.Â  
In Englert, Inc. v. Netherlands Ins. 
  Co., this court determined an affiantâ€™s status as the vice-president of 
  the company was insufficient to demonstrate he had personal knowledge of the 
  contract and job performed in that case.Â  Englert, 315 S.C. 300, 304, 
  433 S.E.2d 871, 874 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  As in Englert, the mayorâ€™s affidavit 
  fails to provide sufficient admissible evidence to support his belief.Â  Although 
  the mayor states he is familiar with the situation in Pageland, his affidavit 
  is not based on personal knowledge, but is only an opinion based on his belief 
  that the townâ€™s population had decreased.Â  The mayor did not, and obviously 
  could not, state he knew the exact population of the town.Â  Accordingly, the 
  trial court correctly refused to give this â€œmorselâ€ of information such significance 
  as to create a genuine issue of fact regarding the townâ€™s population. 
Because the only properly admitted evidence regarding 
  the townâ€™s populationâ€”the 2000 United States Censusâ€”established the population 
  was 2,521, Lynches River can only service areas within the town if it falls 
  under one of the exceptions mentioned above and discussed below. 
II.Â Â Â Â  Other Exceptions 
Lynches River has not contended it is 
  the principal supplier of electricity in the Town of Pageland and is thus not 
  entitled to provide service inside the town under that exception.
The only other exception that could apply 
  is the annexation exception that would allow Lynches River to continue servicing 
  premises being served at the time of the annexation of an area into the town 
  or additional premises within the annexed area until the town directs otherwise.Â  

Lynches River contends the existing structure 
  and the new structure occupy a single premises because they sit on a single 
  tract owned by the same developer.Â  Although the statute permits the cooperative 
  to service all premises it served prior to the annexation and all premises in 
  that area until instructed otherwise, it specifically states the cooperative 
  â€œshall not extend service to any premises in any other part of such city or 
  townâ€ where, as here, it is not the townâ€™s principal electrical provider.Â  See 
  Â§ 33-49-250(1).Â  Here, the new structure is entirely within the original town 
  limits, an area in which Lynches River has no right to provide service.
Although not directly applicable to the 
  definition of â€œpremisesâ€ in section 33-49-250, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 58-27-610 (1976) 
  defines the term for purpose of that article, which involves the service rights 
  of electric suppliers:

(2) The term â€œpremisesâ€ means the building, structure 
  or facility to which electricity is being or is to be furnished; provided, 
  that two or more buildings, structures or facilities which are located on one 
  tract or contiguous tracts of land and are utilized by one electric consumer 
  for farming, business, commercial, industrial, institutional or governmental 
  purposes, shall together constitute one â€œpremises,â€ except that any such 
  building, structure or facility shall not, together with any other building, 
  structure or facility, constitute one â€œpremisesâ€ if the electric service to 
  it is separately metered and the charges for such service are calculated independently 
  of charges for service to any other building, structure or facility.

(Final emphasis added.)
In the instant case, the existing structure 
  and the new structure are located on one tract of land.Â  However, they will 
  be separately metered and the calculation of the electricity consumed by and 
  billed for the existing structure will be separate from that consumed by and 
  billed for the new structure.Â  As such, they are considered two separate premises 
  even though they are situated on the same tract of land. Accordingly, the trial 
  court correctly concluded Lynches River may not provide service to the new structure.
III.Â Â Â  Carolina Power & Light v. City of Bennettsville
Lynches River argues the holding in Carolina 
  Power & Light Co. v. City of Bennettsville, 314 S.C. 137, 442 S.E.2d 
  177 (1994), applies to its situation because the point of distribution to the 
  new structure lies in the annexed area and outside the original town limits.Â  
  In Bennettsville the court held a cooperative could provide service that 
  was distributed to a point in a rural area even though it was ultimately consumed 
  within the city limits.Â  Id. at 139-40, 442 S.E.2d at 179.
In this case, the distribution point is a new distribution 
  point located in an annexed area of the Town of Pageland, not a rural area as 
  in Bennettsville.Â  Even though the distribution point in this case is 
  in the annexed area, where Lynches River has the right to continue to provide 
  service to existing premises, there was a new connection created which 
  was not authorized by statute.Â  Accordingly, the Bennettsville 
  case is not controlling and the trial court correctly declined to rely upon 
  its holding.
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Sections 33-49-210 and 33-49-250 have been recently amended 
    by Act No. 179, 2004 S.C. Acts ___.Â  The amendments do not affect the outcome 
    of this case.
