THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Larry Foster,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Bettie Foster,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Wylie H. Caldwell, Jr., Family Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No, 2004-UP-248
Submitted March 8, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  15, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Jerry D. Vinson, Jr. and Michele R. Krize, both of Florence, 
  for Appellant.
James M. Saleeby, Sr., of Florence, and Marian Dawn Nettles, 
  of Lake City, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Larry Foster (â€œHusbandâ€) brought 
  this action against his former wife Bettie Foster (â€œWifeâ€) seeking a termination 
  or reduction in alimony based on his substantial change of circumstances.Â  The 
  family court reduced Husbandâ€™s alimony obligation, but only based on Wifeâ€™s 
  change of income.Â  Wife appeals, alleging the trial court erred in modifying 
  the alimony and in failing to award her the full amount of her attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
  We affirm.
FACTS
Husband and Wife married on April 17, 
  1985 and divorced on April 30, 1998.Â  The divorce decree divided the marital 
  estate equally between the parties and granted Wife $1,500 per month in permanent, 
  periodic alimony.Â  Wife appealed.Â  The parties settled the case during the pendency 
  of the appeal with an agreement approved by the family court.Â  This agreement 
  provided Husband would pay Wife $7,500 per month, consisting of $6,000 per month 
  in equitable distribution payments and $1,500 per month in permanent, periodic 
  alimony payments until the last equitable distribution payment was made in January 
  of 2002.Â  After the Husbandâ€™s equitable distribution payment obligations ceased, 
  Husbandâ€™s alimony obligations would increase to $4,000 per month.Â  The agreement 
  further provided that at that time, either party could move for a modification 
  of alimony based on a substantial change of circumstances.Â  
In February 2002, Husband filed this action 
  seeking a reduction or elimination of alimony based on a substantial change 
  of circumstances.Â  He alleged his businessesâ€™ incomes had decreased substantially 
  causing similar decreases in his personal income.Â  In addition to the Husbandâ€™s 
  alleged decrease in income, the family court also considered the wifeâ€™s new 
  employment with a bank in which she earned $1,387.00 per month.Â  
The family court reduced Husbandâ€™s alimony 
  obligation by $1,000 per month, basing the modification solely on Wifeâ€™s new 
  employment, and not Husbandâ€™s alleged loss of business income.Â  The court awarded 
  the Wife $2,500.00 of the attorneyâ€™s fees she requested.Â  This appeal followed.Â  

LAW/ANALYSIS

I.Â  Reduction in alimony

Wife argues the family court erred in finding 
  there had been a substantial change in her circumstances that warrant a reduction 
  in alimony.Â  We disagree.Â  
The family court has the authority to alter alimony 
  payments upon a proper showing of a change of condition.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-170 
  (1985).Â  Questions concerning alimony are in the sound discretion of the family 
  court.Â  Bryson v. Bryson, 347 S.C. 221, 224, 553 S.E.2d 493, 495 (Ct. 
  App. 2001).Â  The family courtâ€™s modification of an alimony award will not be 
  reversed on appeal absent a showing of abuse of discretion.Â  Thornton v. 
  Thornton, 328 S.C. 96, 111, 492 S.E.2d 86, 94 (1997).Â  To justify modification 
  of an alimony award, the changes in circumstances must be substantial or material.Â  
  Sharps v. Sharps, 342 S.C. 71, 76, 535 S.E.2d 913, 916 (2000).Â  â€œGenerally, 
  changes in circumstances within the contemplation of the parties at the time 
  the decree was entered do not provide a basis for modifying either an alimony 
  allowance or a child support award.â€Â  Id. (quoting Calvert v. Calvert, 
  287 S.C. 130, 139, 336 S.E.2d 884, 889 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  Therefore, courts have 
  refused to modify alimony where the parties anticipated the substantial change 
  in circumstances at the time of the divorce decree.Â  Sharps, 342 S.C. 
  at 76, 535 S.E.2d at 916. Â The original divorce decree generally addresses the 
  expected change of circumstances.Â  Id. at 76-77, 535 S.E.2d at
916.  

The family court reduced Husbandâ€™s alimony obligation 
  from $4,000 per month to $3,000 per month.Â  The court stated, â€œThe only reason 
  he is receiving the decrease herein awarded is the Wife managed to land a job 
  immediately before the hearing, candidly disclosed that fact, and allowed that 
  to be considered by the court.â€Â  Wife contends that the fact she now earns a 
  $1,387 per month income is not a sufficient change of circumstances to warrant 
  modification of the alimony award.Â  She argues the parties clearly anticipated 
  she would return to the work force, and therefore, it was error for the family 
  court to modify the alimony award.Â  
We find Wifeâ€™s new employment was a change of 
  circumstances that was unanticipated by the parties at the time of the decree.Â  
  The original decree stated Wife had â€œjob skills as evidenced by her past work 
  history, however, she has been out of the job market for a number of years.â€Â  
  We do not find this as an expression of the courtâ€™s anticipation of Wifeâ€™s future 
  employment.Â  Instead, we find the court was contemplating the difficulty Wife 
  might face trying to find employment because of her long absence from the job 
  market.Â  We also find no indication the parties anticipated Wifeâ€™s re-entry 
  into the workforce at the time they entered into the settlement agreement.Â  
  In fact, except for some part-time employment, the Wife remained unemployed 
  from the time of the decree until the day before the hearing.
Wife also argues the reduction in alimony would not allow her to 
  maintain the standard of living she enjoyed during the marriage.Â  We find no 
  error in the family court reducing the alimony award to $3,000 a month when 
  Wife is now also earning $1,387 a month and listed the property she owns as 
  valued at $340,623.Â  In addition, Wife asserts the reduction in alimony penalizes 
  her for gaining employment.Â  We find this assertion meritless.Â  An alimony award 
  should not serve as a disincentive for a spouse to make reasonable efforts to 
  improve her employment potential or to dissuade the spouse from providing, to 
  the extent possible, for her own support.Â  Brandi v. Brandi, 302 S.C. 
  353, 358, 396 S.E.2d 124, 127 (Ct. App. 1990).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Being mindful of our standard of review, which gives the family court judge 
  discretion in modifying alimony, we find Wifeâ€™s new employment and income is 
  a sufficient change of circumstances to warrant the modification of the alimony 
  award from $4,000 to $3,000 per month.Â  

  II.      Attorneyâ€™s FeesÂ  

Wife argues the family court erred by only awarding her a portion of her attorneyâ€™s 
  fees and costs.Â  We disagree.Â  
An award of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs is in the 
  discretion of the family court and will not be overturned absent an abuse of 
  discretion.Â  Donahue v. Donahue, 299 S.C. 353, 365, 384 S.E.2d 741, 748 
  (1989).Â  To prevail on appeal, a party must show the courtâ€™s conclusions were 
  without factual support, resulted in prejudice, and amounted to an error of 
  law.Â  Alliegro v. Alliegro, 287 S.C. 154, 157, 337 S.E.2d 252, 254 (Ct. 
  App. 1985).Â  
In determining the proper amount to award, we 
  consider: the nature, extent, and difficulty of the services rendered; the time 
  necessarily devoted to the case; the professional standing of counsel; the contingency 
  of compensation; the beneficial results obtained; and the customary legal fees 
  for similar services.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 
  S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991).Â  
We recognize Wifeâ€™s attorney spent a considerable 
  amount of time deciphering Husbandâ€™s confusing business records in defending 
  the Husbandâ€™s claim for a reduction of alimony.Â  However, Wife is capable of 
  paying her own fees.Â  Her gross monthly income, including the reduced alimony, 
  is $4,387 and she owns $340,623 in total property according to her financial 
  declaration.Â  Furthermore, as to the beneficial results obtained, although the 
  family court rejected Husbandâ€™s contention that alimony should be reduced due 
  to his decrease in income, it nevertheless granted his request for a reduction 
  based on Wifeâ€™s new employment.Â  Therefore, Husband was successful in his claim 
  for a reduction in alimony.Â  Based on the above, we find the family court did 
  not abuse its discretion in awarding Wife $2,500.00 in attorneyâ€™s fees and costs. 

CONCLUSIONÂ  
For the foregoing reasons, the decision of the 
  family court is
AFFIRMED. 
 HUFF, STILWELL, and CURETON, JJ., concur.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PREDCEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT 
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Arthur Tyrone Davis,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Marc H. Westbrook, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-251
Heard December 9, 2003 â€“ Filed April 
  15, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  Assistant Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe, all of Columbia;Â  and Solicitor 
  Cecil Kelly Jackson, of Sumter; for Respondent.
      
    
  

 PER CURIAM:Â  Arthur Tyrone Davis 
  was convicted of two counts of assault and battery of a high and aggravated 
  nature (â€œABHANâ€), one count of possession of a weapon during a violent crime, 
  and one count of conspiracy.Â  The circuit court sentenced Davis to ten years 
  imprisonment for each count of ABHAN, five years imprisonment for possession 
  of a weapon during a violent crime, and five years imprisonment for conspiracy, 
  with the sentences to run consecutively.Â  Davis appeals, arguing the circuit 
  court erred by: 1) admitting the confession he gave as a part of the plea agreement; 
  and 2) refusing to enforce his plea agreement.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On April 14, 1997, assailants forced two men into 
  the trunk of their car.Â  The victims were driven to a secluded location where 
  they were robbed, beaten, stripped, and shot. 
Subsequently, Davis was brought to the police station for 
  questioning. After arriving at the police station, Officer James Hicks advised 
  Davis of his Miranda rights.Â  Because Davis chose not to waive these 
  rights, Officer Hicks did not question Davis at that time.Â  Instead, Officer 
  Hicks assisted Davis in calling his attorney, Murrell Smith. [1]  Davis and his attorney spoke 
  privately for approximately twenty minutes. Smith then proposed a deal to Officer 
  Hicks in which Davis would agree to tell the Solicitor about every crime he 
  had been involved in, and in exchange, the Solicitor would agree to allow Davis 
  to plead guilty to all offenses delineated as non-violent and receive a ten-year 
  cap on sentencing.Â  Officer Hicks spoke with a Sumter County Assistant Solicitor 
  and obtained approval to accept the offer.Â  Davis then gave a written confession 
  in which he admitted abducting and shooting the victims.Â  Thereafter, the Solicitor 
  refused to honor the agreement after learning Davis was involved in several 
  crimes he had not disclosed pursuant to the plea agreement. 
At a pre-trial hearing, Davis moved to enforce 
  the terms of the plea agreement, denying the Solicitorâ€™s allegation that he 
  had been involved in crimes he had not disclosed pursuant to the agreement.Â  
  The Solicitor presented testimony and evidence tying Davis to the additional 
  crimes.Â  Specifically, the Solicitor examined a police officer who testified 
  that he had learned of numerous crimes Davis did not report to the Solicitor. 
  The officer also testified he had interviewed a co-defendant concerning Davisâ€™ 
  involvement in crimes not disclosed to the Solicitor and had located documents 
  verifying Davis pawned stolen goods from those crimes.Â  The circuit court found 
  Davis breached the plea agreement and denied Davisâ€™ motion to enforce it. 
At the call of the case for trial, Davis 
  moved to suppress the confession he had made to police in connection with the 
  failed plea agreement, arguing it could no longer be considered voluntary.Â  
  Davis testified in the suppression hearing that his confession was made in reliance 
  on the plea agreement and that he would not otherwise have given such a statement.Â  
  Davis argued that because the Solicitor chose not to honor the terms of the 
  plea agreement, the circuit court should find his confession was involuntarily 
  given.Â  The circuit court denied the motion to suppress Davisâ€™ confession, finding 
  it was voluntarily given.Â  
At trial, the Solicitor introduced the confession 
  over Davisâ€™ objection.Â  The jury subsequently returned a guilty verdict for 
  two counts of ABHAN, one count of possession of a weapon during a violent crime, 
  and one count of conspiracy.Â  The circuit court sentenced Davis to ten years 
  imprisonment for each count of ABHAN, five years imprisonment for possession 
  of a weapon during a violent crime, and five years imprisonment for conspiracy, 
  with the sentences to run consecutively.Â  Davis appeals.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Admission of Confession
Davis argues the circuit court erred by admitting 
  Davisâ€™ confession into evidence because the statement was not voluntarily given. 
  [2] Â  We disagree.Â  
In determining whether a confession was voluntarily 
  given by the defendant, the circuit court examines the totality of the circumstances 
  at the time the defendant gave the statement to determine if the conduct of 
  â€œlaw enforcement officials was such as to overbear [the defendantâ€™s] will to 
  resist and bring about confessions not freely self-determined.â€ Rogers v. 
  Richmond, 365 U.S. 534, 544 (1961); see State v. Peake, 291 
  S.C. 138, 139, 352 S.E.2d 487, 488 (1987) (â€œThe test for determining the admissibility 
  of a statement is whether it was knowingly, intelligently, and voluntarily given 
  under the totality of the circumstances.â€).
Initially, we note, Davis alleges because the plea 
  agreement induced him to confess, his statement became involuntary once the 
  Solicitor decided not to honor the plea agreement.Â  Because the totality of 
  the circumstances is considered to determine if the defendantâ€™s will is overborne 
  by the acts of the police at the time the confession is given, it would be inappropriate 
  to review the circumstances existing after the confession was given.Â  Thus, 
  we examine voluntariness at the time Davis gave his confession.
â€œWhen reviewing a trial courtâ€™s ruling concerning 
  voluntariness, this Court does not reevaluate the facts based on its own view 
  of the preponderance of the evidence, but simply determines whether the trial 
  courtâ€™s ruling is supported by any evidence.â€ State v. Saltz, 346 S.C. 
  114, 136, 551 S.E.2d 240, 252 (2001); see State v. Rochester, 
  301 S.C. 196, 200, 391 S.E.2d 244, 247 (1990) (holding the conclusion of the 
  circuit court on issues of fact as to the voluntariness of a confession will 
  not be disturbed on appeal unless so manifestly erroneous as to show an abuse 
  of discretion).
In the circuit courtâ€™s consideration of the totality 
  of the circumstances, the only factor that weighed against the voluntariness 
  of the confession was the fact that Davis received a promise of leniency before 
  confessing. Id., at 200, 391 S.E.2d at 246-47 (holding a promise of leniency 
  is a factor to be considered in determining whether a statement was voluntarily 
  given, but does not always necessitate a finding that the statement was involuntarily 
  given).
The remaining factors favored a finding that the 
  confession was voluntarily given.Â  Foremost in this analysis was the fact that 
  Davisâ€™ offer to confess in return for a specific sentence resulted in the promise 
  of leniency from the police officer.Â  See Drew v. State, 503 N.E.2d 
  613, 617 (Ind. 1987) (â€œ[T]he promise of . . . leniency was not initiated by 
  the State, but rather resulted in response to a specific request by the defendant, 
  who solicited the promise[ ] as a precondition for making a full statement.Â  
  Thus, the defendant had already manifested the propensity and willingness to 
  make a voluntary statement before the occurrence of any action on the part of 
  the State.â€); State v. Harwick, 552 P.2d 987, 990 (Kan. 1976) 
  (â€œWhen the promises are solicited by the accused, freely and voluntarily, the 
  accused cannot be heard to say that in accepting the promise he was the victim 
  of a compelling influence.â€). 
In addition, Davis was advised of his Miranda 
  rights and consulted privately with his attorney prior to making the offer to 
  confess. Cf. Miranda v. Arizona, 384 U.S. 436, 466 (1966) (â€œThe 
  presence of counsel . . . would insure that statements made in the government-established 
  atmosphere are not the product of compulsion.â€). Â 
Furthermore, the record does not reflect: 1) the 
  questioning was unreasonably lengthy; 2) the police officer engaged in deceit 
  or trickery; 3) the police officer made physical threats against Davis; or 4) 
  Davis was subjected to physical violence.Â  See Rochester, 301 
  S.C. at 201, 391 S.E.2d at 247 (holding lengthy questioning, trickery, threats 
  of violence, and the use of violence all weigh against finding a confession 
  was voluntarily given).
After reviewing the totality of the circumstances, 
  the circuit court determined Davisâ€™ confession was voluntarily given.Â  Because 
  the circuit courtâ€™s decision was supported by the evidence, the circuit court 
  did not err by making this determination.Â  See Saltz, 346 S.C. 
  at 136, 551 S.E.2d at 252 (â€œWhen reviewing a trial courtâ€™s ruling concerning 
  voluntariness, this Court . . . simply determines whether the trial courtâ€™s 
  ruling is supported by any evidence.â€); see also State v. Richardson, 
  342 S.E.2d 823, 831 (N.C. 1986) (â€œPromises or other statements indicating to 
  an accused that he will receive some benefit if he confesses do not render his 
  confession involuntary when made in response to a solicitation by the accused.â€); 
  People v. Wright, 469 N.E.2d 351, 354 (Ill. Ct. App. 1984) (holding defendantâ€™s 
  confession following Stateâ€™s promise not to seek death penalty deemed voluntary, 
  as defendant initiated discussion and stated he would not confess unless State 
  promised not to seek death penalty); Taylor v. Commonwealth, 461 S.W.2d 
  920, 922 (Ky. 1970) (holding â€œthe circumstances of the promise in the instant 
  case were entirely compatible with the exercise by the appellants of a free 
  volition in the giving of the confessionsâ€ because one of the defendants proposed 
  the deal to police and the other obtained the advice of counsel before agreeing 
  to the confession deal); Thomas v. State, 531 So.2d 45, 48 (Ala. Crim. 
  App. 1988) (holding a confession is not involuntarily given when the defendant 
  made the request for leniency without being coerced by the police officer). [3] Â  
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Refusal to Enforce Plea Agreement
Davis argues the circuit court erred 
  by refusing to enforce the plea agreement.Â  Specifically, Davis contends the 
  circuit court erred by failing to apply a clear and convincing burden of proof 
  in determining whether Davis breached the terms of the plea agreement.Â  Davis 
  argues the evidence presented by the Solicitor was not sufficient to meet this 
  higher burden of proof.Â  We disagree.
Plea agreements are contractual in nature, and 
  courts use traditional principles of contract law to interpret and enforce them.Â  
  See State v. Thrift, 312 S.C. 282, 292-93, 440 S.E.2d 341, 347 
  (1994) (citation omitted).Â  When the defendant breaches a plea agreement, the 
  Solicitor is released from his obligations thereunder. State v. Tillman, 
  320 S.C. 61, 63, 463 S.E.2d 94, 96 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  In determining whether 
  the defendant has breached the plea agreement, the circuit courtâ€™s â€œanalysis 
  must be more stringent than a contract [analysis] because the rights involved 
  are fundamental and constitutionally based.â€Â  Thrift, 312 S.C. at 293, 
  440 S.E.2d at 347.
Davis argues Thrift requires the 
  circuit court to use a clear and convincing evidence standard to determine whether 
  Davis breached the plea agreement by failing to disclose crimes in which he 
  was involved.Â  See Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 577 (7th ed. 1999) (stating 
  clear and convincing evidence â€œis a greater burden than preponderance of the 
  evidence, the standard applied in most civil trialsâ€).Â  
We conclude this argument is without merit.Â  Assuming, 
  without deciding, Thrift requires the circuit court to apply a clear 
  and convincing evidence standard, the circuit court did so in the present case.Â  
  After reviewing the applicable law, the terms of the plea agreement, and the 
  omissions in Davisâ€™ statement, the circuit court found, â€œ[e]ven when holding 
  the State to a higher degree of responsibility, this Court is clearly convinced 
  that the State has presented more than enough evidence to support its contention 
  that Arthur Tyrone Davis breached his plea agreement.â€ (emphasis added).Â  
Furthermore, the Solicitor presented adequate evidence 
  to support the circuit courtâ€™s conclusion.Â  The Solicitor presented a co-defendantâ€™s 
  statement and testimony from an investigating police officer outlining independent 
  corroboration of Davisâ€™ involvement in crimes not disclosed pursuant to the 
  plea agreement, as well as documents verifying Davis pawned stolen goods from 
  those crimes.Â  
Because the circuit court found clear evidence 
  convincing it that Davis was involved in crimes he failed to disclose to the 
  Solicitor, the circuit court did not err by finding Davis breached the plea 
  agreement. See State v. Amerson, 311 S.C. 316, 320, 428 S.E.2d 
  871, 873 (1993) (â€œAppellate courts are bound by fact findings in response to 
  motions preliminary to trial when the findings are supported by the evidence 
  and not clearly wrong or controlled by error of law.â€). Â Thus, the circuit court 
  did not err by denying Davisâ€™ motion to enforce the plea agreement. 
CONCLUSION
Based on the above, Davisâ€™ convictions 
  are 
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concurring.

 
   
    [1] Smith did not represent Davis at trial.

 
   
    [2] We note, Rule 410, SCRE, addresses the admissibility of statements 
    obtained in guilty plea negotiations.Â  However, Davis did not raise this statute 
    as a ground for exclusion of the confession, nor did the circuit court rule 
    upon its applicability. Therefore, we cannot address it on appeal.Â  See 
    Humbert v. State, 345 S.C. 332, 337, 548 S.E.2d 862, 865 (2001) 
    (holding to preserve an issue for appellate review, it must have been raised 
    to and ruled upon by the circuit court).Â  

 
   [3]  Davis further contends State 
    v. Mathis, 287 S.C. 589, 340 S.E.2d 538 (1986) required the circuit court 
    to exclude the confession he gave as part of the plea agreement.Â  In Mathis, 
    our supreme court stated a defendantâ€™s guilty plea cannot be introduced into 
    evidence. Id. at 592-93, 340 S.E.2d at 540-41.Â  In explaining the ruling, 
    our supreme court distinguished guilty pleas from â€œprior inconsistent statements 
    (including confessions),â€ noting confessions may be used as evidence. Id. 
    at 592, 340 S.E.2d at 540; cf. Kercheval v. U.S., 274 U.S. 220, 
    223 (1927) (â€œA plea of guilty differs in purpose and effect from a mere admission 
    or an extrajudicial confession.â€).Â  Because Davis moved to suppress his confession 
    at trial, but did not argue evidence of his plea offer was inadmissible, Mathis 
    is inapplicable to the facts of this case.Â  To the extent Davis argues evidence 
    of his plea agreement was inadmissible, this issue is not preserved for appellate 
    review.Â  See Humbert, 345 S.C. at 337, 548 S.E.2d at 865 (holding 
    to preserve an issue for appellate review, it must have been raised to and 
    ruled on by the circuit court).Â

THIS OPINION 
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT 
  IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Paul Zahn, individually and d/b/a Zahn Construction Company,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Sadie Allen and Abbeville Savings & Loan,       
Defendants,
Of Whom Sadie Allen is the       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Abbeville County
Joseph J. Watson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-261
Submitted March 8, 2004 â€“ Filed April 
  19, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Hemphill P. Pride II, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.Â  
Edward S. McCallum, III, of Greenwood, and James B. Richardson, 
  Jr., of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this action to foreclose 
  a mechanicâ€™s lien, the trial court awarded homebuilder Paul Zahn a $43,848.73 
  judgment against homeowner Sadie Allen.Â  Allen appeals, arguing the trial court 
  erred in:Â  (1) finding the mechanicâ€™s lien was timely filed; (2) ruling she 
  was liable under the contract; and (3) awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to Zahn.Â  We 
  affirm. [1] 
BACKGROUND
The parties contracted for Zahn to build 
  Allen a house.Â  The house was based on a design the parties modified to accommodate 
  Allenâ€™s needs including handicapped features for her mother.Â  It is undisputed 
  Zahn made mistakes in constructing the home.Â  He also failed to deliver it in 
  a timely fashion.Â  After Zahn informed Allen the home was complete and demanded 
  payment, Allen refused to pay the remainder due under the contract until the 
  home could be independently inspected.Â  In response to a complaint filed by 
  Allen, an inspector with the South Carolina Department of Labor, Licensing, 
  and Regulation inspected the home, finding a number of construction deficiencies.Â  
  Zahn repaired the items noted in the report and approximately a month later 
  filed a mechanicâ€™s lien and this action.Â  Allen answered, asserting several 
  affirmative defenses and a breach of contract counterclaim.Â  Zahn completed 
  additional repairs after the filing of pleadings.Â  However, problems continued 
  with the home.Â  
Following a bench trial, the trial court issued an 
  order finding Zahn timely filed the mechanicâ€™s lien and awarding him $43,848.73.Â  
  This amount reflected two setoffs to Allen, one for the interest she lost during 
  the time between scheduled delivery and actual completion and another for repair 
  costs to correct an error in the foyerâ€™s construction.Â  The court also held 
  Zahn was entitled to legal fees and costs it later determined to be $14,610.08.Â  

DISCUSSION
 I.     Filing of the Mechanicâ€™s Lien 
   
Allen argues the trial 
  court erred in concluding Zahn timely filed his mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  We disagree.
â€œAn action to foreclose a mechanicâ€™s lien is a 
  law case in South Carolina.â€Â  Keeneyâ€™s Metal Roofing, Inc. v. Palmieri, 
  345 S.C. 550, 553, 548 S.E.2d 900, 901 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  In an action at law 
  tried without a jury, the appellate courtâ€™s standard of review extends only 
  to the correction of errors of law.Â  Barnacle Broad. v. Baker Broad., 
  343 S.C. 140, 146, 538 S.E.2d 672, 675 (Ct. App. 2000), cert. dismissed, 
  348 S.C. 11, 558 S.E.2d 516 (2002).Â  Therefore, the trial courtâ€™s factual 
  findings will not be disturbed on appeal unless the record discloses there is 
  no evidence reasonably supporting the courtâ€™s findings.Â  Id.
Mechanicsâ€™ liens 
  [2]  serve to secure payment for a â€œperson to whom a debt is due for labor 
  performed or furnished or for materials furnished and actually used in the erection 
  . . . of a building or structure . . . by virtue of an agreement with, or by 
  consent of, the owner of the building or structure.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10(a) 
  (Supp. 2003). 
For a person to be entitled to enforce 
  a mechanicâ€™s lien, he must file within ninety days of furnishing labor or materials 
  for the building or structure.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-90 (providing a mechanicâ€™s 
  lien â€œshall be dissolvedâ€ unless the person holding the lien serves and files 
  the lien within ninety days of providing labor or materials); see also 
  Preferred Sav. & Loan Assâ€™n, Inc. v. Royal Garden Resort, Inc., 301 
  S.C. 1, 4, 389 S.E.2d 853, 854 (1990) (stating when a person files a mechanicâ€™s 
  lien, he is essentially asserting work has been performed in the ninety days 
  prior to filing for which he is entitled to a lien).Â  
The court found for Zahnâ€™s lien to be timely, he 
  must have performed work sometime between March 28 and June 26, 2000, the date 
  he filed the lien.Â  Zahn sent Allen a letter on May 31, 2000 stating the problems 
  outlined in LLRâ€™s April 6 report had been remedied.Â  Based on this letter and 
  the testimony adduced at trial, the court found Zahn performed work within the 
  ninety-day period.Â  Thus the trial court properly found Zahn timely filed his 
  lien.
Allen also argues S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-250 (1991) 
  precludes Zahn from asserting a mechanicâ€™s lien under the facts of this case.Â  
  However, because Allen raises this issue for the first time on appeal, it is 
  not preserved.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 
  S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (finding an issue must be raised to and ruled on by the 
  trial court to be preserved for appeal).
II.Â    
Enforceability of Mechanicâ€™s Lien
Allen also contends the trial court erred in finding 
  an enforceable mechanicâ€™s lien because it should have found Allen was not liable 
  under the contract.Â  The contract provides for final payment to be made â€œat 
  the time of completion.â€Â  Allen asserts because numerous problems arose during 
  construction, the house was never completed, and thus, the final payment never 
  became due.Â  We disagree.Â  
Allen points to several deficiencies as evidence 
  the house was not completed, including problems with the garage, the foundation, 
  the foyer, and the roof trusses.Â  She also contends Zahn failed to deliver the 
  house for inspection.Â  Zahn repaired some of these items and the trial court 
  granted Allen setoffs (1) for the interest she paid to the bank and lost in 
  investment income caused by the delay in delivery and (2) to bring the foyer 
  into compliance with the building plans.Â  However, the court further noted â€œ[a]ny 
  other setoffs alleged by [Allen] that are not mentioned in this order are denied 
  because they lacked evidence in the record to support them or no damages were 
  proven by Allen.â€Â  Allen does not challenge the sufficiency of the setoffs, 
  either by the items they covered or the amounts credited to her.Â  
Additionally, Zahnâ€™s action was based on a mechanicâ€™s 
  lien, not the partiesâ€™ contract.Â  A mechanicâ€™s lien secures payment to the provider 
  of materials and labor who provides them either by agreement with or consent 
  of the recipient, regardless of the existence of a formal contract.Â  See 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10(a) (providing a person due a debt for labor or materials 
  furnished in the building, alteration, or repair of a structure on real estate 
  shall have a lien against the structure and the ownerâ€™s interest in the land 
  on which it is situated).Â  Thus whether Zahn can enforce a mechanicâ€™s lien against 
  Allen is based on the materials and labor he provided in the homeâ€™s construction, 
  not whether he could demand full payment of the contract amount.Â  
Although the court found Zahn breached his agreement 
  with Allen, it also found Zahn was entitled to $57,340 for labor and materials 
  minus the amount of Allenâ€™s setoffs.Â  In addition to the major construction 
  efforts, the record demonstrates Zahn repaired all items brought to his attention 
  by LLR, additional items asserted by Allenâ€™s engineer, and that he even made 
  repairs during the pendency of litigation.Â  Because the evidence supports the 
  courtâ€™s ruling, it properly held the mechanicâ€™s lien was enforceable against 
  Allen.Â  
III.Â    
Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Allen also argues the trial court erred in granting 
  attorneyâ€™s fees to Zahn.Â  We disagree. 
South Carolina Code section 29-5-10(a) clearly 
  provides â€œ[t]he costs which may arise in enforcing or defending against the 
  lien under this chapter, including a reasonable attorneyâ€™s fee, may be recovered 
  by the prevailing party.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10(a).Â  This section further 
  provides the amount of the fee recovered is to be decided by the court, but 
  in no event should the fee and costs exceed the amount of the lien.Â  Id.
Subsection (b) provides instructions to determine 
  who is the prevailing party for the purposes of awarding attorneyâ€™s fees and 
  litigation expenses.Â  The party whose settlement offer is closer to the ultimate 
  verdict is the prevailing party.Â  In the event neither party makes a settlement 
  offer, the amount prayed for in the complaint is considered the plaintiffâ€™s 
  offer and the value of defendantâ€™s counterclaim is the negative value of his 
  settlement offer.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10(b).Â  
As neither party made a settlement offer under 
  section 29-5-10(b), Zahnâ€™s offer is considered the amount he prayed for in his 
  complaint, or $58,355, whereas Allenâ€™s is considered to be the value of her 
  counterclaim, or negative $5,000.Â  Because Zahnâ€™s settlement offer is closer 
  to the ultimate verdict of $43,848.73 than negative $5,000, Zahn is clearly 
  the prevailing party and therefore entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  See 
  Brasington Tile Co., Inc. v. Worley, 327 S.C. 280, 288, 491 S.E.2d 
  244, 248 (1997) (holding that in determining the prevailing party in a mechanicâ€™s 
  lien case, the ultimate verdict should include setoffs).Â  
However, Allen argues the court erred in considering 
  the contingency fee agreement between Zahn and his attorney because the agreement 
  did not differentiate between the amount of time spent on assertion of the lien 
  claim and the time spent defending against Allenâ€™s counterclaims.Â  Allen relies 
  on Utilities Constr. Co., Inc. v. Wilson, 321 S.C. 244, 468 S.E.2d 1 
  (Ct. App. 1996), to support the argument that the time spent by Zahnâ€™s counsel 
  on these items should be separate.Â  We find this reliance misplaced.Â  
In Utilities Constr., a utility company brought three 
  causes of action against Wilsonâ€”a mechanicâ€™s lien foreclosure claim, unjust 
  enrichment, and breach of contract.Â  The court directed a verdict against the 
  utility company on the mechanicâ€™s lien claim, and the remaining causes of action 
  were submitted to the jury. Â The jury subsequently returned a verdict for the 
  utility company.Â  Id. at 246, 468 S.E.2d at 2.Â  
Having prevailed on the mechanicâ€™s lien claim, the court 
  awarded Wilson attorneyâ€™s fees pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10(a).Â  Id.Â  
  The utility company appealed this award arguing it should have received the 
  award because it was the prevailing party on the verdict.Â  The court disagreed, 
  holding â€œit is the enforcement of the lien which confers the right to attorneyâ€™s 
  fees, and not the joinder of an attempted enforcement with another non-statutory 
  cause of action on which the lienor prevails.â€Â  Id. at 247-248, 468 S.E.2d 
  at 2.Â  Accordingly, the case stands for the proposition that when a plaintiff 
  brings a mechanicâ€™s lien action along with other causes of action, if the plaintiff 
  does not prevail on the mechanicâ€™s lien claim, he or she is not entitled to 
  attorneyâ€™s fees under the statute.Â  As the case does not stand for the proposition 
  for which Allen cites it, we find her argument without merit.
Allen also argues the trial court erred by considering the 
  contingency fee agreement in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees because it does not comport 
  with Rule 407, SCACR.Â  We disagree.Â  The reasonableness of a statutorily mandated 
  attorneyâ€™s fee award is not controlled by a contract between lawyer and client.Â  
  See, e.g., Jackson v. Speed, 326 S.C. 289, 308, 486 S.E.2d 750, 
  759 (1997); see also Blumberg v. Nealco, Inc., 310 S.C. 492, 494, 
  427 S.E.2d 659, 660 (1993) (noting six factors to be considered when considering 
  reasonableness of an award for attorneyâ€™s fees).
 AFFIRMED.
HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., and
CURETON, A.J., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 
    215, SCACR.

 
   
    [2]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Mechanicsâ€™ liens are creatures of statute in South Carolina.Â  
    See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 29-5-10 â€“ 440 (1991 & Supp. 2003).

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Edward N. Dawson,       
Appellant.

A. Victor Rawl, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-267
Submitted February 20, 2004 â€“ Filed April 19, 2004 


AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Tara S. Taggart, of the South 
  Carolina Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Attorney General David Spencer, all of Columbia; 
  and Solicitor Ralph E. Hoisington, of Charleston; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Edward N. Dawson seeks a remand 
  for re-sentencing on the charge of possession of a stolen motor vehicle, claiming 
  for the first time on appeal that he was â€œentitled to be sentenced in open court 
  rather than simply in writingâ€ for that offense.Â  We affirm. [1] 
A jury convicted Dawson of second-degree burglary 
  and possession of a stolen vehicle.Â  On October 23, 2002, the day after the 
  trial ended and while Dawson was present in the courtroom with his counsel during 
  a sentencing proceeding for both convictions, the trial judge concluded:Â  â€œSentence 
  of the Court is life without parole, based on 17-25-45.â€ 
  [2] Â  Neither the solicitor nor defense counsel brought to the attention 
  of the trial judge any concerns regarding a sentence for the vehicle offense.Â  

Two days later, the trial judge signed the sentencing 
  orders in the case.Â  The orders formally declared to Dawson the legal consequences 
  of his convictions and committed him to the State Department of Corrections 
  for concurrent terms of life imprisonment for the burglary offense and five 
  years for the vehicle offense.Â  See 21A Am. Jur. 2d Criminal Law 
  Â§791, at 54-55 (1998) (â€œIn a legal sense, sentence is ordinarily synonymous 
  with judgment and denotes the judgment of the court which formally declares 
  to the accused the legal consequences of his or her conviction . . . .â€); see 
  also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-21-80(2) (2003) (authorizing a sentence of up to 
  five years for possession of a stolen vehicle worth more than $1,000 but less 
  than $5,000).Â  Both the solicitor and defense counsel also signed the sentencing 
  order.Â  Defense counsel, however, filed no post-trial motions regarding the 
  vehicle offense and Dawsonâ€™s sentence therefor.Â  See SCRCrimP, Rule 29(a) 
  (â€œ[P]ost trial motions shall be made within ten (10) days after the imposition 
  of the sentence.â€).
We recognize that a defendant has the right to 
  be present at the time of sentencing.Â  21 Am. Jur. 2d Criminal Law Â§ 
  798, at 62 (1998).Â  In this case, Dawson was present at his sentencing proceeding, 
  a rather lengthy one, and he fully participated in that proceeding, even addressing 
  the trial judge when given the opportunity to do so.Â  Dawsonâ€™s sole contention 
  on appeal is that he was â€œentitled to be sentenced in open court rather than 
  simply in writing.â€Â  
Because Dawson failed at the sentencing hearing 
  to raise the issue of the trial judgeâ€™s omitting to announce his sentence for 
  the vehicular offense and because he also failed to assert any alleged error 
  in his sentencing within ten days after the trial judge imposed the sentence, 
  the issue has not been preserved for our review.Â  See State v. Gaster, 
  349 S.C. 545, 564 S.E.2d 87 (2002) (holding even constitutional issues must 
  be raised to and ruled on by the trial court to be preserved for review); State 
  v. Johnston, 333 S.C. 459, 510 S.E.2d 423 (1999) (noting subject matter 
  jurisdiction is generally conferred by a proper indictment and holding that 
  an objection to the sentence imposed, including even the argument that the sentence 
  exceeded the statutory maximum, did not involve subject matter jurisdiction 
  and must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved 
  for direct appeal); State v. Shumate, 276 S.C. 46, 275 S.E.2d 288 (1981) 
  (holding a defendantâ€™s failure to timely object to or seek modification of his 
  sentence from the trial judge precludes the defendant from presenting an objection 
  for the first time on appeal); cf. State v. Williams, 292 S.C. 
  231, 355 S.E.2d 861 (1987) (stating a defendantâ€™s objection to being tried in 
  his absence must be raised at the first opportunity). 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, AND KITTREDGE, JJ., CONCUR. 


 
   [1] Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
    [2] Â  See S.C. Code 
    Ann. Â§ 17-25-45 (2003) (imposing a sentence of life in prison without parole 
    for recidivists convicted of certain enumerated offenses).

THIS OPINION 
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT 
  IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Charles Ellis Cutshaw,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Joyce Sinclair Cutshaw,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Chester County
Brooks P. Goldsmith, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-269
Submitted March 8, 2004 â€“ Filed April 
  19, 2004

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
Coreen B. Khoury, of Lancaster, for Appellant.
Thomas F. McDow, of Rock Hill, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:  Joyce Sinclair Cutshaw (Wife) appeals the
provision of the family court order placing the valuation on the real property
allotted to Charles Ellis Cutshaw (Husband), and the apportionment of unsecured
martial debt.  We affirm.[1] 


FACTS
The family
court granted Husband and Wife a divorce and issued an order apportioning the
marital property and debt.  All
assets and debt were divided equally except for two parcels of property: 
(1) a house and seventeen acres located in Farmwood Estates and (2) a
house and twelve acres located on Trussel Road. 
Husband and Wife each had independent experts appraise the properties for
the purpose of equitable distribution.  Husbandâ€™s
appraiser valued Farmwood at $118,000, while Wifeâ€™s appraiser valued it at
$154,000.  Husbandâ€™s appraiser
submitted a value of $84,000 on Trussel Road, compared with a valuation of
$98,000 offered by Wifeâ€™s appraiser.  The
family court awarded Farmwood to Husband with a 45 percent equity interest
retained by Wife, and awarded Trussel Road to Wife with a 45 percent equity
interest retained by Husband.  For
both parcels, the court accepted the appraised values placed on them by the
appraiser for the party to whom the property was awarded; that is, the court
used Husbandâ€™s appraisal for Farmwood and Wifeâ€™s appraisal for Trussel Road.
 


Wife appeals the valuation assigned to Husbandâ€™s property at Farmwood
and also the distribution of unsecured marital debt, contending it to be
inequitable. 
DISCUSSION
  In appeals from the family court, this court may find facts in accordance 
  with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Miles v. Miles, 
  355 S.C. 511, 516, 586 S.E.2d 136, 139 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  However, this broad 
  scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s determinations.Â  
  Id.Â  Nor do we ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard 
  the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign 
  comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Id.Â   
 
I.Â  Valuation of 
  Farmwood
Wife claims the family court erred in adopting Husbandâ€™s valuation 
  of Farmwood, arguing the appraisal was too low in light of all the evidence.Â  
  We disagree. 
In valuing marital property, the family court may give such weight to expert 
  testimony as it deems appropriate.Â  Smith v. Smith, 294 S.C. 194, 200, 
  363 S.E.2d 404, 408 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  Therefore, the court may accept one partyâ€™s 
  valuation of marital property over anotherâ€™s.Â  Id. at 200-201, 363 S.E.2d 
  at 4078.Â  
  The family courtâ€™s valuation will not be disturbed if it is within the range 
  of evidence.Â  Woodward v. Woodward, 294 S.C. 210, 215, 363 S.E.2d 413, 
  416 (Ct. App. 1987).
Husbandâ€™s appraiser testified Farmwood had a value of $118,000 at 
  the time of trial.Â  Although Wifeâ€™s expert valued the property at $154,000, 
  we note the same expert valued the property at $120,000 less than two years 
  earlier when the parties refinanced the property.Â  We therefore conclude the 
  valuation assigned to Farmwood was within the range of values supported by the 
  evidence.Â  Accordingly, the family court did not err by adopting Husbandâ€™s appraisal.
II.Â  Allocation of Unsecured Marital Debt
Wife argues the family court erred by allocating 50 percent of the 
  unsecured marital debt to her.Â  She contends the court abused its discretion 
  by requiring her to pay an equal share of the debt while only giving her a 45 
  percent interest in Farmwood.Â  We disagree.
When apportioning marital debt, the family court must consider the 
  factors set out in S.C. Code section 20-7-472 (Supp. 2003).Â  The statute vests the family 
  court with discretion to decide what weight should be assigned to the various 
  factors of equitable apportionment.Â  On review, we look to the fairness of the 
  overall apportionment; if the end result is equitable, it is irrelevant that 
  we might have weighed specific factors differently than the family court.Â  Jenkins 
  v. Jenkins, 345 S.C. 88, 100, 545 S.E.2d 531, 537 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
Wife argues because a portion of the marital debt was incurred to 
  pay for improvements to Farmwood as well as Husbandâ€™s medical bills, the family 
  court should have made Husband pay a greater share of the debt.Â  The debt was 
  not limited to expenses for Husband alone.Â  Moreover, Wife received an equal 
  share of the personal property accumulated during the marriage, despite the 
  fact she earned only 35 percent of the household income.Â  As such, when considering 
  the overall distribution, we find no abuse of discretion in the equitable distribution 
  of marital debt.
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., and
CURETON, A.J., concur.

 
    [1]
   
    Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215,
  SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Alan D. Anderson, Robert and Diane
Ressler, 
        William Todt, Thomas A. Brooks, Juliana S. Calhoun, Robin and Keith Lee, 
        Donald J. and Michele B. Hatcher, Philip D. and Jean F. Landfried,       
Appellants/Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Hank and Linda Buonforte,       
Respondents/Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
W. C. Coffey, Jr., Special Referee

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-270
Heard January 13, 2004 â€“ Filed April 
  19, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John S. Keffer, of Sumter, for Appellants-Respondents.
Kristi F. Curtis, of Sumter, for Respondents-Appellants.
      
    
  


 PER CURIAM: Alan D. Anderson, 
  Robert Ressler, Diane Ressler, William Todt, Thomas A. Brooks, Juliana S. Calhoun, 
  Robin Lee, Keith Lee, Donald J. Hatcher, Michele B. Hatcher, Philip D. Lanfried, 
  and Jean F. Landfried (collectively â€œthe Neighborsâ€), sued Hank and Linda Buonforte 
  (collectively â€œthe Buonfortesâ€), seeking to enforce the restrictive covenants 
  of the Indian Hills Subdivision in Sumter, South Carolina.Â  The special referee 
  ordered the Buonfortes to remove a two-car garage from their property and modify 
  a recently built extension to their home.Â Â  Both parties appeal.Â  We affirm. 

FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The Buonfortes began construction 
  of a house in the Indian Hills Subdivision in Sumter, South Carolina.Â Â  Hank 
  Buonforte convinced his parents to move into his home, promising to build an 
  extension to the main house (â€œthe mother-in-law wingâ€). Thereafter, he approached 
  the City Planning Directorâ€™s Office for a variance to his permit and applied 
  to the Sumter City-County Board of Appeals (â€œthe Boardâ€) for a variance to the 
  cityâ€™s setback requirements to build a garage. However, at the Buonfortesâ€™ hearing 
  before the Board, several neighbors appeared in opposition to the request. 
The Buonfortes applied 
  for a variance with the subdivisionâ€™s designated representative for enforcement 
  of the restrictive covenants.Â  However, eighteen days later, before the Buonfortes 
  received a response from the representative, the Neighbors sued the Buonfortes, 
  alleging the Buonfortesâ€™ mother-in-law wing and garage violated the communityâ€™s 
  restrictive covenants because:Â  1) the main structure was no longer a single-family 
  dwelling; and 2) the house no longer complied with the setback lines.Â  Additionally, 
  the Neighbors sought a temporary restraining order prohibiting any further construction 
  on the lot. 
After a full hearing on the merits, 
  the special referee ruled the home was a single-family dwelling within the meaning 
  of the term in the restrictive covenants.Â  Furthermore, the special referee 
  determined the house violated â€œthe general scheme of developmentâ€ and ordered 
  the garage removed and the â€œmother-in-law wingâ€ altered to better conform to 
  surrounding houses.Â  The special referee also ordered the Buonfortes to pay 
  all court costs and special referee fees.Â  Both parties appeal.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  An action to enforce 
  a restrictive covenant is in equity.Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Natural Res. 
  v. Town of McClellanville, 345 S.C. 617, 622, 550 S.E.2d 299, 302 (2001).Â  
  As such, this court may view the facts in accordance with our preponderance 
  of the evidence.Â  However, we should not disregard the findings of the special 
  referee, who was in a better position to weigh the credibility of witnesses.Â  
  Tiger, Inc. v. Fisher Agro, Inc., 301 S.C. 229, 237, 391 S.E.2d 538, 
  543 (1990).
LAW / ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  The Neighborsâ€™ 
  Appeal
A.Â Â Â Â Â  â€œSingle-Family Dwellingâ€
Initially, the Neighbors argue 
  the special referee erred by failing to rule on whether the Buonfortesâ€™ house 
  was a single-family dwelling or a duplex.Â  We disagree.
An appellate court must 
  view the trial courtâ€™s statements as a whole to determine its reasoning.Â  State 
  v. Evans, 354 S.C. 579, 584, 582 S.E.2d 407, 410 (2003).Â  Furthermore, â€œ[a]n 
  order should be construed within the context of the proceeding in which it is 
  rendered.â€Â  Dibble v. Sumter Ice & Fuel Co., 283 S.C. 278, 282, 322 
  S.E.2d 674, 677 (Ct. App. 1984); see also Eddins v. Eddins, 304 
  S.C. 133, 135, 403 S.E.2d 164, 166 (Ct. App. 1991) (holding judgments are to 
  be construed as other instruments, and the determinative factor is the intention 
  of the court, considering the judgment in its entirety).Â  
The special refereeâ€™s 
  order specifically found the Buonfortesâ€™ house, â€œconstitutes a single family 
  unit as defined by the restrictive covenants.â€ Thus, the Neighborsâ€™ claim is 
  without merit.
Next, the Neighbors assert the 
  contrary argument that the special referee erred by ruling on whether the Buonfortesâ€™ 
  structure constituted a single-family dwelling or a duplex. They contend this 
  issue was neither raised by the pleadings nor argued at trial.Â  We disagree. 

â€œA judgment must conform to the pleadings and be 
  in accordance with the theory of action upon which the case was tried.â€Â  Chandler 
  v. Merrel, 291 S.C. 227, 228, 353 S.E.2d 135, 136 (1987).Â Â  However, â€œ[w]hen 
  issues not raised by the pleadings are tried by express or implied consent of 
  the parties, they shall be treated in all respects as if they had been raised 
  in the pleadings.â€Â  Rule 15(b), SCRCP.  
In pertinent part, the 
  Neighborsâ€™ complaint alleges, â€œthe . . . [Buonfortesâ€™] construction . . . violate[s] 
  the restrictive covenants in the following particulars:Â  . . . The . . . [Buonfortes] 
  are developing and/ or constructing a residence and attached apartment/duplex 
  which is in clear violation of the limit to a single family residence . . . 
  .â€Â  Furthermore, during the trial, both the Neighbors and the Buonfortes presented 
  extensive testimony about whether the structure was a single-family dwelling 
  or a duplex.Â  Neither party objected to the admission of the testimony.Â  Thus, 
  this issue was both raised in the pleadings and tried by consent during the 
  trial.Â  Consequently, this issue is without merit.
Next, the Neighbors argue the 
  special referee erred by considering the testimony of two of the Buonfortesâ€™ 
  witnesses.Â  Specifically, the Neighbors claim the testimony was irrelevant.Â  
  We disagree.
â€œAny evidence that assists in 
  getting at the truth of the issue is relevant and admissible, unless because 
  of some legal rule it is incompetent.â€Â  Toole v. Salter, 249 S.C. 354, 
  361, 154 S.E.2d 434, 437 (1967).Â  Furthermore, 

[i]n determining a dispute concerning 
  the relevancy of . . . evidence, the question to be resolved is as to whether 
  there is a logical or rational connection between the fact which is sought to 
  be presented and a matter of fact which has been made an issue in the case. 
  Relevancy is that quality of evidence which renders it properly applicable in 
  determining the truth and falsity of matters in issue between the parties to 
  a suit. All that is required to render evidence admissible is that the fact 
  shown thereby legally tends to prove, or make more or less probable, some matter 
  in issue, and bear directly or indirectly thereon. 

Id.Â  (internal citations 
  omitted).Â  Â Â Â Â Â  
When a term is not defined within 
  a contract, evidence of its usual and customary meaning is competent to aid 
  in determining its meaning.Â  S.C. Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co. v. Oates, 
  356 S.C. 378, 382-83, 588 S.E.2d 643, 645 (Ct. App. 2003).
The restrictive covenant states 
  only single-family dwellings are permitted on the Buonfortesâ€™ property.Â  Furthermore, 
  the covenant expressly prohibits the construction of duplexes.Â  However, neither 
  â€œsingle-family dwellingâ€ nor â€œduplexâ€ is defined within the restrictive covenants.Â  

Thus, attempting to demonstrate 
  the house was a single-family dwelling, the Buonfortesâ€™ presented the testimony 
  of William Henry Hoge, the Planning Director for the Sumter Planning Commission, 
  and John Humphries, the Building Official for the City of Sumter, who testified 
  that pursuant to the applicable Sumter zoning ordinances, the Buonfortesâ€™ house 
  was a single-family dwelling.Â Â  The Neighbors objected, arguing only the testimony 
  of Robert Ross Dinkins, the person responsible for enforcing the restrictive 
  covenants, was relevant on the issue.Â  
We conclude the admitted testimony 
  was relevant to determine the meaning of the term â€œsingle-family dwellingâ€ within 
  the restrictive covenants, as the zoning ordinances were evidence of its usual 
  and customary meaning.Â  Thus, the special referee did not err by admitting the 
  testimony.
Lastly, the Neighbors 
  argue the special referee abused his discretion by ruling the Buonfortesâ€™ structure 
  was a single-family dwelling.Â  We disagree.
Dinkins testified he 
  was responsible for enforcing the restrictive covenants, and, in his opinion, 
  the structure was a duplex.Â  The Neighbors also admitted the testimony of Charles 
  R. McCreight, an architect, who opined the structure was a duplex.Â  
In response, the Buonfortes 
  presented the testimony of Hoge and Humphries.Â  Hoge testified it is his duty 
  to enforce the zoning ordinances of the City of Sumter.Â  Additionally, he testified 
  the Indians Hills Subdivision is within the City of Sumter, zoned in an area 
  where duplexes were prohibited.Â  In his opinion, the structure constituted a 
  single-family residence under the applicable Sumter zoning ordinances.Â  Humphries, 
  who is responsible for enforcing the City of Sumter building regulations, testified 
  the structure was a single-family dwelling and did not meet the definition of 
  a duplex within the building code definition.Â  
Viewing the entirety of the record, 
  we agree with the special referee that the weight of the evidence indicates 
  the Buonfortesâ€™ structure was a single-family dwelling for purposes of the restrictive 
  covenants.Â  
B.Â Â Â Â Â  Notice of Restrictive Covenants
The Neighbors 
  argue the special referee erred by finding the Buonfortes were not on notice 
  of the restrictive covenants. The Neighbors misunderstand the special refereeâ€™s 
  ruling.
An appellate court must 
  view the trial courtâ€™s statements as a whole to determine its reasoning.Â  Evans, 
  354 S.C. at 584, 582 S.E.2d at 410.Â  Furthermore, â€œ[a]n order should be construed 
  within the context of the proceeding in which it is rendered.â€Â  Dibble, 
  283 S.C. at 282, 322 S.E.2d at 677; see also Eddins, 304 S.C. 
  at 135, 403 S.E.2d at 166 (holding judgments are to be construed as other instruments, 
  and the determinative factor is the intention of the court, considering the 
  judgment in its entirety).Â  
Constructive notice and actual notice 
  are not one in the same.Â  Strother v. Lexington County Recreation Commâ€™n, 
  332 S.C. 54, 64, 504 S.E.2d 117, 122 (1998).Â  Rather, a person has actual notice 
  â€œwhere the person . . . either knows of the existence of the particular facts 
  in question or is conscious of having the means of knowing it, even though such 
  means may not be employed by him.â€Â Â  Id. at 64 n. 6, 504 S.E.2d at 122 
  n. 6.Â  In contrast, â€œconstructive notice is a legal inference which substitutes 
  for actual notice. It is notice imputed to a person whose knowledge of facts 
  is sufficient to put him on inquiry; if these facts were pursued with due diligence, 
  they would lead to other undisclosed facts.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œA homeowner is charged 
  with constructive notice of any restriction properly recorded within the chain 
  of title.â€Â  Harbison Comm. Assâ€™n, Inc., v. Mueller, 319 S.C. 99, 103, 
  459 S.E.2d 860, 863 (Ct. App. 1995).
The Buonfortes bought 
  a piece of property in the Indian Hills Subdivision with restrictive covenants 
  in the chain of title.Â  The Buonfortes denied actual notice of the restrictive 
  covenants.Â  The Neighbors did not present any evidence within the record indicating 
  the Buonfortes were on actual notice of the restrictive covenants.
In the findings of fact, the 
  special refereeâ€™s final order states that the Buonfortesâ€™ deed did not put the 
  Buonfortes on â€œadequateâ€ notice of the restrictive covenants.Â  Subsequently, 
  as a conclusion of law, the special referee held the Buonfortes were unaware 
  of the restrictive covenants when they began building the garage and mother-in-law 
  wing.Â  
We conclude a reasonable 
  reading of the special refereeâ€™s order, in light of the proceedings in which 
  it was rendered, indicates the special referee found the Buonfortes were not 
  on actual notice, as opposed to constructive notice, of the restrictive covenants.Â  
  Furthermore, this finding is supported by the weight of the evidence within 
  the record.Â  Thus, we hold the special referee did not err. 
C.Â Â Â Â Â  Balancing of the Equities
The Neighbors argue 
  the special referee erred by balancing the equities in an arbitrary and unfair 
  manner.Â  Specifically, the Neighbors contend the Buonfortes came to the hearing 
  with â€œunclean hands,â€ and thus, both the mother-in-law wing and the garage should 
  be removed.Â  We disagree.
When this court is sitting 
  in equity, and thus viewing evidence for our own preponderance, we are to consider 
  the equities of both sides, balancing the two to determine what, if any, relief 
  to give.Â  See Foreman v. Foreman, 280 S.C. 461, 464-65, 313 S.E.2d 
  312, 314 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  However, if a party has unclean hands, the party 
  is precluded from recovering in equity.Â  A party will have unclean hands, where 
  the party behaves â€œunfairly in a matter that is the subject of the litigation 
  to the prejudice of the defendant.â€Â Â  Ingram v. Kaseyâ€™s Assocs., 340 
  S.C. 98, 107, 531 S.E.2d 287, 292 (2000). 
The Neighbors sued the Buonfortes, 
  seeking to enforce the restrictive covenants of the Indian Hills Subdivision.Â  
  Specifically, the Neighbors argued the additions to the Buonfortesâ€™ house created 
  a duplex, the mother-in-wing and garage violated the setback lines, and the 
  mother-in-law wing and garage did not conform with the aesthetics of the neighborhood.Â  

While the litigation was pending, 
  the parties signed a consent order providing the following:

ORDERED, that the . . . [Buonfortes] 
  immediately cease any further construction regarding the â€œmother-in-law wingâ€ 
  on the property . . . . The . . . [Buonfortes] will be permitted to install 
  the front window units of said wing along with the door, and can also complete 
  the sides and rear of said wing, however, the . . . [Buonfortes] may not continue 
  to build or improve the front of the structure.Â  Further, the . . . [Buonfortes] 
  may not destruct or improve the wall separating the â€œmother-in-lawâ€ wing from 
  the main structure . . . . ORDERED, that the . . . [Buonfortes] be allowed to 
  complete the main structure of said building . . . Further, the . . . [Buonfortes] 
  will be allowed to complete the interior of the balance of the structure . . 
  . and the exterior of the entire structure . . . ORDERED, that if the . . 
  . [Buonfortes] do continue to build or improve said property beyond the parameters 
  of this Order, that the . . . [Buonfortes] do so at their own risk[.]

(emphasis added).Â  
Subsequently, the Buonfortes 
  completed construction of the garage and interior of the mother-in-law wing.Â  
  Following a final hearing, the special referee ruled the Buonfortes must remove 
  the garage.Â  Furthermore, the special referee ruled the Buonfortes must remove 
  the front door entrance of the mother-in-law wing, such that the house now only 
  has one front entrance.Â  Moreover, the special referee ordered the Buonfortes 
  to remove the gabled entrance roof.Â  
The Neighbors now contend 
  the special referee erred by balancing the equities to allow the mother-in-law 
  wing to remain because the Buonfortes are seeking equity with unclean hands.Â  
  Specifically, the Neighbors allege the following particulars weigh against the 
  Buonfortes:Â  1) the Buonfortes misrepresented information on their original 
  building permit because they did not request a permit for the additions to the 
  house, although they knew they planned to construct additions; 2) the Buonfortes 
  had constructive knowledge of the restrictive covenants before they began to 
  build the additions to their house; and 3) the Buonfortes continued to build 
  after they had actual knowledge of the restrictive covenants.
 We do not view the evidence 
  in the same light as the Neighbors.Â  Rather, our view of the evidence indicates 
  the Buonfortes applied for a building permit to construct their original residence.Â  
  Although the Buonfortes may have intended to construct additions to their residence 
  when they applied for the original building permit, they did not intend to do 
  so without acquiring an additional permit.Â  In fact, prior to construction of 
  the additional structures, the Buonfortes applied for permits to build the additional 
  structures, leading to this lawsuit.
The evidence also indicates 
  the Buonfortes were not on actual notice of the restrictive covenants, as no 
  evidence exists within the record indicating they actually knew the restrictive 
  covenants existed.Â  Rather, the evidence indicates that prior to buying the 
  piece of property, the Buonfortes hired an attorney to conduct a title search.Â  
  The attorneyâ€™s report does not indicate the existence of restrictive covenants.Â  
  Thus, although the Buonfortes were on constructive notice of the restrictive 
  covenants, they were not on actual notice, mitigating any allegation of unclean 
  hands.
Pursuant to the above 
  quoted agreement, the Buonfortes continued to build the additions to their home 
  after commencement of this lawsuit.Â  With the exception of the garage, which 
  the special referee ordered the Buonfortes to remove, the continued building 
  was permitted under the agreement.Â  
We conclude the Buonfortes 
  did not have unclean hands such that they are precluded from the aide of equity, 
  as they have not acted unfairly to the prejudice of the Neighbors.Â  Moreover, 
  we conclude the special referee appropriately weighed the equities of the situation.Â  
  Thus, we hold the special referee did not err. 
II.Â Â Â Â Â  The Buonfortesâ€™ 
  Appeal
A.Â Â Â Â Â  General Scheme of Development
The Buonfortes 
  argue the special referee erred by ordering them to remove the garage and alter 
  the mother-in-law wing.Â  They contend Dinkins implicitly approved their construction 
  plans pursuant to an automatic approval provision in the restrictive covenants.Â  
  We disagree.
â€œThe cardinal rule of contract interpretation 
  is to ascertain and give legal effect to the partiesâ€™ intentions as determined 
  by the contract language.â€Â  Schulmeyer v. State Farm Fire & Cas. Co., 
  353 S.C. 491, 495, 579 S.E.2d 132, 134 (2003).Â  Thus, â€œ[i]f the contractâ€™s language 
  is clear and unambiguous, the language alone determines the contractâ€™s force 
  and effect.â€Â  Id.
The restrictive covenants provide: 

In the event Robert Ross Dinkins, or his designated representative, 
  fails to approve or disapprove within thirty days after plans and specifications 
  have been submitted to him, or in the event no suits to enjoin the construction 
  have been commenced prior to the completion thereof, approval will not be required 
  and the related covenants shall be deemed to have been fully complied with.

(emphasis added).Â  
The Buonfortes submitted a copy 
  of their plans to Dinkins.Â  Subsequently, approximately eighteen days after 
  the Buonfortes submitted their plans to Dinkins and before Dinkins responded, 
  the Neighbors sued the Buonfortes.Â  Because the Neighbors filed suit against 
  the Buonfortes before the expiration of Dinkinsâ€™ thirty days response period, 
  we hold this provision of the restrictive covenants is inapplicable.
B.Â Â Â Â Â  Fees and Costs
The Buonfortes argue 
  the special referee erred by ordering them to pay all of the fees and costs 
  of the litigation.Â  We disagree.Â  
â€œIn every civil action commenced 
  or prosecuted in the courts of record in this State . . . the attorneys for 
  the plaintiff or defendant shall be entitled to recover costs and disbursements 
  of the adverse party.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-37-10 (1977); see Rule 54(d), 
  SCRCP (â€œ[C]osts shall be allowed as of course to the prevailing party unless 
  the court otherwise directs.â€).Â  However, â€œ[n]o costs will be allowed to any 
  party unless he succeed, in whole or in part, in his claim or defense, unless 
  otherwise directed by the judge hearing the cause.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-37-20 
  (1977).Â  
Initially, we note, the Buonfortes 
  do not argue the special referee lacked authority to award fees and costs.Â  
  Furthermore, the Buonfortes do not argue the special referee awarded fees and 
  costs for expenses not provided for by statute.Â  Rather, the Buonfortes only 
  argue the special referee abused his discretion by ordering the Buonfortes to 
  pay all of the fees and costs of the litigation.
In an action in equity, the decision 
  to grant or deny costs is largely a matter within the sound discretion of the 
  trial court.Â  See Cauthen v. Cauthen, 81 S.C. 313, 315, 62 S.E.2d 
  319, 320 (1908).Â  Thus, this court will not disturb the decision of the trial 
  court absent a clear abuse of discretion.Â  Id.
The Neighbors sued the Buonfortes, 
  seeking to enforce restrictive covenants.Â  Specifically, they sought to have 
  the Buonfortes remove both the mother-in-law wing and the garage.Â  The Buonfortes 
  answered, seeking to maintain both additions to their house.Â  The special referee 
  ordered the Buonfortes to remove the garage.Â  Furthermore, the special referee 
  ordered the Buonfortes to remove the front entrance to the mother-in-law wing 
  and the gabled front entrance, thus bringing the mother-in-law wing in aesthetic 
  alignment with the rest of the neighborhood.Â  
From the record before us, we 
  conclude the special referee did not commit a clear abuse of discretion by ordering 
  the Buonfortes to pay all of the fees and costs of the litigation.Â  Thus, we 
  hold the special referee did not err. 
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the 
  order of the special referee is
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., HOWARD, 
  and KITTREDGE, JJ., concurring.
