THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Hilton Head Resort Four Seasons Centre Horizontal Property Regime Council 
        Of Co-Owners, Inc.,        Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Martin Bergman and Hilton Head Realty Group, Defendants, Of Whom Martin 
        Bergman is,        Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Daniel E. Martin, Sr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-271
Heard March 10, 2004 â€“ Filed April 20, 
  2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Michael S. Seekings, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Russell S. Stemke, of Isle of Palms, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The Hilton Head Resort Four 
  Seasons Centre Horizontal Property Regime Council Of Co-Owners (the Regime) 
  filed a complaint against both Hilton Head Realty Group and one of the groupâ€™s 
  partners, Martin Bergman.Â  A subsequent jury trial resulted in a verdict in 
  favor of the Regime in the amount of $1,498,334.36 in actual damages and $375,000 
  in punitive damages.Â  Bergman appeals.Â  We affirm.
 FACTS
   In late 1989, Martin Bergman and Robert 
    Oâ€™Sickey formed Hilton Head Realty Group to purchase a block of condominium 
    units on Hilton Head Island.Â  In October 1989, Bergman and Oâ€™Sickey entered 
    into a contract to purchase 140 condo units, operated by the Regime, from 
    Mellon Bank.Â  Bergman and Oâ€™Sickey each contributed $50,000, which 
    was to be held in escrow by Mellon Bank.Â  After their original plan for financing 
    fell through, Bergman and Oâ€™Sickey approached New York attorneys Mark Birnbaum 
    and Kenneth Wurman about joining their venture and providing additional capital.Â  
  
  Bergman, Oâ€™Sickey, and Hilton Head Realty as 
    one party and Birnbaum and Wurman as the other party entered into a Joint 
    Venture Agreement on February 13, 1990.Â  The joint venture was formed to purchase 
    twenty condo units every thirty days until all the units were closed.Â  The 
    name of the joint venture was to be RICO, Inc.Â  On February 21, 1990, RICO, 
    Inc. was incorporated as a South Carolina Corporation.Â Â Â  
  Birnbaum and Wurman arranged for Strom Trust, 
    a client of theirs for which Birnbaum served as trustee, to provide financing 
    for the first purchase of condominiums.Â  In a document dated February 21, 
    1990, Strom Trust and Hilton Head Realty agreed Strom Trust would advance 
    $400,000 for the purchase of the first twenty units provided for in the agreement 
    with Mellon Bank.Â  
  The condominiums did not sell as quickly as expected.Â  
    Bergman found a buyer for the second set of units who took title to the units 
    immediately after the transfer from Mellon Bank to RICO in March 1990.Â  Bergman 
    testified that after that transaction, he told the other members of RICO that 
    he did not want any further involvement with the venture.Â  To that end, Bergman 
    did not make any contribution to the purchase of the third group of twenty 
    units.Â  However, he continued writing checks from the RICO account, including 
    making payments on the loans he and Oâ€™Sickey obtained to fund the escrow with 
    Mellon Bank.Â  On July 27, 1990, RICO secured a $200,000 loan from Stark Leasing, 
    another client of Birnbaum and Wurmer, for the purchase of the third set of 
    condominiums.Â  
  In October 1990, the Regime filed a lien for 
    unpaid assessments on the thirty-five units owned by RICO.Â  On February 22, 
    1991, the Regime filed a summons and complaint to foreclose on the units.Â  
    Approximately one year later, on February 25, 1992, the master filed an order 
    granting the Regime a judgment against RICO in the amount of $158,066.28 and 
    ordering the sale of the units.Â  
  The day after the decree of foreclosure 
    was filed, Strom Trust and Stark Leasing each filed to foreclose on their 
    mortgages with RICO, naming the Regime as a party.Â  The Regime answered and 
    filed a cross-claim against RICO.Â  In May of 1992, the circuit court granted 
    Strom Trust and Stark Leasing judgments of foreclosure of the mortgages.Â  
    The Regime filed motions to vacate the foreclosure judgment, challenging the 
    relative priority of the mortgages and otherwise challenging the validity 
    of the claims of the mortgage holders.Â  On June 29, 1992, RICO filed for voluntary 
    bankruptcy under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code.Â  The circuit 
    court subsequently entered an order vacating the foreclosure judgments of 
    Strom Trust and Stark Leasing and declaring the Regime had a first priority.Â  
  
  In May 1995, RICO, Strom Trust, Stark Leasing, 
    Wurman, Birnbaum, and the Regime agreed to settle.Â  As part of this settlement, 
    Strom Trust and Stark Leasing combined to form StarkStrom, which would own 
    all of RICOâ€™s assets, including the remaining twenty-eight condo units in 
    the Regime.Â  StarkStrom also agreed to issue a note and first mortgage to 
    the Regime for $230,000.Â  There would be no interest calculated on this amount 
    as long as StarkStrom did not default and made three payments of $76,667 on 
    June 1, 1996, June 1, 1997, and December 31, 1997. 
    [1] Â  In the Agreement, the Regime reserved the claims it believed it 
    had against Bergman and Oâ€™Sickey.  
  In September of 1995, the Regime filed 
    an amended answer and cross-claim against Hilton Head Realty, Bergman, and 
    Oâ€™Sickey alleging various causes of action, including:Â  violation of the Unfair 
    Trade Practices Act, [2]  civil 
    conspiracy, Statute of Elizabeth [3]  claims, piercing the corporate 
    veil, and liability under the doctrine of joint enterprise.Â  The master-in-equity 
    issued an order consolidating all these actions and realigning the parties. 
    [4] Â  In response to Bergmanâ€™s motion for a jury trial, the master ruled 
    that the equitable causes of action, including piercing the corporate veil, 
    would not be tried by the jury.Â  The master then transferred the remaining 
    issues to the jury roster in circuit court. 
  The case against Bergman was tried in front of 
    a jury from April 30, 2001 to May 4, 2001. [5] Â  After the Regime rested its case, the trial 
    court granted Bergmanâ€™s directed verdict motion as to the Unfair Trade Practices 
    Act cause of action but denied the directed verdict motions as to civil conspiracy 
    and joint venture.Â  In addition, the court allowed the Regime to amend its 
    complaint to include a cause of action for negligence.Â  
  At the close of trial, but before closing arguments, 
    Bergman made a motion â€œfor a directed verdict based on [his] argument made 
    at the close of [the Regime]â€™s case.â€Â  This motion was denied.Â  Therefore, 
    the jury considered the following causes of action:Â  negligence, civil conspiracy, 
    and liability under the doctrine of joint enterprise.Â  The jury returned a 
    verdict for the Regime in the amount of $1,498,334.36 in actual damages and 
    $375,000 in punitive damages.Â  Bergman filed a motion for judgment notwithstanding 
    the verdict (JNOV), or, in the alternative, a motion for a new trial absolute 
    or a new trial nisi remittitur.Â  The trial court denied these 
    motions.Â  This appeal followed.Â  

  LAW/ANALYSIS

I.         
Motion to Amend the Pleadings
      Bergman argues the trial court 
        erred in allowing the Regime to amend its pleadings to add a cause of 
        action for negligence.Â  
      After the trial court denied Bergmanâ€™s motions 
        for directed verdict, the Regime moved to amend the pleadings to include 
        a cause of action for negligence.Â  Bergmanâ€™s attorney responded:

      Your Honor, I would oppose such an amendment.Â  We 
        have prepared our defense which include[s] the cross examination of the 
        plaintiffâ€™s witness and at this late stage an (sic) new cause of action 
        really added is inappropriate.Â  And I realize there is a rule allowing 
        the plaintiff in some circumstances to amend to conform for the pleadings 
        but I donâ€™t think itâ€™s appropriate here.Â  

      The trial court agreed to allow the amendment, 
        but did not state any grounds for its ruling.Â  
      The
      South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure provide for the amendment of
      pleadings: 

      When issues not raised by the pleadings are tried 
        by express or implied consent of the parties, they shall be treated in 
        all respects as if they had been raised in the pleadings.Â  Such amendment 
        of the pleadings as may be necessary to cause them to conform to the evidence 
        and to raise these issues may be made upon motion of any party at any 
        time, even after judgment; but failure so to amend does not affect the 
        result of the trial of these issues.Â  If evidence is objected to at the 
        trial on the ground that it is not within the issues made by the pleadings, 
        the court may allow the pleadings to be amended and shall do so freely 
        when the presentation of the merits of the action will be subserved thereby 
        and the objecting party fails to satisfy the court that the admission 
        of such evidence would prejudice him in maintaining his action or defense 
        upon the merits.Â  The court shall upon motion grant a continuance reasonably 
        necessary to enable the objecting party to meet such evidence.Â  Upon allowing 
        any such amendment or evidence the Court shall state in the record the 
        reason or reasons for allowing the amendment or evidence.Â  In the event 
        the Court should try issues not raised by the pleadings, it shall state 
        in the record all such issues tried and the reason therefor.

      Rule 15(b), SCRCP.
      â€œMotions to amend pleadings to 
        conform to proof may be made upon motion of any party at any time, even 
        after judgment . . . .â€Â  Ball v. Canadian Am. Express Co., 314 
        S.C. 272, 275, 442 S.E.2d 620, 622 (Ct. App. 1994).Â Â Â  Generally, amendments 
        to conform to proof should be liberally allowed.Â  Pool v. Pool, 
        329 S.C. 324, 328, 494 S.E.2d 820, 822 (1998).Â Â  â€œIt is well established 
        that a motion to amend is addressed to the sound discretion of the trial 
        judge, and that the party opposing the motion has the burden of establishing 
        prejudice.â€Â  Foggie v. CSX Transp., Inc., 315 S.C. 17, 23, 431 
        S.E.2d 587, 590 (1993).Â  â€œThe prejudice Rule 15 envisions is a lack of 
        notice that the new issue is going to be tried, and a lack of opportunity 
        to refute it.â€Â  Pool, 329 S.C. at 328-29, 494 S.E.2d at 823.Â  If 
        late amendment of the pleadings would cause prejudice to the opposing 
        party, the court should either deny the amendment or grant a continuance 
        reasonably necessary to allow the opposing party to meet the amendment.Â  
        Ball, 314 S.C. at 275, 442 S.E.2d at 622. 
      Bergman only opposed the amendment 
        due to the lateness of the motion rather than the sufficiency of evidence 
        to support a cause of action for negligence.Â  That the motion to amend 
        came after the Regime rested its case does not prevent the trial judge 
        from granting such an amendment.Â  â€œSimply because an amendment to conform 
        to proof was made late in the trial affords no basis for holding that 
        the amendment comes too late. . . .Â  [T]he question is one of prejudice 
        to the opposing party.â€Â  Soil & Material Engâ€™rs, Inc. v. Folly 
        Assocs., 293 S.C. 498, 501, 361 S.E.2d 779, 781 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  
      
      On appeal, Bergman argues he was prejudiced 
        because he â€œhad absolutely no opportunity to present any evidence as to 
        the duties and responsibilities of a corporate officer, had no opportunity 
        to present any experts to discuss duties and responsibilities of corporate 
        officers, and had no opportunity to show that [his] actions fell within 
        the established standard of care.â€Â  Bergman failed to raise these arguments 
        as grounds for his opposition to the motion to amend at the time of the 
        amendment.Â  Accordingly, these arguments are not properly before this 
        court.Â  See Glover v. North Carolina Mut. Life Ins. Co., 
        295 S.C. 251, 257, 368 S.E.2d 68, 72 (Ct. App. 1988) (stating this court 
        will not reverse a trial courtâ€™s ruling on a motion on a basis not presented 
        to the trial court).Â  
      At the time of the motion to amend, Bergman only 
        asserted that he would be prejudiced by the amendment because his preparation 
        of his defense, including the cross-examination of the Regimeâ€™s witnesses 
        would have been different.Â  We find Bergman has failed to demonstrate 
        sufficient prejudice for this court to reverse the trial courtâ€™s allowance 
        of the amendment.Â  One of the Regimeâ€™s primary witnesses during its case 
        was Bergman himself, who testified again during his own case after the 
        amendment.Â  Furthermore, at the time of the amendment, Bergman did not 
        move for a continuance as is allowed by Rule 15(b), SCRCP.Â  As Bergman 
        did not take steps to secure more time in which to prepare a defense for 
        the new negligence cause of action, we cannot conclude the trial court 
        abused its discretion in finding Bergman was not so prejudiced as to mandate 
        denying the amendment.
      Bergman asserts the trial court 
        erred in failing to state for the record its reasons for allowing the 
        amendment as required by Rule 15 (b), SCRCP.Â  As Bergman failed to object 
        to this omission, the issue is not preserved for our review.Â  Wilder 
        Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (stating 
        that it is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time 
        on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge 
        to be preserved for appellate review).Â  Similarly, Bergman failed to request 
        the court require the Regime to set forth evidence to support its motion.Â  
        He cannot complain about the ambiguity of the motion on appeal.Â  See 
        id. Â Bergmanâ€™s inclusion of these arguments in his post-trial motions 
        does not preserve them for appeal.Â  See Patterson v. Reid, 
        318 S.C. 183, 185, 456 S.E.2d 436, 437 (Ct.App.1995) (â€œA party cannot 
        for the first time raise an issue by way of a Rule 59(e) motion which 
        could have been raised at trial.â€).
      Accordingly, we affirm the trial 
        courtâ€™s grant of the motion to amend the pleadings to include a cause 
        of action for negligence.Â  As Bergman does not challenge the sufficiency 
        of the evidence to support the cause of action for negligence, we must 
        affirm the juryâ€™s verdict in favor of the Regime on this issue.Â  
II.      Civil Conspiracy and Joint Venture
Causes of ActionÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Bergman argues the trial court 
        judge erred in denying his motion forÂ  judgment notwithstanding the verdict 
        (JNOV) as to the civil conspiracy cause of action.Â  Bergman also argues 
        the trial court judge erred in denying his motions for JNOV and a new 
        trial absolute as to his liability under the doctrine of joint venture.Â  
        We do not need to reach these arguments under the two-issue rule.Â 
      â€œUnder the â€˜two issueâ€™ rule, when 
        the jury returns a general verdict involving two or more issues and its 
        verdict is supported as to at least one issue, the verdict will not be 
        reversed on appeal.â€Â  Anderson v. South Carolina Dep't of Highways 
        & Pub. Transp., 322 S.C. 417, 419, 472 S.E.2d 253, 254 (1996). 
        The supreme court in Anderson illustrated the â€œtwo issue ruleâ€ 
        as follows:

      [The] two applications of the â€œtwo issueâ€ rule are 
        illustrated in the following example:Â  A case is submitted to the jury 
        on the issues of defamation and invasion of privacy.Â  The jury returns 
        a general verdict for the plaintiff.Â  The defendant appeals, arguing that 
        the trial court erred by failing to direct a verdict on the defamation 
        issue.Â  Under one application of the â€œtwo issueâ€ rule, an appellate court 
        would affirm because defendant has failed to appeal the invasion of privacy 
        issue as well.Â  Assuming, however, that the defendant has appealed both 
        issues, the appellate court would affirm on the basis of a second application 
        of the â€œtwo issueâ€ rule, if either of the two issues supported
      affirmance.  
      

      Id.  at 420, 472 S.E.2d at 254.Â  
      Thus, under this second application of the 
        â€œtwo issueâ€ rule, we find it unnecessary to address the issues of civil 
        conspiracy and liability under the joint venture doctrine as our ruling 
        on the negligence issue requires affirmance of the juryâ€™s general verdict. 
        Â 
III.      
Motions for a new trial nisi remittitur or absolute. 
    Bergman argues the trial court judge 
      erred in denying his motion for a new trial nisi remittitur or new 
      trial absolute.Â  We disagree.
     The trial court alone has the power 
      to grant a new trial nisi when it finds the amount of the verdict 
      to be merely inadequate or excessive.Â  Oâ€™Neal v. Bowles, 314 S.C. 
      525, 527, 431 S.E.2d 555, 556 (1993). The denial of a motion for a new trial 
      nisi is within the trial courtâ€™s discretion and will not be reversed 
      on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Id.Â  On appeal of the denial 
      of a motion for a new trial nisi, the appellate courts will reverse 
      only when the verdict is grossly inadequate or excessive requiring the granting 
      of a new trial absolute.Â  Id.Â  
    The trial courtâ€™s decision to deny 
      a motion for new trial absolute is within its discretion and will not be 
      reversed absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Cock-N-Bull Steak House, Inc. 
      v. Generali Ins. Co., 321 S.C. 1, 9, 466 S.E.2d 727, 731 (1996).Â  When 
      reviewing the denial of a motion for new trial, the court must look at the 
      testimony and inferences raised therefrom in the light most favorable to 
      the nonmoving party.Â  Welch v. Epstein, 342 S.C. 279, 302-03, 536 
      S.E.2d 408, 420 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€œThe trial court must set aside a verdict 
      only when it is shockingly disproportionate to the injuries suffered and 
      thus indicates that passion, caprice, prejudice, or other considerations 
      not reflected by the evidence affected the amount awarded.â€Â  Id. 
      at 302, 536 S.E.2d at 420.Â  A juryâ€™s determination of damages is entitled 
      to substantial deference by this court.Â  Knoke v. S.C. Depâ€™t. of Parks, 
      Recreation & Tourism, 324 S.C. 136, 141, 478 S.E.2d 256, 258 (1996).Â  
    
    In support of his 
      argument that the juryâ€™s verdict was excessive, Bergman raises four issues.Â  
      We find these issues are not properly before this court.Â  Bergman asserts 
      the Regime failed to mitigate its damages by selling the foreclosed units 
      and that it waived its right to collect the debt from Bergman individually 
      by waiving its right to collect from RICO.Â  We find no indication in the 
      record that Bergman presented these issues to the jury.Â  See McClary 
      v. Massey Ferguson, Inc., 291 S.C. 506, 511, 354 S.E.2d 405, 408 (Ct. 
      App. 1987) (stating whether the party acted reasonably to mitigate damages 
      is ordinarily a question for the jury); Stovall Bldg. Supplies, Inc. 
      v. Mottett, 305 S.C. 28, 35, 406 S.E.2d 176, 180 (Ct. App. 1990) (stating 
      the question of waiver is a matter for the jury or fact finder).Â  Bergman 
      also argues that the regime fees assessed against RICO after the order of 
      foreclosure should be stricken from the damages award.Â  Bergman, however, 
      failed to object when the Regime introduced these damages into evidence.Â  
      See Jackson v. Speed, 326 S.C. 289, 307, 486 S.E.2d 750, 759 
      (1997) (a party who fails to object to the admission of evidence when it 
      is offered cannot make its admission a ground for appeal).Â Â  
    Finally, Bergman argues that because 
      the Regimeâ€™s settlement with StarkStrom impaired the collateral that secured 
      the debt, the Regime should be barred from seeking an alternative recovery 
      against Appellant.Â  Our review of the record, however, reveals Bergman failed 
      to raise this or any of the other above arguments until his motion for a 
      new trial.Â  See Patterson v. Reid, 318 S.C. 183, 185, 456 
      S.E.2d 436, 437 (Ct.App.1995) (â€œA party cannot for the first time raise 
      an issue by way of a Rule 59(e) motion which could have been raised at trial.â€).Â  
      Accordingly none of these issues are preserved for our review.Â Â  
Viewing
the evidence in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party, the Regime, we
find the trial court did not err in denying Bergmanâ€™s motion for a new trial. 
In the order denying Bergmanâ€™s post-trial motions, the court found the
juryâ€™s award of damages was not unreasonable. 
The court based this determination on the fact that the jury awarded
$1,498,334.36 in actual damages and the Regime had submitted an exhibit at trial
in which it itemized damages totaling $1,498,334.36. 
After Bergman waived a procedural objection, this exhibit was admitted
into evidence without objection.  The
trial court found Bergman had not presented any evidence that the jury was
â€œcontrolled by corruption, prejudice, passion or caprice.â€ 
We agree with the trial judgeâ€™s findings and find there was no abuse of
discretion in denying the new trial motion. 
There was sufficient evidence in the record to support the juryâ€™s
verdict â€“ down to the penny â€“ and Bergman failed to show the juryâ€™s
verdict resulted from any kind of improper motive. 
Accordingly, we conclude the trial court judge did not err in denying
Bergmanâ€™s motions for a new trial nisi remittitur or absolute.
CONCLUSION
Based upon the foregoing, the trial court judgeâ€™s findings are
       AFFIRMED.
      HUFF, STILWELL, and CURETON,
      JJ., concur.Â  

     
        [1]    StarkStrom made the first payment on June 1, 1996; 
        however, the parties agreed to restructure the next two payments and pay 
        the amounts in increments until the full amount was paid.Â  
    
     
       
         
        [2]    S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 39-5-10 et seq. (1985 & Supp. 
        2003).
    
     
       
         
        [3]    S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-23-10 (Supp. 2003). 
    
     
       
         
        [4]    As a result of this realignment, the parties were arranged in 
        the same manner as is currently before this court.
    
     
        [5]    The Regime settled its claims against Oâ€™Sickey 
        prior to trial.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Robert Hoisington,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Douglas W. MacNeille, Keri A. Jordan, Ruth &
MacNeille, P.A., William 
        A. Ruth, and Michael G. Olivetti,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
L. Henry McKellar, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-274
Submitted April 6, 2004 â€“ Filed April 
  21, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Robert Hoisington, pro se, for Appellant.
Charles J. Baker, III, Martha H. Rhodes, Susan Taylor Wall 
  and Jenny Anderson Horne, all of Charleston; and Solicitor Warren C. Powell, 
  Jr., of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Robert Hoisington appeals an 
  order granting summary judgment to Douglas W. MacNeille, Keri A. Jordan, Ruth 
  & MacNeille, P.A., William A. Ruth and Michael G. Olivetti (collectively, 
  Respondents). Robert argues error by the trial judge in finding that the statute 
  of limitations had run prior to the service and filing of his complaint. He 
  also contends error in the judgeâ€™s failure to find civil liability on the part 
  of respondents and his finding that Jordan and the other respondents had no 
  duty to Robert. We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Robert and Carol Hoisington, although 
  never formally married, were deemed in a previous action to have a common law 
  marriage. Â They have three children, all boys, currently ages 12, 11, 
  and 8.Â  Carol filed for a divorce from Robert in April, 1997.Â  
Jordan was an associate in the 
  Hilton Head law firm of Ruth & MacNeille, P.A., while Ruth, Olivetti, and 
  MacNeille were shareholders of this firm.Â  Jordan was asked by Robertâ€™s and 
  Carolâ€™s attorneys to be guardian ad litem (GAL) for their children in their 
  divorce action. She was officially appointed to this position on June 13, 1997, 
  although she visited the parties in May, and participated at a hearing held 
  on June 2 in this capacity.Â  At the June 2 hearing, Robert and Carol reached 
  an agreement and consented to Jordanâ€™s recommendation that Carol be granted 
  temporary custody, with an obligation on Carolâ€™s part to get substance abuse 
  counseling and both parties to undergo drug testing.Â  
In January 1998, Robert met with Jordan and indicated 
  he was concerned about her performance as GAL and the amount of fees she had 
  been charging.Â  Robert indicated he had no confidence in Jordan as the GAL, 
  and he believed she was not competent to represent his children and she was 
  extremely biased.Â  Jordan informed Robert and his attorney that she would consent 
  to a motion to have her relieved as GAL.Â  
On February 5, 1998 Robert received 
  an anonymous letter stating the following:

To Robert,
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Carol is having an affair with Doug McNeille (sic), 
  a married lawyer, for the past four or five months.Â  They have sex at your house 
  while your children are there.Â  Prove they are having an affair, and it should 
  save you a lot of money in your divorce.Â  Ask your lawyer.
          
-An anonymous friend who doesnâ€™t think Carol deserves alimony.

Robert read the letter and asked someone at work to look at it.Â  That person 
  told Robert he had been writing checks to Ruth & MacNeille.Â  Within five 
  minutes of reading the letter, Robert realized that the attorney referred to 
  in the letter was Jordanâ€™s boss.Â  On February 5, Robert spoke with his attorney 
  about the letter and asked him to get a private investigator to look into the 
  matter.Â  
On February 23 or 24, 1998, Robertâ€™s attorney contacted 
  Jordan and informed her there was an allegation that MacNeille was having an 
  affair with Carol.Â  Subsequent to that conversation, Jordan saw Robertâ€™s attorney 
  at the courthouse, at which time he informed her about the anonymous letter.Â  
  Jordan testified, although she knew that MacNeille and Carol were acquainted 
  and that Carol visited the law firm office, she thought the visits were part 
  of Carolâ€™s association with Dixie Youth baseball.Â  Jordan denied any knowledge 
  of the affair prior to the call from Robertâ€™s attorney.Â  Upon learning of the 
  allegations, Jordan immediately prepared a notice of motion to be relieved as 
  GAL.Â  The motion was dated February 24, 1998, and was filed on February 26, 
  1998.Â  A hearing was held on March 17, 1998, at which time both Robertâ€™s and 
  Carolâ€™s attorneys consented to the motion.Â  Jordan was thereafter relieved of 
  her duties as GAL.Â  
At a hearing on April 30, 1998 
  a successor GAL was appointed.Â  When asked by the trial judge at the pre-hearing 
  conference why she had asked to be relieved, Jordan stated that â€œthere had been 
  an allegation made against a shareholder in my firm of some type of a relationship 
  with one of the parties.â€Â  
Both Robert and Carol sought custody of 
  their children.Â  In November 1998, the family court determined that Robert and 
  Carol had a common law marriage and the divorce action proceeded.Â  In July 1999, 
  Robert took Carol and MacNeilleâ€™s depositions.Â  Carol admitted to the affair 
  with MacNeille as well as another with her sonâ€™s baseball coach.Â  MacNeille 
  invoked the protection of the Fifth Amendment when asked if he had a sexual 
  relationship with Carol.Â  The successor GALâ€™s report recommended Robert be given 
  custody of the children.Â  In November 2000, the court granted custody of the 
  children to Robert.Â  In March 2001, Robert was granted a divorce from Carol 
  on the grounds of adultery.Â  
In August 2001, after Robert filed the current 
  action and Carol filed her own, separate action against the respondents, Carol 
  testified by way of deposition that her affair with MacNeille usually involved 
  MacNeilleâ€™s use of cocaine and marijuana, and that she used cocaine with him 
  on one occasion.Â  She further claimed that, during their affair, MacNeille acted 
  in many ways like her attorney and spoke about the case to Jordan on at least 
  one occasion.Â  
On February 16, 2001, this action was filed and 
  given to the Sheriffâ€™s Office for service on Respondents.Â  The complaint alleged 
  malpractice on the part of Jordan arising from the conflict of interest and 
  her failure to investigate the allegations or inform the court.Â  It alleged 
  negligence on the part of MacNeille for endangering the children and ending 
  any chance of reconciliation between Robert and Carol. It also accused the law 
  firm of negligent inaction for failing to make efforts to police their members 
  and in not reporting MacNeille to the proper authorities.Â  Robert asserted, 
  as a direct and proximate result of the respondentsâ€™ negligence, his â€œchildrenâ€™s 
  normal development was endangered, his children were put under physical risk 
  because their motherâ€™s drug addiction was being fostered, and any possibility 
  of reunion between [Robert and Carol] were (sic) diminished.â€Â  He further alleged 
  he was required to pay considerable sums in GAL fees [1]  and child support, and was deprived 
  of custody of his children while they were put at risk.Â  The trial judge found 
  that the action was time barred by the statute of limitations because more than 
  three years had passed from Robertâ€™s receipt of the letter alleging the affair 
  to the date of filing and service.Â  Alternatively, he found that Jordanâ€™s status 
  as GAL made her immune from civil suits relating to the performance of those 
  duties, Jordan owed no duty to Robert as the childrenâ€™s father, and that MacNielle 
  was not civilly liable because South Carolina no longer recognizes the torts 
  of criminal conversation and alienation of affection.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe purpose of summary judgment is to expedite disposition 
  of cases which do not require the services of a fact finder.â€Â  George v. 
  Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001).Â  When reviewing the 
  grant of a summary judgment motion, the appellate court applies the same standard 
  which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP:Â  summary judgment is 
  proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving 
  party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Ferguson v. Charleston 
  Lincoln Mercury, Inc., 349 S.C. 558, 562, 564 S.E.2d 94, 96 (2002).Â  In 
  determining whether any triable issue of fact exists, the evidence and all reasonable 
  inferences drawn therefrom must be viewed in a light most favorable to the nonmoving 
  party.Â  Hendricks v. Clemson University, 353 S.C. 449, 455-56, 578 S.E.2d 
  711, 714 (2003).
LAW / ANALYSIS
On appeal, Robert does not dispute that the applicable 
  limitations period for his claim against respondents is three years.Â  Rather, 
  he contends the trial judge erred in finding the statute of limitations barred 
  this action because the action was commenced within three years.Â  We disagree.
South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-530 (Supp. 2003) provides 
  a three-year statute of limitations for legal malpractice suits or â€œany injury 
  to the person or rights of another, not arising on contract and not enumerated 
  by law.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-530(5) (Supp. 2003);Â  Peterson v. Richland 
  County, 335 S.C. 135, 138, 515 S.E.2d 553, 555 (Ct. App. 1999);Â  Berry 
  v. McLeod, 328 S.C. 435, 444, 492 S.E.2d 794, 799 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  With 
  respect to injuries to the person, the discovery rule provides: â€œExcept as to 
  actions initiated under Section 15-3-545 [actions for medical malpractice], 
  all actions initiated under Section 15-3-530(5) must be commenced within three 
  years after the person knew or by the exercise of reasonable diligence should 
  have known that he had a cause of action.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-535 (Supp. 
  2003).
â€œAccording to the discovery rule, the statute of 
  limitations begins to run when a cause of action reasonably ought to have been 
  discovered.Â  The statute runs from the date the injured party either knows or 
  should have known by the exercise of reasonable diligence that a cause of action 
  arises from the wrongful conduct.â€Â  Dean v. Ruscon Corp., 321 S.C. 360, 
  363, 468 S.E.2d 645, 647 (1996).

The exercise of reasonable diligence means simply that an 
  injured party must act with some promptness where the facts and circumstances 
  of an injury would put a person of common knowledge and experience on notice 
  that some right of his has been invaded or that some claim against another party 
  might exist.Â  The statute of limitations begins to run from this point and not 
  when advice of counsel is sought or a full-blown theory of recovery developed.

Wiggins v. Edwards, 314 S.C. 126, 128, 442 
  S.E.2d 169, 170 (1994) (quoting Snell v. Columbia Gun Exchange, Inc., 
  276 S.C. 301, 303, 278 S.E.2d 333, 334 (1981)).Â  The focus date under the discovery 
  rule is the date of discovery of the injury and not the date of discovery of 
  the wrongdoer.Â  Id. at 128, 442 S.E.2d at 170.

The important date under the discovery rule is the date 
  that a plaintiff discovers the injury, not the date of the discovery of the 
  identity of another alleged wrongdoer.Â  If, on the date of injury, a plaintiff 
  knows or should know that [he] had some claim against someone else, the statute 
  of limitations begins to run for all claims based on that injury.

Id. (quoting Tollison v. B & J Machinery 
  Co., Inc., 812 F.Supp. 618, 620 (D.S.C. 1993)).Â  
The test of whether or not a person should have 
  known the operative facts is objective rather than subjective.Â  Bayle v. 
  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 344 S.C. 115, 123, 542 S.E.2d 736, 740 
  (Ct. App. 2001).Â  The test is not whether a particular plaintiff actually knew 
  he or she had a claim against a party.Â  Id.Â  Rather, the discovery rule 
  focuses on whether the plaintiff acquired knowledge of any existing facts sufficient 
  to put the party on inquiry.Â  Peterson, 335 S.C. at 139, 515 S.E.2d at 
  555.
Robert contends he had no cause of action against 
  respondents until Jordan and her firm failed to investigate or report MacNeilleâ€™s 
  conduct to the authorities after they were given notice of the allegation of 
  the affair on the February 23 or 24, 1998.Â  We disagree.Â  
It is clear the injuries Robert alleges all stem 
  from the sexual relationship between Carol and MacNeille and the alleged conflict 
  of interest that arose therefrom during the time period that Jordan was acting 
  as GAL.Â  Jordan denied any knowledge of the affair prior to being contacted 
  by Robertâ€™s attorney, and it is undisputed that, recognizing the potential conflict, 
  Jordan immediately took steps to have herself relieved as GAL to the children 
  once she was informed.Â  Robert had the means of discovering his potential claim 
  against the respondents when he received the anonymous letter on February 5, 
  1998.Â  On this date, the facts and circumstances put Robert on notice that some 
  right of his may have been invaded or that some claim against another party 
  might exist.Â  It is irrelevant that Jordan and the law firm may have thereafter 
  failed to investigate the allegations, as Robert acquired knowledge of facts 
  sufficient to put him on inquiry prior to the time that Jordan received notice 
  of the potential conflict of interest.Â  Indeed, Robert stated that at the time 
  he received the letter and discovered the connection between Jordan and MacNeille, 
  he felt it explained why â€œall these . . . biased things [had] been happening 
  to [him]â€ and it â€œstarted making sense of what [had] transpired over the pastâ€ 
  and why things had gone â€œheavily toward Carol and heavily against [him].â€Â  Robert 
  further admitted, â€œthe machinery to inquire into the Doug MacNeille/Carol Hoisington 
  matter was underway on February 5, 1998.â€Â  The fact that an injured party does 
  not initially comprehend the full extent of the damages does not prevent the 
  proverbial clock from starting at the moment that party is aware of the facts 
  that caused the injury.Â  Barr v. City of Rock Hill, 330 S.C. 640, 645, 
  500 S.E.2d 157, 160 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  Because Robert knew or should have known 
  that he had some claim against someone on February 5, 1998 for any injuries 
  accompanied by the affair between Carol and MacNeille, the statute of limitations 
  began to run at that point for all claims based on that injury. The statute 
  of limitations began to run at this time, and not when a full-blown theory of 
  recovery was developed by Robert.
Further, we find our decision in Burgess v. Am. 
  Cancer Socâ€™y, 300 S.C. 182, 386 S.E.2d 798 (Ct. App. 1989), remarkably similar 
  to the situation in the instant case.Â  In Burgess, the plaintiff was 
  fired as executive director of the American Cancer Societyâ€™s local office and 
  later sued the society for this termination.Â  Her attorney in the action was 
  having an affair during the litigation with the woman who replaced her as the 
  director of the organization.Â  The plaintiff learned of the alleged affair, 
  and several years later heard that the attorney had passed information regarding 
  plaintiffâ€™s lawsuit to the Cancer Society during the litigation.Â  She subsequently 
  sued her attorney for malpractice.Â  Stressing that the discovery rule focuses 
  upon whether the complaining party acquired knowledge of any existing facts 
  that would be sufficient to put the party on inquiry, such that if developed 
  would disclose the alleged wrong, the court held that the statute of limitations 
  began to accrue when the plaintiff learned of the affair, not when she learned 
  of the communications giving rise to the alleged malpractice.Â  Burgess, 
  300 S.C. at 186-87, 386 S.E.2d at 800-01.Â  Thus, the suit was barred pursuant 
  to the statute of limitations.
It is undisputed that on February 5, 1998 Robert learned 
  of the alleged affair which, as in Burgess, was very likely to lead to 
  some kind of conflict on the part of Respondents concerning the handling of 
  his legal matter.Â  Per the discovery rule, the statute of limitations began 
  to accrue at this time.Â  Because the current action was initiated more than 
  three years after this date, it is time barred by the statute of limitations 
  as a matter of law. [2] 
For the forgoing reasons, the decision of the trial 
  court is
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and STILWELL, JJ. and CURETON, AJ., concur.

 
   [1] Approximately 
    one month after Robert filed this action, Carol was ordered to reimburse Robert 
    for the $7,000 in GAL fees he paid to Jordan.Â  

 
   [2] In 
    light of our determination that this action is barred by the statute of limitations, 
    we need not reach Robertâ€™s remaining issues on appeal.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Josephine Washington and Annie Brown,       
Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Kimberly Eve Miller,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
A. Victor Rawl, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-276
Heard April 6, 2004 â€“ Filed April 22, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, and REMANDED


  
    
      
Patrick W. Carr, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Akim A. Anastopoulo, Constance A. Anastopoulo and Eric S. Brock, all of Charleston, 
  for Respondents.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  In this negligence case, Kimberly 
  Eve Miller (Appellant) appeals from an order of the circuit court granting summary 
  judgment to Josephine Washington and Annie Brown (collectively, Respondents) 
  as to both negligence and proximate cause, while leaving the determination of 
  the amount of damages to the jury.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and 
  remand.
FACTS
This case arises from an automobile 
  accident which occurred on May 4, 2001, between Appellant and Respondent Josephine 
  Washington.Â  Respondent Washingtonâ€™s mother, Annie Brown, was a passenger in 
  her daughterâ€™s car, which was being driven in the left hand lane.Â  Appellant 
  changed from the middle lane to the left lane so that she would be in position 
  to make a left hand turn.Â  Prior to changing lanes, Appellant checked her side 
  mirror, but did not realize how close the Respondentsâ€™ car was to Appellantâ€™s 
  vehicle.Â  As a result, Appellant struck the Respondentsâ€™ car.
During her deposition, the Appellant 
  was asked: â€œDo you believe sitting here today that you could have avoided this 
  accident?â€Â  Appellant answered: â€œI think â€“ yes, yes, I think that if I had realized 
  that I didnâ€™t have enough space to get over, then I would have not tried to 
  go over in her lane.â€Â  Based on this admission and affidavits from a physician 
  that the Respondentsâ€™ injuries were proximately caused by the accident, the 
  Respondents moved for summary judgment.Â  Appellant did not submit any affidavits 
  at the summary judgment hearing regarding duty, breach, or proximate cause.Â  
  Instead, Appellant relied on the denials and defenses found in the pleadings.
The circuit court granted summary judgment as to 
  duty, breach, and proximate cause, leaving the determination of the amount of 
  damages to the jury.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Summary judgment is appropriate where the pleadings, 
  depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with 
  the affidavits, if any, show there is no genuine issue as to any material fact 
  and the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.Â  Hansen 
  ex rel. Hansen v. United Servs. Auto. Assâ€™n, 350 S.C. 62, 67, 565 S.E.2d 
  114, 116 (Ct. App. 2002) (citing Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Tupper v. Dorchester 
  County, 326 S.C. 318, 325, 487 S.E.2d 187, 191 (1997)).
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  Summary Judgment as to 
  Liability
In a claim of negligence, the 
  plaintiff must show the: (1) defendant owes a duty of care to the plaintiff; 
  (2) defendant breached the duty by a negligent act or omission; (3) defendantâ€™s 
  breach was the actual and proximate cause of the plaintiffâ€™s injury; and (4) 
  plaintiff suffered an injury or damages.Â  Andrade v. Johnson, 356 
  S.C. 238, 245, 588 S.E.2d 588, 592 (2003).Â  In this case, the Respondents 
  presented Appellantâ€™s deposition testimony admitting she could have avoided 
  the accident if she had realized that she did not have enough space to change 
  lanes without striking the Respondentsâ€™ vehicle.Â  Appellant did not file any 
  counter-affidavits or introduce any deposition testimony. 
  [1] Â  South Carolina law requires that: 

Where the plaintiff relies solely 
  upon the pleadings, files no counter-affidavits, and makes no factual showing 
  in opposition to a motion for summary judgment, the lower court is required 
  under Rule 56, to grant summary judgment, if, under the facts presented by the 
  defendant, he was entitled to judgment as a matter of law. . . .

Humana Hospital-Bayside v. 
  Lightle, 305 S.C. 214, 216, 407 S.E.2d 637, 638 (1991).
Appellant argues that because 
  her deposition contains statements that she had turned on her left-hand turn 
  signal and checked for other cars using the mirror and looking over her shoulder, 
  an issue of comparative negligence has been created.Â  This argument is not compelling 
  in light of Appellantâ€™s admission that she breached her duty to yield to the 
  favored driver before switching lanes.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-1900(a) 
  (1991).Â  While courts should be reticent to endorse summary judgments in cases 
  involving comparative negligence, this reticence does not mean that simply pleading 
  comparative negligence will operate as a bar to summary judgment.Â  Cf. Thomasko 
  v. Poole, 349 S.C. 7, 12, 561 S.E.2d 597, 599 (2002) (stating that â€œ[i]n 
  a comparative negligence case, the trial court should grant the [directed verdict] 
  motion if the sole reasonable inference from the evidence is the non-moving 
  partyâ€™s negligence exceeded fifty percent.â€).Â  In this case, because of Appellantâ€™s 
  admission, the sole reasonable inference is that Appellantâ€™s negligence caused 
  the accident.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court properly granted summary judgment 
  after considering the admission in the deposition and the lack of opposition 
  by Appellant.
2.Â  Summary Judgment as to 
  Proximate Cause
Despite the grant of summary 
  judgment regarding liability, the Respondents are not relieved of their responsibility 
  to prove that Appellantâ€™s breach was the actual and proximate cause of the Respondentsâ€™ 
  injuries.Â  See Andrade v. Johnson, 356 S.C. 238, 245, 588 
  S.E.2d 588, 592 (2003).Â  A physicianâ€™s affidavit stating that â€œin [his] 
  professional opinion, to a reasonable degree of medical certainty most probably, 
  [the Respondentsâ€™] injuries . . . were a proximate result of the injuries [they] 
  sustained in the automobile accidentâ€ does not foreclose a juryâ€™s opportunity 
  to measure the credibility of the evidence as to proximate cause.Â  â€œThe fact 
  that testimony is not contradicted directly does not render it undisputed.Â  
  There remains the question of the inherent probability of the testimony and 
  the credibility of the witness or the interests of the witness in the result 
  of the litigation.â€Â  Black v. Hodge, 306 S.C. 196, 198, 410 S.E.2d 595, 
  596 (Ct. App. 1991) (citation omitted).
In contrast to the physicianâ€™s 
  affidavit, the following facts exist: (1) the Respondents refused medical treatment 
  at the scene of the accident; (2) the automobile air bags did not deploy; and 
  (3) the Respondentsâ€™ car was driven away from the scene of the accident.
â€œIn determining whether any triable 
  issue of fact exists, the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably 
  drawn therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving 
  party.â€Â  Summer v. Carpenter, 328 S.C. 36, 42, 492 S.E.2d 55, 58  (1997).Â  
  Taking the deposition testimony in the light most favorable to Appellant, inferences 
  could be drawn that this was a minor accident that would not normally cause 
  injury to the Respondents.Â  In light of these facts, a determination about the 
  extent to which the accident did or did not cause injuries should be left to 
  a jury.Â  Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment as to proximate 
  cause is reversed.
In light of our ruling as to 
  proximate cause, it is not necessary to address Appellantâ€™s allegation that 
  the circuit court improperly considered Appellantâ€™s payment to Respondent Washington 
  in settlement of property damage.Â  Additionally, the verdict form ordered by 
  the circuit court is no longer appropriate as it required the jury to return 
  a monetary verdict for the Respondents.Â  This Court would suggest that the appropriate 
  verdict form to be used is one that offers two choices for each of the Respondents: 
  (1) â€œWe, the jury, find for the Plaintiff in the amount ofÂ  ______ actual damagesâ€; 
  and (2) â€œWe, the jury, find for the Defendant.â€
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, 
  based on the foregoing reasons, the decision of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED 
  IN PART, and REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J., ANDERSON, and 
  BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Appellant stated the deposition of the investigating officer had 
    been scheduled for the week following the summary judgment hearing.Â  However, 
    the deposition statement by Appellant is a clear admission that could not 
    be refuted by the limited testimony of an investigating officer.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Edward D. Sloan, Jr., individually, and a Citizen, Resident, Taxpayer 
        and Registered Elector of Greenville County,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Greenville County, a Political Subdivision of the State of South Carolina, 
        Dozier Brooks, Scott Case, Bob Cook, Joseph Dill, Cort Flint, Lottie Gibson, 
        Phyllis Henderson, Allen "Bunk" Johnson, Mark Kingsbury, Xanthene 
        Norris, Stephen Selby, and Robert Taylor,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-277
Submitted April 6, 2004 â€“ Filed April 22, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James G. Carpenter and Jennifer 
  J. Miller, both of Greenville, for Appellant.
Thomas H. Coker and Boyd B. Nicholson, Jr., both of Greenville, 
  for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Edward D. Sloan, Jr., suing 
  as a taxpayer and citizen of Greenville County, brought this action challenging 
  the sufficiency of a written determination by the county for the procurement 
  of design-build services for the countyâ€™s 2001-2002 Roads Paving Program.Â  Sloan 
  alleged that the countyâ€™s written determination was insufficient and, was therefore 
  â€œarbitrary, capricious, ultra vires and an abuse of discretion.â€Â  
  He appeals the ruling of the trial court, finding the determination was sufficient, 
  granting judgment to the County, and dismissing the case with prejudice.Â  We 
  affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The Greenville County Code 
  (â€œG.C.C.â€ or â€œthe Codeâ€) prescribes the methods the County may use in awarding 
  contracts for construction services.Â  Generally, under the Code, the County 
  must procure construction services that exceed $15,000 through the competitive 
  sealed biding (â€œCSBâ€) process.Â  G.C.C. Â§ 7-213.Â  However, the County may forego 
  the CSB method and utilize an alternative procurement and construction method 
  if one of several exceptions set out in the code applies.Â  One of these alternative 
  methods is the â€œdesign-build services, turnkey management services, or construction 
  management servicesâ€ method (hereinafter collectively referred to as â€œdesign-build 
  servicesâ€).Â  Specifically, Greenville County Code Â§ 7-212 provides in pertinent 
  part as follows: 

Unless otherwise required 
  by law, all county contracts shall be awarded by competitive sealed bidding, 
  pursuant to section 7-213 (competitive sealed bidding), except as provided in:
. . . 
(10) Section [7-242.5] 
  [1]  (design-build services, turnkey management services, or construction 
  management services).

G.C.C. Â§ 7-212.Â  The Code defines these services as â€œapproaches 
  to construction contract management that allow for the selection of a single 
  firm to perform and/or manage the complete design and construction of a project.â€Â  
  G.C.C. Â§ 7-198.Â  
Greenville County Code Â§ 7-242.5 sets out the guidelines 
  that the county administrator shall follow when exercising his discretionary 
  right to utilize the design-build construction method in lieu of the CSB method.Â  
  The administrator is to consider the method which, in his or her discretion, 
  is â€œthe most advantageous to the county and will result in the most timely, 
  economical and successful completion of the construction project.â€Â  This determination 
  must be stated in writing and included as a part of the contract file.Â  G.C.C. 
  Â§ 7-242.5(a). [2] Â  If the county administrator determines use 
  of design-build services is most advantageous, and the project exceeds $5 million, 
  the administratorâ€™s written determination must be submitted for review to the 
  county councilâ€™s committee of the whole.Â  Notice of review must be presented 
  to the public, and an interested party has fifteen days to submit written comments 
  to the committee of the whole.Â  At the next committee meeting, members of the 
  public who submitted written comments may address the committee.Â  Following 
  comments, County Council may reject the design-build method.Â  If County Council 
  does not vote to reject the design-build method, the project goes forward.Â  
  G.C.C. Â§ 7-242.5(b).Â  
In October 2001, the county administrator of Greenville County 
  made a written determination to use design-build service for the Countyâ€™s 2001-2002 
  Roads Project. This determination called for the procurement of these services 
  through the competitive sealed proposal (CSP) method.Â  The County gave public 
  notice of the determination, inviting the public to make comment upon it.Â  The 
  administrator submitted the determination to county council at its committee 
  of the whole meeting and council did not reject the proposal.Â  Following a selection 
  process pursuant to G.C.C. Â§ 7-215, governing the CSP method, the County entered 
  into a contract with a contractor for the performance of the project.Â  
In November 2001, Sloan filed a summons and complaint challenging 
  the sufficiency of the determination and seeking declaratory and injunctive 
  relief.Â  While admitting that the County had prepared a written determination, 
  Sloan alleged that the County â€œfailed to include sufficient facts and rationale 
  based on those stated facts to justify an exception to competitive sealed bidding.â€Â  
  Thus, he alleged that the determination was â€œarbitrary, capricious, ultra 
  vires and an abuse of discretion.â€Â  
The trial judge held that Sloan had â€œutterly failed to meet 
  his burden of proof on [the] claim.â€Â  Instead of concluding that the document 
  arbitrarily triggered the exception, the trial judge found that the written 
  determination contained several well-reasoned conclusions supported by empirical 
  data and prior County experience to support the county administratorâ€™s decision 
  to use the design-build/CSP method.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW / ANALYSIS
The action before us now is nearly identical to a suit recently 
  ruled on by this Court concerning the same parties of the present case.Â  The 
  current case differs from the previous suit, also brought by Sloan against Greenville 
  County, only in that it challenges a different written determination for use 
  of the design-build/CSP method than the three determinations in prior years 
  challenged by the previous case.Â  Sloan v. Greenville County, 356 S.C. 
  531, 590 S.E.2d 338 (Ct. App. 2003) (hereinafter â€œSloan Iâ€).Â  As in the 
  previous case, the primary issue here is the validity of the Countyâ€™s determination 
  to use design-build/CSP source selection instead of competitive sealed bidding.Â  
  Since the present action was brought before the filing of the first caseâ€™s opinion, 
  several issues extensively discussed and conclusively determined by the prior 
  case are raised again here.Â  As such, we give these matters only a cursory treatment 
  here and focus instead on the sufficiency of the particular written determination 
  at issue in this case.
I.Â  STANDARD OF REVIEW
As in Sloan I, Sloan contends this is an action in 
  equity such that this court has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with 
  our own view of the preponderance of the evidence. 
  [3] Â  The county argues this action is one at law and this court should, 
  accordingly, apply an â€œany evidenceâ€ standard of review. 
  [4] Â  We agree with Sloan that this action is properly characterized as 
  one in equity, and we should therefore apply the preponderance of the evidence 
  standard of review.
In Sloan I, after considering that the main purpose 
  of the suit was to enjoin the County from awarding contracts in a manner which 
  Sloan claims is ultra vires under Greenville Countyâ€™s procurement 
  code, and the fact that Sloan did not seek monetary damages, but instead sought 
  a judgment to prevent the County from awarding future public works contracts 
  in the manner employed, we held this type of action is appropriately characterized 
  as equitable, and should be reviewed under the preponderance of the evidence 
  standard.Â  We further noted, however, that under this broad scope of review, 
  we are not required to disregard the findings of the trial judge.Â  Id. 
  at 544-46, 590 S.E.2d at 345-46.
II.Â  JUSTICIABILITY 
  OF SLOANâ€™S CLAIMS
Greenville County contends that this case is not properly 
  justiciable because Sloan lacks standing to challenge the Countyâ€™s contract 
  awards.Â  This same issue was raised in Sloan I.Â  There we noted, while 
  generally a taxpayer may not maintain a suit to enjoin the action of State officers 
  when he has no special interest and his only standing is the exceedingly small 
  interest of a general taxpayer, the rules of standing are flexible, and one 
  may assert taxpayer standing if he demonstrates some overriding public purpose 
  or concern to confer standing to sue on behalf of his fellow taxpayers.Â  Id. 
  at 548-49, 590 S.E.2d at 347.
As in Sloan I, we find Sloan has standing 
  in this case.Â  He has the same interest as a taxpayer in how public funds were 
  spent on large projects requiring the expenditure of millions of taxpayer dollars, 
  this burden was borne exclusively by the taxpaying citizens of Greenville County, 
  and Sloan therefore had a real, material, and substantial interest in whether 
  the County properly followed the procurement procedures set out in the county 
  code.Â  Id. at 551, 590 S.E.2d at 349.Â  The issue in the present case 
  is also of sufficient public importance to confer taxpayer standing.Â  See 
  Id. at 551, 590 S.E.2d at 349 (finding taxpayer â€œpublic importanceâ€ standing 
  in similar case involving issue of competitive bidding procurement because â€œpublic 
  entities must be accountable under the laws and regulations which govern how 
  they spend public moneyâ€). For these reasons, we conclude that the trial court 
  correctly determined Sloan had standing to pursue this declaratory judgment 
  action.
III. ADMISSIBILITY OF EVIDENCE REGARDING THE WRITTEN DETERMINATIONS
Sloan argues the trial court erred by allowing 
  the county to present evidence regarding the written determinations for the 
  use of the design-build/CSP method of source selection.Â  He contends that since 
  the trial court was seeking to determine the sufficiency of a written determination, 
  its inquiry should be limited to the facts contained within the four corners 
  of that writing.Â  We disagree.
Again, this issue was decided under a nearly identical 
  factual scenario in the Sloan I decision.Â  As in Sloan I, the 
  testimony in question in this case extended beyond the confines of the written 
  determinations that were submitted to County Council.Â  Sloan I, 356 S.C. 
  at 560-62, 590 S.E.2d at 354-55.Â  As we did in the prior case, we find that 
  this evidence was material and probative to the trial courtâ€™s inquiry into the 
  sufficiency of the written determination, and its admission was proper in order 
  to educate the court, as the finder of fact, of the surrounding circumstances 
  and â€œfill in the gapsâ€ so that the court might have a better understanding.Â  
  Id. at 562, 590 S.E.2d at 355.Â  Just as in Sloan I, Sloanâ€™s reliance 
  here on Piedmont Natural Gas Co. v. Hamm, 301 S.C. 50, 389 S.E.2d 655 
  (1990), and Parker v. South Carolina Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 288 S.C. 304, 
  342 S.E.2d 403 (1986), is misguided, for â€œ[b]oth Piedmont Natural Gas 
  and Parker stand for the rule that after a case has been remanded by 
  an appellate court, a party cannot submit additional evidence unless the appellate 
  court has given leave to do so.â€ Id. at 562, 590 S.E.2d at 354.Â  The 
  present case does not concern the admission of additional evidence upon remand 
  from appeal, but the trial courtâ€™s initial consideration of evidence at trial.Â  
  As such, the cases cited by Sloan are not applicable to this analysis.Â  
IV.Â  SUFFICIENCY OF THE WRITTEN DETERMINATION
Having found Sloanâ€™s claims to be properly reviewable 
  by this court and the disputed testimony to be properly admitted at trial, we 
  now review whether the written determination published by the County is sufficient 
  under the Greenville County Code and this Courtâ€™s prior decision in Sloan 
  I. 
The Greenville County Code grants the County the 
  discretionary power to use design-build/CSP source selection rather than the 
  traditional CSB method.Â  County Code Â§ 7-242.5(a).Â  A discretionary decision 
  of a legislative body should not be upset on appeal unless such determination 
  is â€œarbitrary, unreasonable, in obvious abuse of discretion, or in excess of 
  lawfully delegated power.â€Â  Sloan I, 356 S.C. at 555-56, 590 S.E.2d at 
  351; Smith v. Georgetown County Council, 292 S.C. 235, 238, 355 S.E.2d 
  864, 866 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  Since the use of the design-build method may raise 
  concerns among citizens of the County, [5]  it is limited under the Code 
  to those situations in which it is properly justified.Â  In justifying the exercise 
  of this discretionary power, the county administrator or his designee must consider 
  â€œthe method which in [his or his designeeâ€™s] discretion is the most advantageous 
  to the county and will result in the most timely, economical, and successful 
  completion of the construction project.â€Â  G.C.C. Â§ 7-242.5(a).Â  Additionally, 
  the determination of this method of source selection must be stated in writing 
  and included in the contract file.Â  Id.  
Considering the underlying legislative intent and guiding 
  policies of the Greenville County Code, this Court has held that a written determination, 
  required by section 7-242.5, must serve the following dual function:

The determination must first effectively inform county council 
  of the reasons why design-build source selection works to the Countyâ€™s best 
  advantage for the project at issue.Â  Equally important, the determination must 
  provide the citizens of Greenville County a window into the Countyâ€™s decision-making 
  process--safeguarding the quality and integrity of the contract awards through 
  public accountability.Â  

Sloan I, 356 S.C. at 556, 590 S.E.2d at 351-52.Â  â€œIf 
  the written determination provides sufficient factual grounds and reasoning 
  for the County Council and the public to make an informed, objective review 
  of these decisions, then it has accomplished its purpose.â€Â  Id. at 556, 
  590 S.E.2d at 352.Â  In other words, if County Council and the public can look 
  to the written determination and comprehend the Countyâ€™s rationale in utilizing 
  the design-build method as arguably the most timely, economical, and potentially 
  successful option, then the determination is sufficient.
The written determination to use design-build source 
  selection for the Roads 2001-2002 project was prepared by Greenville County 
  Administrator Steven Stewart.Â  Like the prior yearsâ€™ projects at issue in Sloan 
  I, Stewartâ€™s determination addresses County Councilâ€™s time, budget, and 
  quality requirements and sets forth the project-specific reasons why design-build 
  rather than traditional competitive sealed bidding procurement serves to better 
  meet the Countyâ€™s goals.Â  See Sloan I, 356 S.C. at 557, 590 S.E.2d 
  at 352.
Stewartâ€™s written determination first addresses 
  the underlying plan of the County behind this particular project, an expedited 
  road-paving plan meant to improve County roads by the year 2010 (the â€œPrescription 
  for Progress, Paving County Roadsâ€ program).Â  He also noted that the 2001-2002 
  Road Improvement Program outweighed the capacity of the current staff. Considering 
  the one-year timeframe for completion of the project and the limited staff available, 
  Stewart concluded the design-build/CSP method would best address the road programâ€™s 
  needs, while maintaining the quality level of other county services.Â  Stewart 
  also cited the success of past design-build/CSP county projects, including previous 
  â€œPrescription for Progressâ€ road projects, for the proposition that the design-build 
  method could again be successfully utilized by the County.Â  The determination 
  continues by pointing out how the design-build method, as opposed to the traditional 
  CSB method, would be particularly advantageous to the County in this specific 
  large scope project.Â  It speaks to one of the goals being to ensure the roads 
  are â€œbuilt and maintained in such a manner to maximize life expectancy and riding 
  surface condition.â€Â  It notes that, under the current process of public/private 
  partnership, the strain on County staff is alleviated, and the County can provide 
  a full time inspector to travel the roads and insure proper inspection procedures 
  are being followed.Â  Further, the determination states that, due to staffing 
  requirements, it would cost the County an extra $1,075,000 should the design-build/CSP 
  method not be used.Â  It also indicates that utilization of an alternative method 
  (such as CSB) would mean the project would take at least one additional year 
  to complete compared to the design-build method.Â  These assertions go directly 
  to the frugality, timeliness and quality of the design-build method as opposed 
  to the traditional CSB method in this particular project.
Based on the foregoing, we find this determination 
  provided ample grounds to support County Councilâ€™s decision to approve use of 
  the design-build method.Â  Since it addressed the specific needs of the project 
  and weighed alternative methods for procuring construction services, the determination 
  provided County Council and members of the public â€œclear insight into the rationale 
  underlying its decision to use [the] design-build [method].â€Â  Sloan, 
  356 S.C. at 558, 590 S.E.2d at 352.Â  Accordingly, the trial court properly ruled 
  this determination was sufficient under Â§ 7-242.5 of the Greenville County Code.
For the foregoing reasons, the decision of the trial court 
  is
 AFFIRMED.
 GOOLSBY, HUFF, and CURETON, A.J., concur.

 
   [1] The 
    Code references Â§ 7-236 within Â§ 7-212(10), but this is apparently a scriveners 
    error and the parties agree the section should reference Â§ 7-242.5 instead.Â  
  

 
   [2] The 
    portion of Greenville County Code Â§ 7-242.5 most at issue reads as follows:
  (a) The county administrator 
    or his designee shall have the discretion to use construction management services, 
    design-build services, or turnkey management services as alternatives for 
    construction contracting administration.Â  In exercising such discretion, the 
    county administrator or his designee shall consider the method which in the 
    administrator or his designeeâ€™s discretion is the most advantageous to the 
    county and will result in the most timely, economical, and successful completion 
    of the construction project.Â  The determination of the method of source selection 
    utilized shall be stated in writing and included as part of the contract file.

 
   [3] In 
    an action in equity, tried by a judge alone, without a reference, on appeal 
    the appellate court has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with its 
    own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. 
    City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).

 
   [4] In 
    an action at law, on appeal of a case tried without a jury, the findings of 
    fact of the judge will not be disturbed upon appeal unless found to be without 
    evidence which reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings.Â  Townes Assocs., 
    Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â Â  
  

 
   [5]  See Sloan I, 356 S.C. at 541, 590 
    S.E2d at 344 (â€œIt is [the] design-build [method]â€™s lack of objective, bright-line 
    criteria that raises concerns about its use. . . . Because price is not a 
    controlling factor in design-build source selection, the public entity may 
    not always receive the lowest, most competitive price possible.â€).
