THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Beachside Real Estate, Inc.,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
John Y. Dong, Danher Dong, also known as Danher W. Wang, and Jianyun 
        Y. Dong,        Defendants and Third-Party Plaintiffs,
Of Whom John Y. Dong and Danher Dong, also known as Danher W. Wang are       
Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Dick Hargett,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Roger M. Young, Master-in-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-278
Submitted April 6, 2004 â€“ Filed April 
  26, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John J. Dodds, III, of Mount Pleasant, for Appellants.
Dennis E. O'Neill, of Mount Pleasant, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Dr. John Y. Dong a/k/a Dr. 
  Jianyun Y. Dong and his wife, Dr. Danher Dong a/k/a Dr. Danher W. Wang (â€œAppellantsâ€) 
  [1] , appeal the masterâ€™s rulings in favor of Beachside Real Estate, Inc. 
  (â€œRespondentâ€) in this breach of contract action.Â  We affirm. 
  [2] 
FACTS
On or about May 26, 2000, Dr. Dong 
  phoned Dick Hargett, a real estate agent for Respondent, to inquire about certain 
  parcels of real property located in the Victory Point neighborhood in Charleston, 
  South Carolina.Â  Appellants met with Mr. Hargett on May 27, 2000 to view the 
  properties.Â  Finding a parcel of property to their liking, Appellants decided 
  to place an offer.
Prior to placing the offer, on that same day, May 
  27, 2000, Mr. Hargett asked Appellants to sign an Acknowledgment of Relationship 
  Disclosure form.Â  This document identified Appellants as Buyers and acknowledged 
  that Beachside Real Estate and Mr. Hargett were Appellantsâ€™ agents.Â  Also on 
  May 27, 2000, Appellants signed an Exclusive Buyer Agency Agreement with Beachside 
  Real Estate and Mr. Hargett which provided that, should their offer be accepted, 
  Mr. Hargettâ€™s commission would be paid completely by the listing broker.Â  Mr. 
  Hargett testified that he fully explained both forms to Appellants and particularly 
  how the listing broker would pay his commission.Â  However, after placing the 
  offer, Appellants were informed the piece of property was no longer available.
Due to the unavailability of their first 
  choice, Appellants soon expressed an interest in another parcel of property 
  located in the same neighborhood. 
  [3] Â  Unlike the prior property in which Appellants expressed interest, 
  this property was not listed in the Multiple Listing Service.Â  Instead, the 
  owners were selling the property through an independent real estate agent.Â  
  Mr. Hargett explained to the Appellants that the significance of this difference 
  was that the sellers would not be paying his commission and accordingly, the 
  buyers would have to pay the commission.
Accordingly, on May 31, 2000, Mr. Hargett 
  prepared another Exclusive Buyer Agency Agreement (â€œthe Agreementâ€) which provided 
  that the buyer agreed to pay the broker (Mr. Hargett) five percent of the sales 
  price upon successful negotiation of a contract on the property.Â  Mr. Hargett 
  testified that on June 1, 2000, he delivered the Agreement to Appellantâ€™s office, 
  but due to the fact that Dr. Dong was out of town, Dr. Wang was the only person 
  to sign the form.
After execution of the Agreement, Dr. 
  Wang submitted an offer to purchase the property for $350,000.Â  This offer listed 
  Beachside Real Estate as the cooperating broker.Â  The owner did not accept this 
  offer, and Mr. Hargett prepared a second offer of $353,000 on June 2, 2000.Â  
  In contrast to the first offer, both Dr. Dong and Dr. Wang signed the second 
  offer, which also listed Beachside Real Estate as the cooperating broker.Â  Both 
  offers were also contingent on Appellants getting approval to install a dock 
  on the property. [4] Â  Â Â 
 Again, the owner of the property did not 
  accept Appellantsâ€™ offer.Â  Mr. Hargett contacted the ownerâ€™s agent on numerous 
  occasions in an effort to get the asking price lowered.Â  After receiving a counteroffer 
  from the owner of $360,000, Dr. Dong expressed concern that he would not be 
  able to pay that asking price along with Mr. Hargettâ€™s commission.Â  As such, 
  Mr. Hargett got the impression Appellants were going to look at other properties.Â  
  Accordingly, Mr. Hargett and Appellants looked at properties in several other 
  locations, but no offers on any of the properties were made through Mr. Hargett 
  or Beachside Real Estate. 
On June 27, 2000, Dr. Dong received a 
  fax from the ownerâ€™s agent offering to sell the property for $360,000 if the 
  decision was made that day, earnest money of $20,000 was paid, and the deal 
  closed by August 15, 2000.Â  Dr. Dong accepted the offer the same day by writing 
  â€œagreedâ€ on the fax and signing his name.Â  Also on June 27, 2000, both Dr. Dong 
  and Dr. Wang entered into a contract to purchase the property per the ownerâ€™s 
  proposal for $360,000.Â  Shortly thereafter, Dr. Dong contacted Carolina First 
  Bank about obtaining a loan to pay for the property.
Having obtained loan approval, Appellants sought an 
  attorney to handle the real estate closing.Â  Appellants first contacted attorney 
  Robert W. Haines.Â  Upon learning of Appellantsâ€™ intention to close with Mr. 
  Haines, Mr. Hargett wrote a letter to both Mr. Haines and Appellants.Â  The letter 
  stated that Appellants owed him a commission of $18,000.00 and included all 
  paperwork executed by the Appellants.Â  Knowing Dr. Dong would not agree to pay 
  the commission, Mr. Haines asked Appellants to escrow the commission so that 
  the dispute could be resolved through other channels.Â  Unable to convince Appellants 
  to pay the commission or escrow the disputed amount, Mr. Haines terminated his 
  representation.
Appellants then contacted attorney Amy Campbell in 
  an attempt to complete the closing.Â  After discovering that Ms. Campbell was 
  going to perform Appellantsâ€™ closing, Mr. Hargett provided her with a copy of 
  the Agreement as well.Â  Like Mr. Haines, after receiving this information, Ms. 
  Campbell refused to perform the closing.
Appellants were finally able to complete the closing 
  by contacting attorney C.J. Manos.Â  Because Mr. Manos was unknown to Mr. Hargett, 
  he never became aware of the Agreement or that a commission was being claimed 
  on the purchase of the property.  [5] Â  As such, Appellants were able 
  to complete the closing.Â  Significantly, title to the property was placed in 
  Dr. Dongâ€™s name only.Â  
On December 6, 2000, Respondent commenced the current 
  action alleging breach of contract, breach of the implied covenant of good faith 
  and fair dealing, breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act, and civil 
  conspiracy.Â  Appellants answered averring several defenses, including violation 
  of section 40-57-135(D) of the South Carolina Code.Â  Appellants also asserted 
  a number of counterclaims, including breach of fiduciary duty, fraud, and fraudulent 
  concealment.
The case was tried before a master-in-equity on September 
  18, 2002.Â  On October 1, 2002, the master issued his order finding in favor 
  of Respondent.Â  The master held inter alia that the Agreement 
  met all of the statutory requirements necessary to be a proper buyer representation 
  agreement.Â  Accordingly, the master found that because Dr. Wang signed the Agreement, 
  she was bound by it and thus, she was liable for breach of contract in the amount 
  of $18,000 as well as costs.Â  Concomitantly, the master found that because Dr. 
  Dong did not sign the Agreement, he was not a party to it, and therefore he 
  was not liable.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â 
ISSUES

  I.         Did the trial court err in holding that Dr. Dong was not a party to the Agreement 
  dated May 31, 2000?
  II.         Did the trial court err in holding that the May 31, 2000 Agreement complied 
  with statutory requirements and as such, Dr. Wang was bound by its terms?
  III.        Did the trial court err in ruling Dr. Wang was liable to Respondent in the amount 
  of $18,000 under the May 31, 2000 Agreement?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
An action to recover a brokerâ€™s commission 
  is an action at law.Â  Chambers v. Pingree, 351 S.C. 442, 449, 570 S.E.2d 
  528, 531-532 (Ct. App. 2002) (citing United Farm Agency v. Malanuk, 284 
  S.C. 382, 383, 325 S.E.2d 544, 545 (1985)).Â  In an action at law, the appellate 
  court will correct any error of law, but it must affirm the masterâ€™s factual 
  findings unless there is no evidence that reasonably support those findings.Â  
  Sea Cabins on the Ocean IV Homeowners Assâ€™n, Inc. v. City of N. Myrtle Beach, 
  337 S.C. 380, 388, 523 S.E.2d 193, 197 (Ct. App. 1999); Jefferies v. Phillips, 
  316 S.C. 523, 527, 451 S.E.2d 21, 22-23 (Ct. App. 1994); see also 
  Waterpointe I Prop. Ownerâ€™s Assâ€™n Inc. v. Paragon, Inc., 342 S.C. 454, 
  459, 536 S.E.2d 878, 881 (Ct. App. 2000) (finding where an action at law for 
  interpretation of a contract referred to the master-in-equity for final judgment 
  with direct appeal to the supreme court; the appellate court will correct any 
  error of law, but must affirm the masterâ€™s findings unless there is no evidence 
  reasonably supporting them). 
LAW/ANALYSIS 
  [6] 
Appellants argue the master erred in finding Dr. 
  Dong was not a party to the Agreement.Â  Initially, we note this position is 
  completely inconsistent with that taken by Appellants at trial.Â  For instance, 
  when asked whether he knew Dr. Wang was going to make an offer on the property, 
  Dr. Dong responded that he did, but that he never saw the Agreement prior to 
  the offer being made.Â  In fact, Dr. Dong repeatedly asserted that he never signed 
  the Agreement and because he did not, he maintained that he did not owe â€œanybodyâ€ 
  a commission.
As Respondent correctly points out, Dr. Dong was 
  successful in convincing the master that because he did not sign the Agreement, 
  he should not be liable.Â  Now Appellants assert that because the master erred 
  by finding Dr. Dong was not a party to the Agreement, this caused the master 
  to further err in concluding the Agreement met the relevant statutory requirements.Â  
  Accordingly, because the Agreement did not meet the statutory requirements, 
  the trial court erred in finding Dr. Wang liable for the $18,000 commission.Â  
  We disagree with this reasoning in its entirety.
Appellantsâ€™ first assertion is that the master 
  erred in finding Dr. Dong was not a party to the Agreement.Â  The master concluded 
  that the mere presence of Dr. Dongâ€™s name on the Agreement did not make him 
  a party, nor did it otherwise invalidate the Agreement as to Dr. Wang.Â  We agree 
  with the master.Â  
Appellants aver that because other documents during 
  the course of the partiesâ€™ interaction, including the Acknowledgement of Relationship 
  form and two of the offers to purchase property, were signed by both Dr. Dong 
  and Dr. Wang, this supports their contention that Dr. Dong was a party to the 
  contested Agreement.Â  Coupled with the fact that Dr. Dong did most of the negotiating 
  with Respondent, Appellants aver this evidence â€œoverwhelmingly establishes that 
  both [Dr. Dong and Dr. Wang] were parties to the agreement.â€Â  
Based on our standard of review, we find that there 
  is more than sufficient evidence to support the masterâ€™s ruling that Dr. Dong 
  was not a party to the Agreement.Â  Not the least of which is Dr. Dongâ€™s own 
  testimony that he never saw the Agreement nor was he aware of it until after 
  the events leading up to this action had taken place.Â  
Next, Appellants contend that because Dr. Dong 
  was a party and did not sign the Agreement, the Agreement fails to satisfy section 
  40-57-135(D)(4)(g) of the South Carolina Code.Â  Section 135(D) provides in pertinent 
  part that â€œ[a] listing or buyerâ€™s representation agreement must be in writing 
  and must set forth all material terms of the partiesâ€™ agency relationship, including, 
  but not limited to . . . (g) the signature of all parties.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. 
  40-57-135(D)(4)(g) (2001).Â  Therefore, they argue because Dr. Dong was a party 
  and did not sign the Agreement, the trial court erred in holding the Agreement 
  was valid.Â  We disagree.Â  
As we have already found the master did not err 
  in concluding Dr. Dong was not a party to the Agreement, this argument is without 
  merit.Â  Significantly, Appellantsâ€™ final argument is very similar.Â  Appellants 
  contend that because Dr. Dong did not sign the Agreement and therefore the Agreement 
  is invalid, i.e., Respondent failed to comply with the statutory requirements, 
  the master erred in holding Dr. Wang was liable to Respondents.Â  Again, because 
  we find Dr. Dong was not a party to the Agreement, this argument is without 
  merit.
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, based on the above discussion, the 
  masterâ€™s rulings are
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., ANDERSON and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  For clarity, Dr. John Dong will be referred to throughout this opinion 
    as Dr. Dong and Dr. Danher W. Wang will be referred to as Dr. Wang.

 
   
    [2]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   
    [3]  The purchase of this property is the catalyst for the current dispute.

 
   
    [4]  Mr. Hargett testified that he contacted the South Carolina Coastal 
    Council and others in an attempt to get the approval Appellants sought for 
    installation of a dock.

 
   
    [5]  We feel it appropriate to mention that Mr. Manosâ€™ actions in closing 
    the transaction are not being questioned.Â  As Beachside Real Estate notes 
    in its brief, â€œMr. Manos is a well-respected, experienced real estate closing 
    attorney.Â  Mr. Manosâ€™ integrity and professional handling of this transaction 
    is above reproach.â€ 

 
   
    [6] Â  Because all of Appellantsâ€™ issues are closely related, they will 
    be addressed together.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The
State,        Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Ravin L.
Johnson,        Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Chester County
Paul E. Short, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-280
Submitted April 6, 2004 â€“ Filed April 26, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Teresa L. Norris, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  and Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; 
  and Solicitor John R. Justice, of Chester, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Ravin L. Johnson (â€œAppellantâ€) 
  appeals his conviction for voluntary manslaughter.Â  Appellant argues the trial 
  judge erred in failing to grant a directed verdict.Â  He contends the evidence 
  offered by the State was insufficient to disprove self-defense as a matter of 
  law.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On November 3, 2000, Appellant left his home in 
  West Columbia and drove to Chester to pick up his cousins, Ezekiel Darnell and 
  Mario Johnson.Â  The purpose of the trip was to bring Mario and Ezekiel back 
  to Columbia because Appellant and Mario worked together and both were due at 
  work the next day. 
Upon arrival in Chester, Appellant went 
  to Brian Jacksonâ€™s house.Â  There he met Brian, his brother, two of their friends, 
  Mario and Ezekiel.Â  Shortly thereafter, Appellant, Ezekiel, and Brian decided 
  to go to a party on Cemetery Street to visit Brandon Johnson, another of Appellantâ€™s 
  cousins.Â  Ezekiel and Appellant rode in Marioâ€™s car, Mario drove Appellantâ€™s 
  truck, and Brian drove his own car. 
Appellant and Ezekiel stayed at the party 
  for approximately fifteen minutes before deciding to leave and drive back to 
  Columbia.Â  Mario drove off first in Appellantâ€™s truck, followed closely by Appellant 
  and Ezekiel in Marioâ€™s car. [1] Â  
  Appellant was driving and Ezekiel was riding in the passenger seat.Â  As Appellant 
  and Ezekiel turned onto Cemetery Street, they noticed Danielle Hughes and Jonathan 
  Mackey walking across the street.Â Â  Ezekiel erroneously thought he knew Hughes 
  and, as a result, said something to her as they were passing by.Â Â  
Ezekiel noticed that Mackey responded, 
  but he could not make out exactly what had been said because music was playing 
  loudly in the car.Â  Ezekiel then asked Appellant to back up.Â  After backing 
  up, it became apparent to Appellant and Ezekiel that Mackey was angry with them. 
  Â Â Mackey then pulled a .38 caliber handgun from his pocket and began firing 
  at the car.Â Â  One of the bullets shattered the back window of the car and lodged 
  in the rear seat. 
Both Ezekiel and Appellant ducked when 
  the shooting began.Â  Appellant attempted to shake Ezekiel, but did not get a 
  response.Â Â  Ezekiel testified that he became hysterical and panicked.Â  Unable 
  to get a response from Ezekiel, Appellant reached under his seat and obtained 
  the gun he had taken from his own car earlier in the evening.Â Â  Appellant opened 
  his door and fired a single shot at Mackey.Â  The bullet penetrated Mackeyâ€™s 
  cheek where it lacerated the base of the brain and spinal cord.Â  Mackey died 
  in less than a minute.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Appellant then shut his door, pushed Ezekiel 
  up, and drove to his uncleâ€™s house where he attempted to contact his father.Â  
  Eventually, Appellant and Ezekiel went back to Columbia.Â  The next morning, 
  accompanied by Appellantâ€™s mother, father, and uncle, both Appellant and Ezekiel 
  went to the Chester Police Department where they related the previous eveningâ€™s 
  events and turned over Appellantâ€™s handgun. 
A Chester County grand jury indicted Appellant 
  for murder.Â  Appellant did not testify at trial.Â  At the close of the evidence, 
  Appellantâ€™s counsel moved for a directed verdict on the murder charge.Â  Counsel 
  asserted there was no evidence of â€œmalice aforethoughtâ€ given the evidence established 
  that Mackey fired the first shot.Â Â  However, he stated â€œthere might be evidence 
  to sustain a conviction on the lesser included offense of voluntary manslaughter.â€Â  
  Throughout this discussion, defense counsel asserted the theory of self-defense.Â  
  After hearing arguments from counsel, the judge directed a verdict as to the 
  murder charge, finding there was no evidence tending to show malice aforethought.Â  
  The judge then informed counsel that he would charge the jury on voluntary manslaughter.
The jury convicted Appellant of voluntary manslaughter.Â Â  
  After the verdict was read, defense counsel moved for a new trial on the ground 
  the evidence was insufficient as a matter of law as to the charge of voluntary 
  manslaughter.Â  The judge denied the motion.Â  He then sentenced Appellant to 
  fifteen years imprisonment.Â  This appeal follows.
DISCUSSION
Appellant argues the trial judge erred in failing 
  to direct a verdict as to the voluntary manslaughter charge, as the evidence 
  offered by the State was insufficient as a matter of law to disprove self-defense.
In criminal cases, â€œ[a] defendant is entitled to 
  a directed verdict when the State fails to produce evidence of the offense charged.â€Â  
  State v. McHoney, 344 S.C. 85, 97, 544 S.E.2d 30, 36 (2001).Â  â€œIn reviewing 
  a motion for directed verdict, the trial judge is concerned with the existence 
  of the evidence, not with its weight.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œIf there is any direct 
  evidence or any substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove 
  the guilt of the accused, an appellate court must find that the case was properly 
  submitted to the jury.â€ State v. McGowan, 347 S.C. 618, 622, 557 S.E.2d 
  657, 659 (2001).Â Â  On appeal from the denial of a motion for directed verdict, 
  this Court must view the evidence in a light most favorable to the State.Â  Id.Â  

At trial, Appellant argued that he shot Mackey 
  in self-defense.Â  In order for a defendant to establish self-defense, the following 
  four elements must exist: 

  (1) the defendant must be without fault in bringing on the difficulty; (2) the 
  defendant must have been in actual imminent danger of losing his life or sustaining 
  serious bodily injury, or he must have actually believed he was in imminent 
  danger of losing his life or sustaining serious bodily injury; (3) if his defense 
  is based upon his belief of imminent danger, defendant must show that a reasonably 
  prudent person of ordinary firmness and courage would have entertained the belief 
  that he was actually in imminent danger and that the circumstances were such 
  as would warrant a person of ordinary prudence, firmness, and courage to strike 
  the fatal blow in order to save himself from serious bodily harm or the loss 
  of his life; and (4) the defendant had no other probable means of avoiding the 
  danger. 

State v. Day, 341 S.C. 410, 416, 535 S.E.2d 431, 434 
  (2000).Â  
The defendant has the burden of raising self-defense.Â  
  However, once raised, the State has the burden of disproving it beyond a reasonable 
  doubt.Â  State v. Wiggins, 330 S.C. 538, 544, 500 S.E.2d 489, 492 (1998).Â  
  Significantly, in this case, the parties only dispute the existence of the first 
  and fourth elements.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Initially, we note this issue was not properly 
  raised at trial.Â  During the discussion regarding Appellantâ€™s motion for a directed 
  verdict on the murder charge, counsel agreed there was evidence to support a 
  voluntary manslaughter charge.Â  Thus, no motion was ever made to direct a verdict 
  as to the voluntary manslaughter charge.Â  Although after the jury verdict had 
  been returned, defense counsel made a motion asking the court to â€œstrike the 
  verdict and to find as a matter of law the defendant not guilty of voluntary 
  manslaughter due to the insufficiency of the evidence,â€ this does not preserve 
  the issue presented by Appellant in this appeal.Â Â  In a criminal case, the only 
  way to contest the sufficiency of the evidence post-trial is to move for a new 
  trial.Â  State v. Follin, 352 S.C. 235, 258, 573 S.E.2d 812, 824 (Ct. 
  App. 2002), cert. denied (May 30, 2003).Â  In addition, because Appellant 
  did not raise the issue of insufficiency of the evidence as to self-defense 
  in the court below, it cannot be raised for the first time on appeal.Â  See 
  State v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 5, 377 S.E.2d 581, 584 (1989) (holding that 
  a party cannot raise one ground for directed verdict to the court below and 
  another on appeal).Â  Therefore, we find the issue presented by appellant was 
  not properly preserved for our review.
In the alternative, Appellant argues the trial judge erred 
  in failing to grant judgment notwithstanding the verdict (JNOV).Â Â  However, 
  JNOV motions are civil in nature and are not appropriate in criminal trials.Â  
  See Follin, 352 S.C. at 258, 573 S.E.2d at 824 (â€œA motion for 
  JNOV is a civil trial motion, and thus it is improper for a party to move for 
  JNOV in a criminal trial . . . In criminal matters, a motion for a new trial 
  is the â€˜only available post-trial motion addressing the sufficiency of the evidence.â€™â€ 
  (quoting State v. Miller, 287 S.C. 280, 282, 337 S.E.2d 883, 884 (1985))) 
  (citations omitted).Â  Therefore, we need not address this issue.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
In any event, Appellantâ€™s argument fails on the merits as 
  well.Â  Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the State, we find 
  there was sufficient evidence to present to the jury the question of whether 
  Appellant was acting in self-defense or was guilty of voluntary manslaughter. 
  As to the first and fourth elements of self-defense, the State presented evidence 
  that Appellant stopped his car and then backed up in order to hear Mackeyâ€™s 
  response to Ezekielâ€™s comments.Â  At one point in his statement, Appellant indicated 
  that he reached under his seat for his gun and then fired at Mackey.Â  Appellant 
  then â€œgot in the car and left.â€Â  The pathologist also testified that the gunshot 
  that killed Mackey was fired at some distance.Â  Furthermore, the evidence indicates 
  that Appellant had an opportunity to flee the scene given he was driving his 
  car and Mackey was standing in the road.Â  This evidence and sequence of events 
  reasonably tended to prove that Appellant was not acting in self-defense and 
  was guilty of voluntary manslaughter.Â  Therefore, the judge properly presented 
  the case to the jury.Â  See Wiggins, 330 S.C. at 545, 500 S.E.2d 
  at 493 (â€œâ€˜Reversal of a conviction because of the trial courtâ€™s refusing to 
  give a directed verdict on the ground of self-defense is rare.â€™â€ (quoting William 
  S. McAninch & W. Gaston Fairey, The Criminal Law of South Carolina 
  483 (3d ed. 1996) (Supp. 1997 at 77))). 
Accordingly, Appellantâ€™s conviction and sentence are 
 AFFIRMED.
 HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., and CURETON, 
  AJ., concur.  

 
   
    [1]  Prior to switching cars with Mario, Appellant removed his handgun 
    from his own car and placed it in Marioâ€™s car.Â  Ezekiel testified that Appellant 
    did this so that Mario would not get in trouble should he be stopped by the 
    police while driving Appellantâ€™s car.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT 
  SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED 
  BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Mark New and Karen New,       
Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Max G. Crosby Construction Co., Inc.,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Dorchester County
Diane Schafer Goodstein, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-282
Heard January 13, 2004 â€“ Filed April 27, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART,
AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Stephen L. Brown, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Steven L. Smith, Esquire and Wm. Mark Koontz, both of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Purchasers of a home sued the 
  property development company that sold them the home and the construction company 
  that built the home for the structural damages resulting from construction.Â  
  The construction company, Crosby Construction Company (â€œCrosby Constructionâ€), 
  appeals the jury verdict in favor of the purchasers.Â  We affirm in part, reverse 
  in part, and remand.
FACTS
Crosby Construction was a charter member 
  of the Southern Living Builder Program and agreed to build homes according to 
  Southern Living plans and specifications.Â  However, Max Crosby, owner of Crosby 
  Construction, testified that Crosby Construction was allowed to alter the Southern 
  Living plans.Â  Crosby Construction contracted with Greenwood Development Corporation 
  (â€œGreenwoodâ€) to build five model homes in Coosaw Creek Country Club in North 
  Charleston, South Carolina.Â Â  One of the five homes built by Crosby Construction 
  for Greenwood was the home eventually purchased by Mark and Karen New. 
Crosby Construction and Greenwood agreed 
  to numerous modifications of the Southern Living plans with regards to the house 
  in question.Â  Specifically, the basement was eliminated, a finished media room 
  was provided, and the master bedroom and kitchen were made larger.Â  Additionally, 
  rather than utilizing steel beams, as the original Southern Living plans specified, 
  Crosby Construction changed the design to utilize wooden beams, which Max Crosby 
  believed were appropriate.Â  
Crosby Construction completed the home 
  for Greenwood in June of 1998.Â  Greenwood used it as a model home, advertised 
  the home as a Southern Living home, and sold the home to the News on October 
  21, 1998.Â Â  Crosby Construction had no hand in the sale of the house from Greenwood 
  to the News, and the Newsâ€™ contract with Greenwood made no mention of Crosby 
  Construction.Â Â  Mark New testified that he and Karen understood they were purchasing 
  a â€œSouthern Livingâ€ home. 
The News discovered several problems with 
  their home.Â  Most significantly, the News at some point discovered a hump and 
  sag in their second story floor.Â  Investigation revealed the wood beams Crosby 
  Construction had substituted for the specified steel beams proved inadequate 
  to support the load placed on them.Â  Crosby Construction sent a subcontractor 
  in to fix the beam causing the sag, however, it was inadequate.Â Â  Other problems 
  discovered by the News included a leaking roof, inadequate foundation, an incorrectly 
  sloped yard that did not drain, a bowed exterior wall, cupped and warped floors, 
  a poorly built retention wall, and poor flashing. 
The News brought suit against Greenwood 
  and Crosby Construction, alleging the breach of several implied warranties, 
  negligence, and unfair trade practices.Â  The News sought actual and punitive 
  damages against Crosby Construction and Greenwood.Â  Crosby Construction and 
  Greenwood filed answers denying the material allegations and asserting various 
  affirmative defenses.Â  The News subsequently dismissed the action against Greenwood 
  and chose instead to proceed exclusively against Crosby Construction.
 After directing a verdict against the 
  News on their claim for unfair trade practices, the trial court denied Crosby 
  Constructionâ€™s directed verdict motions and objections to the charges presented 
  to the jury.Â  At the conclusion of the four-day trial, the jury returned a verdict 
  against Crosby Construction for $285,942 in actual damages.Â  Crosby Construction 
  then filed post-trial motions for a JNOV, a new trial absolute, and a new trial 
  nisi remittitur.Â Â  These motions were denied.Â  This appeal follows.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. STIGMA DAMAGES
Crosby Construction contends the circuit court 
  erred in refusing to grant its motion for directed verdict as to the Newsâ€™ claim 
  of diminution in property value, or â€œstigmaâ€ damages.Â  Crosby Construction also 
  contends the circuit court erred in failing to grant a new trial absolute where 
  there was no evidence to support the juryâ€™s award.Â  We agree.
A. Directed Verdict
At trial, Crosby Construction moved for 
  a directed verdict on the Newsâ€™ claim for stigma damages, arguing there was 
  no testimony regarding the value of the home after repairs and to award both 
  the cost of repairs and stigma damages would amount to double recovery.Â  The 
  circuit court disagreed, finding Dr. New had testified to the value of the home 
  after all the repairs had been made, amounting to diminution in value.Â  Crosby 
  Construction contends the circuit court erred in allowing the question of stigma 
  damages to go to the jury.Â  
In ruling on motions for directed verdict, 
  the trial court is required to â€œview the evidence and the inferences that reasonably 
  can be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the party opposing the 
  motion[] and to deny the motion[] where either the evidence yields more than 
  one inference or its inference is in doubt.â€Â  Strange v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Highways 
  & Pub. Transp., 314 S.C. 427, 429-30, 445 S.E.2d 439, 440 (1994).Â  We 
  will reverse the trial court only when there is no evidence to support the ruling 
  below.Â  Id. at 430, 445 S.E.2d at 440.Â  
Stigma, or diminution in value, damages are generally 
  awarded when there is a permanent injury to real property.Â  See Gray 
  v. S. Facilities, Inc., 256 S.C. 558, 569, 183 S.E.2d 438, 443 (1971) (holding 
  that â€œ[t]he general rule is that in case of an injury of a permanent nature 
  to real property . . . the proper measure of damages is the diminution of the 
  market value by reason of that injury, or in other words, the difference between 
  the value of the land before the injury and its value after the injuryâ€).Â  Thus, 
  where there is a permanent injury to land, damages are based on the diminution 
  in value of the property based on its value before the injury and after the 
  injury.Â  Yadkin Brick Co. v. Materials Recovery Co., 339 S.C. 640, 645, 
  529 S.E.2d 764, 767 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  

While proof, with mathematical certainty, of the amount 
  of loss or damage is not required, in order for damages to be recoverable the 
  evidence should be such as to enable the court or jury to determine the amount 
  thereof with reasonable certainty or accuracy.Â  Neither the existence, causation 
  nor amount of damages can be left to conjecture, guess or speculation. 

Gray, 256 S.C. at 570-71, 183 S.E.2d at 444.
The News presented evidence at trial that 
  repairs to their home would cost $129,930.42.Â  This figure consisted of estimates 
  to repair the foundation, flashing, roof leaks, ridge beam and holes, landscaping 
  problems, as well as cosmetic damages.Â  Although the Newsâ€™ experts testified 
  that repairing the problems would not give the News the Southern Living home 
  they expected, they stated the problems could all be repaired.Â  However, one 
  expert opined that an entire new roof would need to be put in place because 
  there would always be leaks even if the current roof were repaired.Â  
Dr. Mark New testified at trial that he wanted 
  the jury to give him enough money to repair the house.Â  He also expressed concern 
  that he would have to disclose the structural damage to the house upon resale.Â Â  
  Dr. New estimated the value of the home if it were in good condition to be $550,000.Â Â  
  When asked to estimate the value of the home â€œin its present condition,â€ Dr. 
  New stated it would be $300,000 to $350,000.Â Â  Thus, we interpret Dr. Newâ€™s 
  testimony to state that the difference in value of the home if it had been built 
  in accordance with Southern Living plans and the value of the home in its then 
  current, unrepaired state to be between $200,000 and $250,000.Â Â Â  
Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable 
  to the News, no evidence was presented as to the diminution in value of the 
  home if all the repairs were performed.Â  Although Dr. New testified regarding 
  the problems disclosing the prior structural damage would pose in trying to 
  sell the house, he did not place a value on the home after repairs were performed.Â  
  His testimony only addressed the value of the home in its unrepaired state and 
  the value of the home had it been constructed according to the Southern Living 
  plans.Â  As Crosby Construction argued before the circuit court, allowing recovery 
  for both the cost of repairs and the diminution in value of the home prior to 
  repairs would amount to double recovery.Â  Further, the failure to present evidence 
  of the diminution in value of the repaired home left the jury to speculate as 
  to the amount of stigma damages.Â  Because there was no testimony regarding the 
  amount of stigma damages, the circuit court erred in failing to direct a verdict 
  on this theory of recovery. [1] Â  
  Gray, 256 S.C. at 570-71, 183 S.E.2d at 444; see also Collins 
  Music Co. v. Smith, 332 S.C. 145, 147, 503 S.E.2d 481, 482 (Ct. App. 1998) 
  (noting the general rule that there can be no double recovery for a single injury).Â  
  Accordingly, we reverse the circuit courtâ€™s denial of the motion for a directed 
  verdict as to stigma damages.
B. New Trial Absolute
Crosby Construction argues the circuit court erred in failing to 
  grant a new trial absolute because there was no evidence to support the juryâ€™s 
  award.Â  We agree.
The decision to grant or deny a motion 
  for a new trial absolute is within the trial courtâ€™s discretion and will not 
  be reversed unless the courtâ€™s decision is â€œwholly unsupported by the evidence 
  or the conclusions reached are controlled by error of law.â€Â  Vinson v. Hartley, 
  324 S.C. 389, 405, 477 S.E.2d 715, 723 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  In determining whether 
  the trial court erred in denying a motion for a new trial, we must look at the 
  testimony and inferences raised therefrom in favor of the nonmoving party.Â  
  Id.; Welch v. Epstein, 342 S.C. 279, 302-03, 536 S.E.2d 408, 420 
  (Ct. App. 2000).Â  
The circuit court may grant a new trial absolute 
  in two instances.Â  The court must grant a motion for a new trial absolute when 
  the verdict is â€œâ€˜so grossly excessive that it shocks the conscience of the court 
  and clearly indicates the verdict was the result of caprice, passion, prejudice, 
  partiality, corruption, or other improper motive.â€™â€Â  Duncan v. Hampton Co. 
  Sch. Dist. No. 2, 335 S.C. 535, 547, 517 S.E.2d 449, 455 (Ct. App. 1999) 
  (quoting Knoke v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Parks, Recreation & Tourism, 
  324 S.C. 136, 141, 478 S.E.2d 256, 258 (1996)).Â  â€œAlternatively, the trial court 
  may grant a new trial absolute when, sitting as the thirteenth juror, 
  it concludes the juryâ€™s verdict is not supported by the evidence.â€Â  Duncan, 
  335 S.C. at 547, 517 S.E.2d at 455 (emphasis in original).Â  However, substantial 
  deference should be given to a juryâ€™s determination of damages.Â  Knoke, 
  324 S.C. at 141, 478 S.E.2d at 258.Â  
The jury rendered a general verdict in 
  favor of the News in the amount of $285,942.Â  The evidence presented at trial 
  showed that it would cost $129,930.42 to make the repairs to the home.Â  Dr. 
  New opined that his home was worth between $200,000 and $250,000 less in its 
  unrepaired state than it would be worth had the home been built to Southern 
  Living specifications.Â  As discussed above, this estimate does not indicate 
  the depreciation to the home after repairs are made and cannot be considered 
  in isolation.Â  Giving substantial deference to the juryâ€™s verdict, there is 
  not any evidence in the record to support a verdict $155,000 greater than the 
  estimate of damages.Â  Because there was no evidence to support the amount of 
  the juryâ€™s verdict, the circuit court erred by failing to grant Crosby Constructionâ€™s 
  motion for a new trial absolute.Â  Accordingly, we reverse the circuit courtâ€™s 
  denial of the motion and remand the case for a new trial absolute.Â  
II. Insurance Testimony
Crosby Construction asserts the circuit court erred 
  in admitting into evidence information regarding the insurance related work 
  of one of its experts.Â  We disagree.Â  
Generally, the fact that a defendant is protected 
  by insurance from liability in an action for damages shall not be made known 
  to the jury.Â  Dunn v. Charleston Coca-Cola Bottling Co., 311 S.C. 43, 
  45, 426 S.E.2d 756, 757 (1993).Â  The rule protects against unfair prejudice 
  in the verdict that might result from the juryâ€™s knowledge that the defendant 
  will not have to pay the award amount.Â  Dunn, 311 S.C. at 45, 426 S.E.2d 
  at 757-58.Â  However, this general rule does not require evidence of insurance 
  to be kept from the jury where it is offered for some other purpose.Â  Rule 411, 
  SCRE provides:

Evidence that a person was or was not insured against liability 
  is not admissible upon the issue whether the person acted negligently or otherwise 
  wrongfully.Â  This rule does not require the exclusion of evidence of insurance 
  against liability when offered for another purpose, such as proof of agency, 
  ownership, or control, or bias or prejudice of a witness.

Rule 411, SCRE.  
Our Supreme Court has adopted a â€œsubstantial 
  connectionâ€ analysis to determine whether an expertâ€™s connection to a defendant 
  insurer is sufficiently probative of witness bias to outweigh the prejudice 
  to the defendant resulting from the knowledge that the defendant carries liability 
  insurance.Â  Yoho v. Thompson, 345 S.C. 361, 366, 548 S.E.2d 584, 586 
  (2001).Â  In Yoho, the defendant in a car wreck case was represented by 
  the underinsured motorist carrier, Nationwide Insurance Company.Â  One of the 
  defendantâ€™s experts, Dr. Brannon, did a fair amount of consulting work for Nationwide 
  and between ten to twenty percent of his practice included consulting for insurance 
  companies.Â  Our state Supreme Court reversed the circuit courtâ€™s refusal to 
  allow Yoho to question Dr. Brannon regarding his potential bias due to his work 
  with insurance companies.Â  The Court determined the connection between Brannon 
  and Nationwide was substantial enough to permit Yoho to question him about the 
  relationship and potential bias.Â  Yoho, 345 S.C. at 366, 548 S.E.2d at 
  586.Â  The Court went on to note that showing the connection to the insurance 
  company was qualitatively different from showing the expert worked for the defense 
  and was much more indicative of possible bias in favor of the defendant.Â  Id.
In the present case, Crosby Construction presented 
  Robert Lanier as an expert in general contracting.Â Â  Although the Newsâ€™ expert 
  testified that most of the repairs to the home could be accomplished for $84,580, 
  Lanier testified he could perform the same repairs for $41,901.15.Â Â  Outside 
  the presence of the jury, the News stated they wanted to question Lanier regarding 
  his estimates for insurance companies which comprised between seventy-five and 
  eighty percent of his work.Â Â  Over Crosby Constructionâ€™s objections, the circuit 
  court allowed the News to question Lanier about his insurance work.Â  Lanier 
  testified to the jury that most of his work came from making repairs for insurance 
  companies on claims on homeownerâ€™s insurance policies.Â  He also stated he was 
  willing to change his estimates upon the request of insurance companies.Â Â  The 
  parties did not know whether Lanier had ever performed work for Zurich, Crosby 
  Constructionâ€™s liability insurer, and no testimony was elicited identifying 
  specific insurance companies Lanier worked with. 
The present case is distinquishable from 
  Yoho.Â  Whereas the expert in Yoho actually performed work for 
  the insurance carrier representing the defendant, nothing in this case indicates 
  Lanier ever worked for Zurich.Â  Lanier worked with insurance companies under 
  homeownerâ€™s policies, not liability policies.Â  Despite the fact that up to eighty 
  percent of Lanierâ€™s work came from insurance companies, the â€œsubstantial connectionâ€ 
  to the specific carrier that existed in Yoho is simply not present here.Â  

Even though there is no substantial connection 
  in the present case, we believe the admission of evidence regarding Lanierâ€™s 
  connection to insurance carriers was permissible.Â  â€œA witness may be cross-examined 
  on any matter relevant to any issue in the case, including credibility.â€Â  Rule 
  611(b), SCRE.Â  â€œConsiderable latitude is allowed in cross-examination to test 
  a witnessâ€™s bias, prejudice, or credibility.â€Â  Yoho, 345 S.C. at 364-65, 
  548 S.E.2d at 585.Â  The trial courtâ€™s ruling regarding scope of cross-examination 
  to show bias or test credibility will not be overturned on appeal absent an 
  abuse of discretion.Â  Id.Â Â  
Lanier testified that he worked for insurance companies 
  on homeownerâ€™s claims.Â  He did not implicate liability insurance in violation 
  of Rule 411, SCRE.Â  Further, the testimony elicited at trial did not indicate 
  whether Crosby Construction was insured.Â  However, Lanierâ€™s dependence upon 
  insurance companies in general for up to eighty percent of his income was evidence 
  that impacted Lanierâ€™s credibility or could show potential bias.Â  As the evidence 
  did not impermissibly inform the jury regarding Crosby Constructionâ€™s insurance 
  status and it was used to test Lanierâ€™s bias, we find no abuse of discretion 
  in the present case. [2] Â  
CONCLUSION
The circuit court erred in failing to grant Crosby 
  Constructionâ€™s motion for a directed verdict on the claim for stigma damages 
  where there was no evidence to support the amount of stigma damages and allowing 
  the jury to consider stigma damages amounted to double recovery.Â  The circuit 
  court also erred in failing to grant Crosby Constructionâ€™s motion for a new 
  trial absolute because there was no evidence to support the amount of the juryâ€™s 
  award.Â  Finally, we find the circuit court did not abuse its discretion in allowing 
  evidence that Crosby Constructionâ€™s expert was connected to insurance companies.Â  Accordingly, the trial court is AFFIRMED 
  IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, and REMANDED for a new trial absolute.Â  
 AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., and CURETON, AJ., 
  concur.

 
   
    [1]  In further support of its claim that the circuit court erred in failing 
    to grant a directed verdict, Crosby Construction argues there was no evidence 
    to support a claim for stigma damages because the problems with the property 
    were not permanent and could be repaired.Â Â  Testimony from the experts indicated 
    the problems with the home could be repaired, thus the damages were not necessarily 
    â€œpermanentâ€ in nature.Â  However, Crosby Construction did not make this argument 
    before the circuit court in support of its motion for directed verdict.Â  Accordingly, 
    this argument is not preserved for appellate review.Â  Staubes v. City of 
    Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000).

 
   
    [2]  Because we reverse and remand on the issues of the trial judgeâ€™s 
    failure to grant Crosby Constructionâ€™s motions for directed verdict and a 
    new trial absolute, we need not address Crosby Constructionâ€™s remaining issues 
    on appeal.Â  However, we have chosen to address the issue regarding Lanierâ€™s 
    connection to insurance companies because it is an issue that is likely to 
    repeat itself upon retrial of this case.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Lucy J. Reuben, PhD and Dr. John A. Cole,       
Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Palmetto Traditional Homes, L.L.C. and Home Buyers Warranty Corporation, 
        Defendants,
of whom Palmetto Traditional Homes,
L.L.C. is,        Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
L. Casey Manning, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-283
Submitted April 6, 2004 â€“ Filed April 29, 2004 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
William G. Besley, Esquire, Andrew E. Haselden, Esquire, George 
  V. Hanna, IV, of Columbia; for Appellant.
Carey M. Ayer, Esquire, Lisa Lee Smith, of Lexington; for 
  Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Lucy J. Reuben and John A. 
  Cole (collectively â€œRespondentsâ€) commenced an action against Palmetto Traditional 
  Homes, L.L.C. (â€œPalmettoâ€) alleging negligence, loss of consortium, negligent 
  misrepresentation and breach of express and implied warranties.Â  Palmetto filed 
  a motion to compel arbitration.Â  After a hearing, the trial judge found Respondentsâ€™ 
  negligence and loss of consortium claims were not subject to arbitration and 
  denied the motion.Â  Palmetto appeals.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL
BACKGROUND
Respondents entered into an agreement 
  to purchase a new home from Palmetto for $266,900.Â  Respondents allege that 
  prior to the closing, Palmetto took Respondents on a walk-through of the house, 
  at which time they were shown an upstairs room over the garage which Palmetto 
  represented to be a storage room, suitable for storing personal items.Â  Respondents 
  further allege that the door to the storage area had a doorknob on each side, 
  indicating the doorway was to be utilized to enter the storage area and that 
  the door could be closed by a person standing inside the storage room.Â  Palmetto 
  denies that it represented personal items could be stored in the storage room 
  or that the room was suitable for walking and/or standing.Â  
The Respondents purchased the home on February 
  18, 2000.Â  On December 3, 2000, Respondent Reuben entered the storage room; 
  however, the flooring did not support her weight, and she fell through the floor 
  and landed atop a car in the garage below.Â  Respondents allege Reuben sustained 
  serious personal injuries as a result of the fall.Â  
Respondents filed a complaint against 
  Palmetto alleging various causes of action based on negligence and breach of 
  warranty.Â  Palmetto filed an answer and a motion to compel arbitration asserting 
  the purchase agreement required any claims arising out of or related to the 
  agreement were to be settled by arbitration, and that the contract documents 
  between the parties required Respondents to arbitrate this dispute.Â  Respondents 
  conceded that their claims for negligent misrepresentation, breach of express 
  warranty, and breach of implied warranty of habitability were subject to arbitration 
  under the agreement.Â  However, they contended their causes of action for negligence 
  and loss of consortium were not subject to arbitration.Â  After a hearing on 
  the matter, the trial judge denied Palmettoâ€™s motion to compel arbitration finding 
  (1) Respondentsâ€™ personal injury claims did not arise out of the contract and 
  were not subject to arbitration and (2) S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-48-10(b)(4) specifically 
  excludes personal injury claims from arbitration and that the Federal Arbitration 
  Act (â€œFAAâ€) did not preempt the South Carolina Uniform Arbitration Act (â€œSCUAAâ€).Â  

 STANDARD
OF REVIEW
   Unless otherwise provided by the parties, 
    the question of the arbitrability of a claim is an issue for judicial determination.Â  
    Stokes v. Metropolitan Life Ins. Co., 351 S.C. 606, 609, 571 S.E.2d 
    711, 713 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  The determination of whether or not a matter is 
    arbitrable is subject to de novo review.Â  Id.Â  However, 
    a circuit courtâ€™s factual findings on the arbitrability of a claim will not 
    be overruled if there is any evidence reasonably supporting them.Â  Id.Â  
    at 609-10, 571 S.E.2d at 713.
   LAW/ANALYSIS
     Palmetto contends the trial court erred in 
      denying its motion to compel arbitration.Â  It argues (1) Respondentsâ€™ claims 
      for negligence and loss of consortium fall within the scope of the arbitration 
      agreement and (2) even though S.C. Code Ann Â§ 15-48-10(b)(4) of the SCUAA 
      excludes personal injury claims, the FAA preempts the SCUAA with respect 
      to Respondents claims.Â  Because we find Respondentsâ€™ claims for negligence 
      and loss of consortium do not fall within the scope of the partiesâ€™ arbitration 
      agreement, we find the trial court properly denied the motion to compel.Â  
      Accordingly, we need not reach the issue of preemption.Â  
    â€œAn arbitration clause is a contractual 
      term, and general rules of contract interpretation must be applied to determine 
      a clauseâ€™s applicability to a particular dispute.â€Â  Towles v. United 
      HealthCare Corp., 338 S.C. 29, 41, 524 S.E.2d 839, 846 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
      Arbitration rests on the agreement of the parties, and the range of issues 
      that can be arbitrated is restricted by the terms of the agreement; a party 
      cannot be required to submit to arbitration any dispute which he has not 
      agreed to submit.Â  Zabinski v. Bright Acres Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 
      596-97, 553 S.E.2d 110, 118 (2001).Â Â Â Â  
    The arbitration agreement in the instant case provides 
      in pertinent part:

    Any controversy, claim or dispute arising out of or relating 
      to this Agreement or your purchase of the Home including claims under the 
      Limited Warranty shall be settled by arbitration pursuant to the Uniform 
      Arbitration Act, Section 15-48-10 et seq., Code of Laws of South 
      Carolina (1976) as amended, in accordance with the Construction Industry 
      Arbitration Rules of the American Arbitration Association (â€œAAAâ€), and judgment 
      rendered by the arbitrator(s) may be confirmed, entered and enforced in 
      any court having jurisdiction.Â  

    The plain meaning of this clause 
      is that arbitration was intended by the parties to resolve all disputes 
      arising out of or relating to the purchase of the home.Â  The clause is expressly 
      limited to â€œ[a]ny controversy, claim or dispute arising out of or relating 
      to this Agreement or your purchase of the Home including claims 
      under the Limited Warranty.â€ (emphasis added) Thus, the arbitration 
      clause would clearly apply to contract-based causes of action â€“ those claims 
      relating to the agreement, the purchase of the home, or the limited warranty.Â  
      However, Respondentsâ€™ claims for negligence and loss of consortium are tort-based 
      claims, unrelated to any of these three subjects.Â  
    In order to decide whether an arbitration agreement 
      encompasses a dispute, the court must determine whether the factual allegations 
      underlying the claim fall within the scope of the arbitration clause, regardless 
      of the label assigned to the claim.Â  Zabinski, 346 S.C. at 597, 553 
      S.E.2d at 118.Â  One method to determine whether a tort cause of action falls 
      within the scope of an agreement to arbitrate is to determine whether â€œthe 
      particular tort claim is so interwoven with the contract that it could not 
      stand alone.â€Â  Id., at 597 n.4, 553 S.E.2d at 119 n.4.Â  â€œ[I]f the 
      tort claim is completely independent of the contract and could be maintained 
      without reference to the contract, the tort claim is not arbitrable.â€Â  Id.Â  
    
    In the instant case, Respondentsâ€™ alleged personal 
      injuries stem from the fact that a storage room was improperly constructed 
      such that it could not support Reubenâ€™s weight.Â  As public policy imposes 
      a legal duty upon builders to construct safe housing, Respondents need not 
      sue Palmetto under the contract to recover for such tort-based injuries.Â  
      See Kennedy v. Columbia Lumber & Mfg. Co., 299 S.C. 335, 
      346, 384 S.E.2d 730, 737 (1989) (â€œpublic policy . . . demands the imposition 
      of a legal duty on a builder to refrain from constructing housing that he 
      knows or should know will pose serious risks of physical harm. . .â€ and 
      â€œsuch a duty . . . should extend to foreseeable parties. . . .â€).Â  In the 
      case at hand, the alleged serious risk of physical harm was not personal 
      to Respondents as those who purchased the home and entered the arbitration 
      agreement.Â  We find compelling Palmettoâ€™s argument that the person falling 
      through the floor could have been a household member or guest in the home 
      who would not be bound by the arbitration agreement, yet could maintain 
      a tort action against Palmetto.Â  The fact that Reuben is a party to the 
      agreement and is the person who allegedly fell through the floor is inconsequential.Â  
      The personal injuries alleged by Respondents, based on Palmettoâ€™s negligent 
      acts, are not so interwoven with the contract that they could not stand 
      alone.
       AFFIRMED.
      HUFF, STILWELL, and CURETON, 
        A.J., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Randall J. Trost,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Sea Mark Tower Property Owners Association, Inc., and The Noble Company 
        of Myrtle Beach,        Defendants,
Of Whom Sea Mark Tower Property Owners Association, Inc., is       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
J. Stanton Cross, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-284
Submitted April 6, 2004 â€“ Filed April 
  29, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Henrietta U. Golding, of Myrtle Beach, for Appellant.
Randall J. Trost, of Lynchburg, Virginia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Sea Mark Tower Property Owners 
  Association, Inc. (â€œAssociationâ€) appeals the Master-in-Equityâ€™s decision ordering 
  it to reinstall the awnings over the balconies of the penthouse units in the 
  Sea Mark Tower Horizontal Property Regime (â€œRegimeâ€). We affirm.
FACTS
The Regime was established in 
  December of 1994 and Sea Mark Tower was built in 1985.Â  At the time of building 
  construction, awnings were installed over the balconies of the two penthouse 
  units.Â  
There have been numerous problems with water intrusion 
  into the building for years.Â  InÂ  1998, the Association hired Law Engineering 
  and Environmental Securities, Inc. to assess the buildingâ€™s structural integrity 
  and identify the reasons for water leakage problems with the building.Â  Although 
  the Law Engineering reports revealed water leakage problems from roofs, windows, 
  and the stucco, they did not state that the penthouse awnings were sources of 
  any water leakage.Â  
Upon receiving the Law Engineering reports, the 
  Association hired Glasstec, a waterproofing company, to correct the water leakage 
  problems.Â  In order to waterproof the walls and floors of the penthouse balconies, 
  Glasstec removed the awnings and awning structures.Â  Glasstec refused to provide 
  a warranty on its work if the awning structures were replaced through its waterproofing.Â  
  Randall Trost, the owner of penthouse unit 1201 demanded the awning be replaced.Â  
  The Board offered to restore the awnings, but only if Trost took responsibility 
  for any subsequent leakage.Â  Trost refused.Â  The awnings have not been restored 
  to their original position.
Trost filed this action against the Association 
  seeking an injunction requiring the Association to replace the awning structures 
  on the balconies and refrain from interfering with the awnings in the future.Â  
  The master determined the penthouse awnings were limited common elements and 
  their removal by the Association was an ultra vires act.Â  The 
  master ordered the Association to pay for all expenses and damages from the 
  awningsâ€™ removal and to pay for their reinstallation.Â  This appeal followed.Â  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
Actions for injunctive relief are equitable 
  in nature.Â  Godfrey v. Heller, 311 S.C. 516, 517, 429 S.E.2d 859, 860 
  (Ct. App. 1993).Â  On appeal, in an action in equity, tried by a master alone, 
  this court may find facts in accordance with its views of the preponderance 
  of the evidence.Â  Tiger, Inc. v. Fisher Agro, Inc., 301 S.C. 229, 237, 
  391 S.E.2d 538, 543 (1989); Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 
  266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  This broad scope of review, however, 
  does not require this court to disregard the findings of the master, who saw 
  and heard the witnesses and was in a better position to evaluate their credibility.Â  
  Tiger, 301 S.C. at 237, 391 S.E.2d at 543.
LAW/ANALYSIS
  I.      Limited Common Elements Designation
Appellant argues the master erred in finding the 
  penthouse awnings are limited common elements.Â  We disagree.Â  
The master deed of a horizontal property regime 
  should be strictly enforced.Â  Kneale v. Bonds, 317 S.C. 262, 267, 452 
  S.E.2d 840, 842 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  Under the Regimeâ€™s master deed, the Regime 
  consists of units, general common elements, and limited common elements.Â  The 
  master deed defines each unit as â€œthe interior cubic space, fixtures, appliances, 
  furnishings, walls, floors, ceilings, and building material enclosed withinâ€ 
  the unfinished surface of the structural slab of the ceiling and floor and the 
  unfinished interior surface of the perimeter walls, except for load bearing 
  walls, which are common elements.Â  The unit also includes â€œall appurtenances 
  which are integral and exclusive to the Unit, including but not limited to lamps 
  attached to the exterior of the Unit . . .â€Â  
The master deed does not include such a detailed 
  description of what constitutes a limited common element.Â  According to the 
  Horizontal Property Act, limited common elements are â€œthose common elements 
  which are agreed upon by all the co-owners to be reserved for the use of a certain 
  number of apartments to the exclusion of the other apartments . . .â€Â  S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 27-31-20(g) (1991).Â  Although the master deed does not include a definition 
  of limited common elements, Exhibit B of the master deed provides that â€œthe 
  balcony or balconies adjacent to each unit, including the railing adjacent to 
  the same, is a limited common area and is subject to the restrictions and requirements 
  as are set out elsewhere in this master deed.â€Â  
We find a strict construction of the master deed 
  supports the masterâ€™s ruling the awnings are limited common elements. There 
  is no language in the deed to support the Associationâ€™s contention that the 
  awning is part of the unit. The deed confines the unit to the area within the 
  four walls, ceiling and floor, with the exception of the specifically mentioned 
  exterior lamp.Â  In contrast, the deed does provide support for Trostâ€™s assertion 
  that the awnings are limited common elements by providing the balconies are 
  limited common elements.Â  It can hardly be said that the balconies are limited 
  common elements, yet the awnings that hang over them are not.Â  
In addition, the testimony presented during trial 
  supports the masterâ€™s conclusion that the awnings are limited common elements.Â  
  Sandy Kelly, the president of the Association testified that in 1999 the Associationâ€™s 
  Board of Directors had concluded the awnings were common elements of the Regime.Â  
  Three witnesses involved in the development, design, and construction of Sea 
  Mark Tower also confirmed the awnings were limited common elements.Â  Kit Christopher, 
  Sea Mark Towerâ€™s developer and original owner of unit 1201 testified the awnings 
  were intended to be an â€œarchitectural featureâ€ of the building.Â  George Howell, 
  designer of Sea Mark Tower, testified the awnings were included as part of the 
  original design on construction drawings for the building, and were intended 
  to enhance the overall appearance and attractiveness of the building.Â  Tom Roe, 
  also an original developer of Sea Mark Tower, Roe testified it was the intent 
  of developers that the awnings be common elements or limited common elements 
  when they were installed.Â  He declared, â€œI signed the Master Deed.Â  I was on 
  the original Board.Â  Iâ€™ve served as Treasurer and President.Â  And there was 
  never any question in my mind . . . about the nature of those awnings.â€Â  
Based on the above, we find the master properly 
  concluded the penthouse awnings were limited common elements.Â  
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Removal of the Penthouse AwningsÂ  
The Association argues that because the master 
  designated the penthouse awnings to be limited common elements, he erred in 
  finding the removal of the penthouse awnings was beyond the Associationâ€™s authority.Â  
  We disagree.
The board of directors of a horizontal 
  property regime may exercise only those powers that are granted to it by law, 
  its master deed, and by any bylaws made pursuant thereto.Â  See S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ Â§ 27-31-100 and 37-31-150 (1991); Seabrook Island Prop. Owners Assâ€™n 
  v. Pelzer, 292 S.C. 343, 347, 356 S.E.2d 411, 414 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  Any 
  act beyond the scope of the powers so granted is ultra vires.Â  Seabrook, 
  292 S.C. at 347, 356 S.E.2d at 414.Â  In addition, the allocation of a limited 
  common element may not be altered without the consent of the unit owners whose 
  units are affected. 15A Am. Jur. 2nd Condominiums Â§ 30 (2000).
Section XVIII of the master deed states:

The Association shall have the right to make or cause to 
  be made such alterations, modifications and improvements to the common elements, 
  provided such alterations, modifications or improvements are first approved 
  in writing by the Board of Directors of the Association; provided further that 
  such alterations, modifications or improvements do not adversely affect the 
  value of the Common Elements or Units in the Regime and the cost of such alterations, 
  modifications or improvements shall be assessed as common expenses . . . .  [1] 

 Clearly, the master deed does not grant 
  the Association express power to remove the awnings.Â  As the awnings are limited 
  common elements the Association only has authority under section XVIII of the 
  master deed to alter, modify, or improve them.Â  The master 
  deed does not grant the Association the power to permanently remove a 
  limited common element.Â  In fact, Article XX of the master deed mandates that 
  the Association shall be responsible for the maintenance, repair, and replacement 
  of all the common elements.Â  
Furthermore, Article XVIII of the master deed 
  only allows alterations, modifications, and improvements to common elements 
  that do not adversely affect the value of the common elements or units.Â  Removing 
  the awnings rendered them completely worthless.Â  In addition, other common elements 
  and units were adversely affected.Â  For example, removal of the awnings affected 
  the architectural appearance of the building and the ability of the penthouse 
  unitsâ€™ air conditioning systems to adequately cool the units.Â  Accordingly, 
  the permanent removal of the awnings was in contravention of Article XVIII. 

 The Association asserts it was fulfilling 
  its obligation under the master deed to repair the regime property by deciding 
  to not replace the awnings, which it claims were a source of water intrusion.Â  

There is no evidence in the record demonstrating 
  the penthouse awnings were a source of water leakage.Â  The Law Engineering reports 
  did not indicate the penthouse awnings contributed to the water leakage.Â  A 
  previous Board member, Thomas Roe, testified that he and others attempted to 
  locate water leaks by hosing down the balcony of unit 1201.Â  However, they were 
  unsuccessful in tracing any leakage to the awnings.Â  In addition, although Ron 
  Weaver of Glasstec testified the awning framework would jeopardize the integrity 
  of the waterproofing, he acknowledged that proper sealing would have been sufficient 
  to prevent any leakage.Â  Thus, simple repair and maintenance, which is required 
  under the master deed, was sufficient.Â  As the master deed must be strictly 
  enforced, we find the Association only had the power to repair and maintain, 
  not permanently remove, the penthouse awnings.Â  Accordingly, the Association 
  was acting beyond the scope of its authority in deciding against reinstalling 
  the awnings after work was completed on the balconies.
Â III.Â Â  Business Judgment
Rule   
The Association argues its decision to remove 
  the penthouse awnings is protected by the business judgment rule.Â  We disagree.Â  

The business judgment rule only applies to intra 
  vires acts, and not to ultra vires acts.Â  Seabrook Island Prop. Owners 
  Assâ€™n v. Pelzer, 292 S.C. 343, 348, 356 S.E.2d 411, 414 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  
  The Association was only permitted to act in accordance with the law or the 
  master deed; any act outside the scope of its power was an ultra vires 
  act. See Kuznick v. Bees Ferry Assocs., 342 S.C. 579, 605, 538 
  S.E.2d 15, 28 (Ct. App. 2000).
As we held above, the master deed did not grant 
  the Association the power to permanently remove the awnings.Â  As the removal 
  of the awnings was an ultra vires act, the Association is not 
  protected by the business judgment rule.Â Â  
CONCLUSION  
Based on the above, we find the penthouse awnings 
  are limited common elements.Â  We further find Appellant was without power to 
  permanently remove the awnings and its decision to remove them was not protected 
  by the business judgment rule.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the lower court 
  is
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, STILWELL, and CURETON, A.J., concur.

 
   [1]  The master deed provides, â€œThe General Common 
    Elements and the Limited Common Elements are hereinafter occasionally collectively 
    referred to as â€œthe Common Elements.â€
