THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Joseph R. Allsbrook, Jr. and Russell
Allsbrook,        Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Horry County, A Body Politic, Billy V. Roberts and Roy C. Roberts,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Steven H. John, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-285
Submitted April 6, 2004 â€“ Filed April 
  30, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John R. Clarke, of North Myrtle Beach, for Appellants.
Mark Andrew Brunty and Thomas C. Brittain, both of Myrtle 
  Beach, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Appellants Joseph R. Allsbrook, 
  Jr., and Russell Allsbrook (Allsbrooks) brought this action against Horry County 
  to set aside a tax sale of real property located in Garden City, South Carolina.Â  
  The Allsbrooks also asserted claims against Billy V. Roberts and Roy C. Roberts 
  for equitable avoidance and breach of fiduciary duty related to the tax sale.Â  
  The circuit court granted the respondentsâ€™ motion for summary judgment, finding 
  the Allsbrooksâ€™ claims were barred by the applicable two-year statute of limitations.Â  
  This appeal followed.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Carolyn A. Roberts died in July 1991, leaving a 
  holographic will disposing of her personal and real property, including her 
  half-interests in two Garden City lots.Â  These lots are at the center of the 
  dispute in this case.Â  The will devised Mrs. Robertsâ€™ 50% interest in one of 
  the lots to her brother, Joseph Allsbrook, Jr., and her 50% interest in the 
  other lot to her nephew, Russell Allsbrook.Â  Mrs. Robertsâ€™ surviving husband, 
  Billy V. Roberts, was appointed personal representative of the estate.Â  
As this appeal turns on the application of the 
  statute of limitations, the following timeline is critical:Â  In April 1993, 
  nearly two years after Mrs. Robertsâ€™ death, Horry County issued an official 
  Notice of Levy on the Garden City lots for failure to pay property taxes.Â  Because 
  no one claiming an interest in the lots paid the taxes, a delinquent tax sale 
  was held on October 4, 1993.Â  Respondent Roy C. Roberts was the successful bidder.Â  
  In December 1994, Roy Roberts filed the tax deed to the lots in his name.Â  
The probate hearing for Carolyn Robertsâ€™ 
  estate was held on June 8, 1995.Â  At the hearing, Joseph Allsbrook challenged 
  Billy Robertsâ€™ distribution of several items of Mrs. Robertsâ€™ personal and real 
  property.Â  Joseph also argued before the probate judge that Billy Roberts allowed 
  the property in question to be sold for delinquent taxes without notifying the 
  beneficiaries.Â  Billyâ€™s attorney noted the probate matter was one to determine 
  the assets of the estate, and if Joseph sought some additional remedy he would 
  need to bring a separate action against Billy.Â  Josephâ€™s attorney agreed that 
  the lots were assets of the estate, and the probate judge then stated, â€œSo everyone 
  understands it is clearly an asset of the estate, and there is nothing for me 
  to determine under this [provision].â€Â  In its order, the probate court found 
  with respect to the provision on the property in question, â€œthe matter is agreed 
  between the parties and the property contained in paragraph 9 is an asset of 
  the estate.â€Â  Joseph appealed the probate courtâ€™s distribution to the circuit 
  court, and later to the Court of Appeals.Â  This courtâ€™s final opinion was filed 
  November 8, 2000.Â  Allsbrook v. Estate of Roberts, Op. No. 2000-UP-509 
  (S.C. Ct. App. Filed Nov. 8, 2000).In regard to the Garden City lots, this court 
  held as follows:

Allsbrook asserts the probate court erred in holding the lots 
  in Garden City, devised in paragraph nine of the will, were assets of the estate.Â  
  At the hearing, the parties agreed the lots were estate assets. . . . Allsbrook 
  is not aggrieved by this ruling.Â  See Rule 201(b), SCACR (â€œOnly a party 
  aggrieved by an order, judgment or sentence may appeal.â€).Â  Therefore we affirm 
  the probate courtâ€™s disposition of this issue.

Id.
On February 6, 2001, the Allsbrooks filed 
  the present action seeking to set aside the 1993 tax sale of the Garden City 
  lots.Â  The Allsbrooks alleged Horry County failed to conform to the strict and 
  specific requirements of the statutes governing notice and sale of property 
  to satisfy delinquent taxes.Â  They further alleged causes of action against 
  Billy Roberts, as personal representative, for breach of fiduciary duty and 
  equitable avoidance stemming from his failure to pay the delinquent taxes on 
  the lots or properly notify the Allsbrooks of the impending tax sale.Â  On Respondentsâ€™ 
  motions for summary judgment, the circuit court dismissed the Allsbrooksâ€™ claims, 
  finding they were barred by the two-year statute of limitations prescribed by 
  South Carolina Code Â§ 12-51-160.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment 
  motion, the appellate court applies the same standard which governs the trial 
  court:Â  Summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any 
  material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  
  Laurens Emergency Med. Specialists v. M.S. Bailey & Sons Bankers, 
  355 S.C. 104, 108-09, 584 S.E.2d 375, 377 (2003); see also McDonnell 
  v. Consol. Sch. Dist. of Aiken, 315 S.C. 487, 489, 445 S.E.2d 638, 639 (1994) 
  (holding a motion for summary judgment can be used to raise the defense of statute 
  of limitations).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Allsbrooksâ€™ Claim Against Horry County
The Allsbrooks first argue the circuit 
  court erred in granting summary judgment in favor of Horry County on their claim 
  seeking to set aside the tax sale.Â  We find the circuit court properly ruled 
  this cause of action was barred by the statute of limitations.
South Carolina Code Ann. Â§Â§ 12-51-40 and 
  12-51-50 (Supp. 2003) authorize counties to sell the property of taxpayers delinquent 
  in paying their property taxes.Â  In granting this authority, the Code prescribes 
  the requirements for notice and conduct of the saleâ€”requirements that are strictly 
  enforced.Â  See Â§ 12-51-40 (a)-(f) (notice requirements); Â§ 12-51-50 (conduct 
  of sale requirements); see also Rives v. Bulsa, 325 S.C. 
  287, 292-93, 478 S.E.2d 878, 881 (Ct. App. 1996) (holding all requirements of 
  law leading up to tax sales which are intended for the protection of the taxpayer 
  against surprise or the sacrifice of his property are to be regarded as mandatory 
  and are to be strictly enforced).Â  If a taxpayer or other interested party desires 
  to challenge the propriety of a county tax sale, suit must be filed within the 
  limitations period prescribed by Â§ 12-51-160 which provides in part:Â  â€œNo action 
  for the recovery of land sold under the provisions of this chapter or for the 
  recovery of the possession may be maintained unless brought within two years 
  from the date of sale.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-160 (2000).
In the present case, the Allsbrooks do 
  not dispute the fact they brought their action to set aside the tax sale over 
  seven years after the date of sale.Â  Rather, they contend the two-year limitations 
  period of Â§ 12-51-160 was tolled during the pendency of their appeal from the 
  probate courtâ€™s order on the distribution of the estate.Â  We disagree.
Though our stateâ€™s courts have not had 
  occasion to consider the narrow question presented, it is well settled in our 
  nationâ€™s jurisprudence that the pendency of other legal proceedings may toll 
  the statute of limitations on a cause of action where such proceedings prevent 
  enforcement of the remedy by action.Â  See 54 C.J.S. Limitations of 
  Actions Â§ 121 (1987) (noting that â€œ[w]here a person is prevented from exercising 
  his legal remedy by the pendency of legal proceedings, the time during which 
  he is thus prevented should not be counted against him in determining whether 
  limitations have barred his rightâ€); 51 Am. Jur. 2d Limitations of Actions 
  Â§ 207 (2000) (noting that â€œ[d]uring the period of the restraint incident to 
  other legal proceedings that are of such a character that the law forbids one 
  of the parties to exercise a legal remedy against another, the running of the 
  statute of limitations is postponed, or, if it has commenced to run, is suspendedâ€).
In the main, the courts have found that 
  limitations periods are tolled by other pending actions where the pursuit of 
  additional or alternative legal remedies is expressly prohibited by statute.Â  
  Typically, this situation arises under statutory schemes that require the exhaustion 
  of all administrative remedies before common-law claims seeking redress for 
  the injury are permitted.Â  See, e.g., Trent v. Bolger, 
  837 F.2d 657, 659-60 (4th Cir. 1988) (holding that when an employee is required 
  to exhaust administrative remedies, applicable limitations period for filing 
  action is tolled pending exhaustion of the administrative channels); Butler 
  v. Glen Oakâ€™s Turf, Inc., 196 Ga. App. 98, 101, 395 S.E.2d 277, 280 (1990) 
  (holding that the statute of limitations was tolled on an employeeâ€™s common-law 
  tort claim because she was legally barred from pursuing that claim during the 
  pendency of her workersâ€™ compensation case).Â  
In the present case, the ongoing probate 
  action involving the disposition of Mrs. Robertsâ€™ estate posed no obstacle to 
  the Allsbrooksâ€™ ability to pursue their remedy under the statute governing county 
  tax sales.Â  As devisees under the will, their interests in the Garden City lots 
  vested immediately upon her death. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-101 (Supp. 2003); see 
  also In re Will of Hall, 318 S.C. 188, 192, 456 S.E.2d 439, 441 
  (Ct. App. 1995) (holding that devisee of life estate under will received her 
  interest in the property the day the testatrix died).Â  The fact of pending collateral 
  litigation with respect to the distribution of property under the will did not 
  affect the deviseesâ€™ right to pursue their remedies under the tax sale provisions 
  of the Code.Â  Thus, the two-year limitations period was not tolled during the 
  pendency of the probate action.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the circuit courtâ€™s 
  finding that the Allsbrooksâ€™ action to set aside the tax sale was barred by 
  the statute of limitations.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Allsbrooksâ€™ Claims Against Billy Roberts 
  and Roy Roberts
The Allsbrooks also appeal the circuit 
  courtâ€™s dismissal of their causes of action against Billy Roberts and Roy Roberts 
  for â€œequitable avoidanceâ€ [1]  and breach of fiduciary duty.Â  Under these 
  claims, the Allsbrooks essentially alleged Billy Roberts breached his duty of 
  care as personal representative of the estate by failing to ensure the taxes 
  on the Garden City lots were timely paid, failing to notify the Allsbrooks of 
  the tax arrears and impending tax sale, and failing to inform the Allsbrooks 
  of their right to redeem the property.Â  These causes of action were dismissed 
  by the circuit court as barred by the statute of limitations under S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 12-51-160.
The Allsbrooks argue it was error for 
  the circuit court to apply the limitations period prescribed under the statutory 
  provisions governing tax sales to their claims for breach of fiduciary duty 
  against Billy Roberts.Â  Under the undisputed facts of the present case, however, 
  we consider this question to be purely academic as it would have no impact on 
  the result reached by the lower court.Â  
Even if the court applied the maximum three-year 
  statute of limitations generally applied to breach of fiduciary duty claims, 
  the Allsbrooksâ€™ claims would still be barred.Â  A cause of action for breach 
  of fiduciary duty is governed by the discovery rule and must be brought within 
  three years of the time the person knew or should have known by exercise of 
  reasonable diligence that he had a cause of action.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§Â§ 15-3-530(5) and 15-3-535 (Supp. 2003); Rumpf v. Massachusetts Mut. Life 
  Ins. Co., 357 S.C. 386, 394, 593 S.E.2d 183, 187 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  
In this case, the Allsbrooks knew by June 1995 
  that Billy Roberts allowed the property in question to be sold for delinquent 
  taxes and that Roy Roberts had purchased the property at the tax sale.Â  Indeed, 
  counsel for Joseph clearly admitted at the June 8, 1995, probate hearing that 
  the Allsbrooks were fully aware of the tax sale and its implications, stating: 


[W]e will submit to the Court 
  documents that one of the parcels of land that is in the Will, was allowed to 
  be sold for taxes through the Horry County Delinquent Tax Collectors office 
  . . . As fiduciary, [Billy Roberts] has the responsibility to protect those 
  assets of the estate during the administration. . . .Â  I think it is admitted 
  that the property was sold through the delinquent tax office, and was purchased 
  by Roy Roberts . . .Â  [Billy] Roberts as fiduciary personal representative, 
  never notified any of the beneficiaries of the delinquent tax notice or anything, 
  and they did not have the opportunity to purchase that property at the tax sale 
  or her interest in it, at the tax sale. 

Therefore, actual knowledge of the tax sale can 
  be imputed to the Allsbrooks no later than the date of the probate hearing, 
  nearly six years before they brought the present action in February 2001.Â  The 
  three-year maximum limitations period of Â§ 15-3-530 was unquestionably exceeded.
We conclude, therefore, that if the circuit 
  court erred by lumping together all of the Allsbrooksâ€™ claims under the umbrella 
  of Â§ 12-51-160â€™s limitations period, the error is a harmless one.Â  
CONCLUSION
For these reasons, we find no error with 
  the trial courtâ€™s finding that all claims of the Allsbrooks were barred by the 
  applicable statute of limitations.Â  The order granting summary judgment in favor 
  of Respondents is therefore
 AFFIRMED.
HUFF, STILWELL, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., 
  concur.

 
   
    [1] Our research reveals no cases in South Carolina that recognize a cause 
    of action for â€œequitable avoidance.â€Â  The allegations under this claim in 
    the Allsbrooksâ€™ complaint mirror those listed under the breach of fiduciary 
    duty cause of action in all material respects.Â  
  Â
